FacilityDescription: Occidental Chemical Corporation owns and operates the Oxychem Ingleside Plant located in San Patricio County, Texas. The plant heats ethane gas and later compresses the heated product to produce ethylene, which is used to create many common plastics.

FacilityDescription: Located in Garrard County, Kentucky, the Paint Lick Compressor Station compresses natural gas received from pipelines for further pipeline transportation. Columbia Gulf Transmission owns and operates the Paint Lick Compressor Station.

Pallas Nitrogen, LLC’s proposed Pallas Nitrogen Plant would be located along the Ohio River in Columbiana County, Ohio. The plant would use natural gas to produce up to 643,860 tons of ammonia per year and a variety of other nitrogen-based fertilizers. The plant would consume an estimated 58 million cubic feet of natural gas per day (about 23 billion cubic feet per year). Because Pallas Nitrogen did not commence construction on the facility by the deadline in its air quality permit or request an extension, the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency confirmed in 2021 that the original air quality permit was invalid in response to a letter from the Environmental Integrity Project.

The Payne Compressor Station is located in Marshall County, West Virginia. The facility is owned and operated by XCL Midstream Operating LLC. The compressor station serves to both compress and dehydrate natural gas from local production wells prior to pipeline transmission.

The Pendleton Compressor Station is a proposed compressor station located in Niagara County, New York. This compressor station would be owned and operated by Empire Pipeline Inc. and is being proposed as part of National Fuel Gas Corporation's (NFG) Northern Access 2016 Project. In June 2022, NFG was granted an extension of time until December 31, 2024 to construct and place the project into service.
ResearchNotes: LM 10/12/21: Facility location from project map

FacilityDescription: The Shell Polymers Monaca Site (formerly known as the Shell Chemical Appalachia Petrochemicals Complex) is a new petrochemical and plastics plant located north-west of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania on the Ohio River. The plant has the capacity to produce 1.6 million metric tons of polyethylene pellets per year. Shell began constructing the complex in November 2017 and it began operating in Novemeber 2022. It includes an ethane cracker, which will convert ethane from the Marcellus and Utica shale formations into ethylene, a petrochemical used to make polyethylene plastic and other types of chemicals. The plant also has three polyethylene units, an on-site natural gas power plant, a rail system, loading facilities, and a wastewater treatment plant. The plant's ethane supply comes from Shell's new 97-mile Falcon Ethane Pipeline, which connects to several new and expanding natural gas liquids fractionation plants in the region. The pipeline began construction in 2019 and was commissioned in October 2021. For additional information about the environmental approvals requested by or issued to this plant, visit the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection's website. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility. Additional information is available on the company’s website.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: The Pine Bend Refinery is an existing oil refinery in Rosemount, Minnesota, located about 25 miles south of the Twin Cities. It was originally constructed in 1955 and is now owned and operated by Flint Hills Resources, a subsidiary of Koch Industries. The Pine Bend Refinery can process up to 375,000 barrels (15.75 million gallons) of refined products every year, including transportation fuels, propane, asphalt, and heating fuels. It also manufactures chemicals used to make plastics, fertilizers, and other synthetic materials. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.

The Pioneer Compressor Station is located in Ohio County, West Virginia, and is owned and operated by Appalachia Midstream Services LLC. The facility receives natural gas from local production wells and compresses it for pipeline transportation.

Enlink Processing Services owns and operates the Plaquemine NGL Fractionation Plant located in Iberville County, Louisiana. The plant fractionates (a form of separating) inlet natural gas liquids into constituents product streams for sale. The facility has a throughput capacity of around 51.1 million barrels of natural gas liquids per year.
ResearchNotes: From V3 permit: This facility is contiguous and under common control with the Plaquemine Gas Plant (AI # 19184). Current TV permit = 1280-00049-V7 (issued 3/19/2020): https://edms.deq.louisiana.gov/app/doc/view?doc=12122164

FacilityDescription: Plaquemines Liquid Terminal LLC proposed to build the Plaquemines Liquid Terminal in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana. The proposed facility would have served 2 purposes: storing and exporting bulk natural gas liquids. However, part of the facility would have been built on historic slave burial grounds, which drove members of the local community spoke out against the construction of the facility. Construction of the facility has since been cancelled, and the permit issued to Plaquemines Liquid Terminal LLC has been revoked.
ResearchNotes:
The terminal would be fed by a pipeline with the capacity to transport up to 800,000 barrels of crude oil per day from Cushing, Oklahoma, to Louisiana.

https://www.opportunitylouisiana.com/led-news/news-releases/news/2018/08/29/plaquemines-port-pursues-crude-oil-export-terminal

FacilityDescription: The Plaquemines LNG Terminal is a proposed liquefied natural gas export terminal located in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana, south of New Orleans. The facility which would be capable of processing up to 24 million tons of LNG per year for export. The Plaquemines LNG Terminal would receive natural gas from the proposed Gator Express Pipeline, which would consist of two new pipelines designed to deliver nearly 4 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: The Ashley Plastics Renewal Facility​ is a plastics-to-fuel plant located in Steuben County, Indiana, which converts mixed plastics into 18 million gallons per year of ultra-low sulfur diesel fuel, 6 million gallons per year of paraffin wax, and naphtha blend stocks. While some sources at the facility were constructed and began operating in 2020, the plant caught fire just a year later and, after two years, the company has failed to get the plant up and running at commercial scale.

This facility consists of sixteen production units and support facilities, including olefins, LLDPE (Linear Low-Density Polyethylene), HDPE (High Density Polyethylene), polypropylene, and VCM/PVC (vinyl chloride monomer/polyvinyl chloride) production units, among others.

FacilityDescription: ExxonMobil Alaska Production Inc. owns and operates the Point Thomson Production Facility located in Point Thomson on the North Slope of Alaska, an area home to large stores of natural gas and natural gas condensate. The production facility processes feed gas into hydrocarbon condensate, with a production capacity of 10,000 barrels-per-day of hydrocarbon condensate. Many anticipate that the facility will export gas via pipeline; the Point Thomson facility will be connected to the proposed Alaska Nikski LNG Pipeline by a 62.5-mile gas transmission line. Moreover, the facility will send feed gas produced to Alaska Gasline Development Corporation’s Alaska LNG – Gas Treatment Plant for further treatment once the gas treatment plant is fully constructed and operational (around 2031).

FacilityDescription: Air Liquide's Port Allen Air Separation Unit is located in West Baton Rouge Parish, Louisiana, next to Exxon's Port Allen Aviation Plant, which manufactures jet fuel and lubricants. This new facility, which began operating in 2022, produces industrial gases, like oxygen, nitrogen, and crude argon, by cryogenically separating air. These products are used by Methanex at its Geismar Methanol Plant, according to reporting by The Advocate.

Bayport Polymers' (Baystar) Port Arthur Side Ethane Cracker is a new ethylene cracker located in Jefferson County, Texas. It's one of the largest steam crackers in the world, capable of producing over 1 million tons of ethylene per year, and is designed to supply ethylene feedstock to Bayport Polymers' Pasadena Polyethylene Plant, located about 80 miles west, in Harris County, Texas. Baystar's Port Arthur Side Ethane Cracker is co-located with Total’s Port Arthur Refinery and the BASF/TOTAL Olefins Complex.

Sempra is also developing the Titan Carbon Sequestration project, which would inject carbon dioxide captured from the LNG facility and potentially other industrial sources.

Liquefied natural gas (LNG) is natural gas that has been cooled to a liquid state, allowing it to be exported on tankers to overseas markets that would otherwise be inaccessible through pipeline transport. It is produced using liquefaction units—called “trains” by the industry—that remove impurities and then liquefy or condense the gas at sub-zero temperatures.

FacilityDescription: INV Propylene, LLC (also known as INVISTA) owns and operates its chemical manufacturing plant in Harris County, Texas. Prior to 2022, the facility was owned and operated by Flint Hills Resources Houston Chemical, LLC; the company changed its name due to corporate restructuring of these two subsidiaries of Koch Industries. The Houston Chemical Plant produces propylene from propane and propane mixed with propylene. This production occurs through a process known as catalytic dehydrogenation. Propylene—the facility’s primary final product—has several uses, as it is a key ingredient in the construction of auto parts, wire coatings, and adhesives.
ResearchNotes:
Flint Hills Resources Houston Chemical LLC acquired the Houston Chemical Plant from PL Propylene, LLC on July 16, 2014.

Delaware Basin Midstream, LLC owns and operates its Ramsey Gas Plant in Reeves County, Texas. The facility receives natural gas from local pipelines and then cryogenically processes, compresses, and distributes the gas via pipelines for later sale.
One of eight new natural-gas fired compressor stations proposed for the Alaska Nikiski LNG Pipeline.

The Red Hills Gas Processing Plant in Lea County, New Mexico is located near the Delaware shale formation, one of three "sub-basins" that make up the prolific Permian Basin. The primary function of the plant is to remove hydrogen sulfide, carbon dioxide, and water from field gas so that the gas can meet pipeline specifications. The maximum inlet capacity of the plant is 520,124 million standard cubic feet per year.

ETC Northeast Pipeline LLC, a subsidiary of Energy Transfer, owns and operates the Revolution Cryogenic Plant located in Washington County, Pennsylvania. FacilityDescription: Appalachia Midstream Services, LLC, owns and operates the Ridgeline Compressor Station located in Marshall County, West Virginia. The facility removes liquids from incoming field gas, then compresses and dehydrates the gas for later pipeline transportation.

Elba Express Company LLC owns and operates the Rincon Compressor Station, which is located in Effingham County, Georgia. The facility compresses natural gas so that it is suitable for transportation via pipelines. It was constructed to support an expansion at the Elba Island LNG Terminal.
The proposed Rio Bravo Compressor Station 1 would be located in Kleberg County, Texas, along the Rio Bravo Pipeline that would supply natural gas to the Rio Grande LNG Terminal in Brownsville, Texas.

FacilityDescription:
The Rio Grande LNG Terminal is a proposed liquefied natural gas terminal located along the Brownsville Ship Channel in Cameron County, Texas. If constructed, it would be capable of producing up to 27 million tons of liquefied natural gas every year for export. The terminal would receive natural gas from a new, 137.3-mile-long pipeline system developed by Enbridge Inc. Initially, the project included plans for a carbon capture and sequestration facility that, according to the company, could reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 94 percent. But on August 20, 2024 NextDecade withdrew their application for the carbon capture and sequestration facility.

On August 6, 2024, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit issued an opinion vacating and remanding the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's authorization for the Rio Grande LNG Terminal and Rio Bravo Pipeline Project. The court ruled that FERC failed to conduct a supplemental environmental review and address environmental justice and air quality issues in response to a previous court decision. On remand, the Commission will prepare a supplemental EIS and re-consider whether to grant the authorizations.
ResearchNotes:
GB 8/26/24: Added language to reflect that plans for CCS project have been cancelled.

FacilityDescription: The Riverside Compressor Station is a greenfield compressor station in Mckenzie County, ND. The facility, which receives natural gas from a pipeline gathering system, boosts the gas pressure to aid in transporting via pipeline.

The Roadrunner Gas Processing Plant in Eddy County, New Mexico is located near the Delaware shale basin, one of three formations that make up the prolific Permian Basin. This facility has been expanding incrementally since it was first constructed in 2017, with plans to triple capacity from 220 to 735 million cubic feet per day. The Roadrunner Gas Processing Plant was owned by the Lucid Energy Group, which operated the largest privately-owned gas gathering and processing system in the Northern Delaware Basin, and will supply 185 million cubic feet of fracked gas to the newly-constructed Double E Pipeline. Lucid was acquired by Targa Resources Corp in July 2022.
ResearchNotes:

The New Mexico Environment Department is accepting public comments prior to the beginning of the hearing. For more information, please refer to the [public notice](https://www.env.nm.gov/public-notices/wp-content/uploads/sites/32/2023/08/2023-08-15-EPD-AQB-Final-English-Notice-of-Hearing.pdf).

FacilityDescription: The Robstown Fractionator is owned and operated by EPIC Y-Grade, LP. Located in Neuces County, Texas, this facility fractionates mixed natural gas liquids (also known as “Y-Grade liquids”) into usable fuel products such as: ethane, propane, isobutane, normal butane, and C5+ hydrocarbons. The Robstown Fractionator currently has a fractionation capacity of 170,000 barrels per day. Notably, this fractionation complex is connected to EPIC’s 165-mile EPIC NGL pipeline, which moves natural gas liquids from both Corpus Christi and Robstown, Texas, to Sweeny, Texas.

FacilityDescription: Permico Midstream's Robstown Fractionator is a proposed natural gas liquids fractionator in Nueces County, Texas, near Corpus Christi. The facility would separate mixed natural gas liquids (also known as "Y-grade" natural gas liquids) into ethane, propane, isobutane, normal butane, and C5+ hydrocarbons. Once fully constructed, the Permico Robstown Fractionator would consist of four processing units with a combined fractionation capacity of 630,000 barrels per day.

FacilityDescription: Simplot Phosphates, LLC owns and operates the Rock Springs Fertilizer Complex located in Sweetwater County, Wyoming. This facility features an anhydrous ammonia plant that uses natural gas as a feedstock to produce anhydrous ammonia, a highly used source of nitrogen fertilizer. Notably, the ammonia plant was an addition to the existing facility, which produces phosphate fertilizer.

The Hopeton and Rose Valley Plants are two co-located gas processing facilities in Alva, Oklahoma. They have separate corporate ownership, and Hopeton was initially permitted in 2009. However, when Rose Valley was proposed, emissions from the two plants were combined into a single permitting action.

The RoughRider Compressor Station is a compressor station in Williams County, North Dakota. The project was delayed in October 2020 due to economic conditions, but a final permit was issued in June 2022 and operations commenced in April 2023.

The Sabine Pass LNG Terminal is located in Cameron Parish, Louisiana, just south of Sabine Lake on the Texas border. Owned by Cheniere Energy, it is the largest liquefied natural gas export terminal in the United States, capable of processing up to 34.6 million metric tons of liquefied natural gas every year. Cheniere plans to expand LNG processing capacity by nearly 20 million metric tons per year starting in 2032. The company also owns the Creole Trail Pipeline, which connects the Sabine Pass LNG terminal with a number of large interstate and intrastate pipelines.
ResearchNotes:

Protests and motions to intervene can be submitted [here](https://ferconline.ferc.gov/QuickComment.aspx) (docketCP24-8). FacilityDescription: One of eight new natural-gas fired compressor stations proposed for the Alaska Nikiski LNG Pipeline.

The Salt Lake City Refinery is an existing oil refinery located in Salt Lake County, Utah. It was originally constructed in 1908 and is now owned and operated by the Marathon Petroleum Corporation. The Salt Lake City Refinery is the largest refinery in Utah, capable of processing 66,000 barrels (2.7 million gallons) of crude oil every day into products like gasoline, distillates, propane, and heavy fuel oil. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.

OE 2 North, LLC, (also known as “Outrigger”) is building the Sanderson Gas Plant located in Williams County, North Dakota. The gas plant removes water from raw field gas and separates natural gas into Y-grade natural gas liquids, which are mixtures of natural gas liquids that have not yet been separated. The facility has the capacity to process 250 million metric standard cubic feet of natural gas per day.

Appalachia Midstream Services LLC owns and operates the Sand Hill Compressor Station. The station, which is located in Marshall County, West Virginia, compresses natural gas from nearby production wells for pipeline transportation.
The Sandstrom Water Treatment Facility is located in Pennsboro, West Virginia. It treats wastewater from shale development and oil and gas operations.

Sasol’s Lake Charles Chemical Complex in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana began operating in 2001. It produces ethylene and petrochemicals used to manufacture soaps, detergents, shampoos, polyester fibers, and more. The Complex was expanded in 2020 to include a 1.5 million ton ethane cracker and two 1 million ton low and linear-low density polyethylene plants, but ownership was transferred to LyondellBasell in January 2021.

EQM Gathering Opco LLC owns and operates its Saturn Compressor Station. The compressor station is located in Doddridge County, West Virginia, and compresses natural gas received from a pipeline system for further pipeline transportation.

Sawtooth Caverns, LLC is a joint venture established in 2018 between Magnum Development, NGL Energy Partners, Sawtooth Management, and Magnum Liquids, formerly a Haddington Ventures, LLC portfolio company. Sawtooth Caverns, LLC owns and operates the NGL Storage Facility, which is an underground salt cavern the company converted into a natural gas liquids storage facility. The storage facility, located in Millard County, Utah, includes infrastructure for accessibility and exportation via train and trucks. Further, the facility would be a part of the proposed Magnum Storage Project, connected via natural gas pipelines. The storage facility stores refined products, such as gasoline and diesel products.
ResearchNotes:
This facility is not a major source and is not a Title IV source; but it is subject to 40 CFR 60 NSPS Subparts A and IIII under Section 111 and 40 CFR 63 MACT Subparts A and ZZZZ regulations under Section 112. However, Title V does not apply because NSPS Subpart IIII and MACT Subpart ZZZZ exempt sources from the obligation to obtain a permit under 40 CFR part 70 (Title V permit) if the source is not otherwise required by law to obtain a permit. Therefore, Title V does not apply.

Sawtooth Caverns, LLC is a joint venture established in 2018 between Magnum Development, NGL Energy Partners, Sawtooth Management, and Magnum Liquids, formerly a Haddington Ventures, LLC portfolio company. Sawtooth Caverns, LLC controls and operates Sawtooth NGL Caverns, the largest natural gas liquids (NGL) storage facility in the western United States, with 6.1 million barrels of capacity in five purpose-built NGL caverns that hold propane and butane. The five caverns were constructed between 2014 and 2018 in Delta, Utah.

FacilityDescription: Max Midstream's Seahawk Terminal is a petroleum terminal located in the city of Point Comfort in Calhoun County, Texas. The terminal receives and stores isobutane, crude oil, and crude oil condensates and transfers the products via pipeline and marine vessel to domestic and international customers. The terminal currently has 612,000 barrels of crude/condensate storage capacity and an export capacity of 100,000 barrels per day.

FacilityDescription: Seaport Oil Terminal (SPOT) Deepwater Port is a proposed offshore platform where crude carrier ships will receive oil for international export. The port will be located approximately 35 miles off the coast of Brazoria County, Texas, in the Gulf of Mexico. SPOT Deepwater Port will be connected to the proposed Oyster Creek Terminal and its associated pipelines through two collocated offshore pipelines. SPOT Deepwater Port would be capable of loading carrier vessels with up to 2 million barrels of crude oil per day.

FacilityDescription: The Seneca Compressor Station in Pendeleton County, West Virginia, was constructed in the early 1950's and is owned and operated by Columbia Gulf Transmission LLC. The facility receives natural gas via pipeline and compresses the gas for further pipeline transportation.

MarkWest’s Seneca Gas Plant processes field gas, primarily from the Utica shale formation, into dry gas, propane, and a mixture of heavier natural gas liquids. Located in Noble County, Ohio (approximately 100 miles east of Columbus), the natural gas processing plant is composed of 5 gas plants, with a total processing capacity of approximately 1,150 million standard cubic feet per day. The plant has expanded incrementally since 2013.

FacilityDescription: The Shamrock Compressor Station is a compressor in German Township, Pennsylvania.

The facility is located in East Carroll Parish, Louisiana, and compresses natural gas received via pipeline for further pipeline transportation. The Sherwood Gas Plant in Doddridge County, West Virginia processes fracked gas extracted from the Marcellus shale formation into dry natural gas, ethane, and a mixture of heavier natural gas liquids. The facility has the capacity to process over 3 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day at its thirteen cryogenic plants and can fractionate at least 40 million barrels of ethane per day at its three de-ethanizer units.

FacilityDescription: The Shintech Plaquemine Plant is a petrochemical manufacturing complex located in Iberville Parish, Louisiana, on the Mississippi River south of Baton Rouge. The plant produces ethylene, polyvinyl chloride, vinyl chloride monomer, hydrochloric acid, and ethylene dichloride.

FacilityDescription: The Shirley Compressor Station is located in Tyler County, West Virginia. CNX Midstream Operating LLC owns and operates the facility, which receives natural gas via pipelines and compresses it for further pipeline transportation.
The Sholem Booster Station is a compressor in Tussy, Oklahoma. It provides compression to Cheniere's Midcontinent Pipeline Project.

The Sierrita Compressor Station is owned and operated by Sierrita Gas Pipeline LLC and is located in Pima County, Arizona. The facility was built as part of the Sierrita Pima Expansion and serves to add pressure to incoming natural gas for further pipeline transportation.

The Sinclair Refinery is an oil refinery located in Carbon County, Wyoming. It was originally constructed in 1924 and is now owned and operated by the Sinclair Oil Corporation. The Sinclair Refinery has the capacity to process up to 85,000 barrels (3.5 million gallons) of crude oil every day into products like propane, gasoline, jet fuel, liquified petroleum gas (LPG), and asphalt. The Sinton Compressor Station is located in San Patricio County, Texas, along the Corpus Christi Pipeline that supplies natural gas to the Corpus Christi LNG Export Terminal.

FacilityDescription: The Smithburg Gas Plant in Doddridge County, West Virginia, is located approximately 65 miles southwest of Morgantown, WV. The facility is a gas processing plant and compressor station, processing natural gas from wells throughout West Virginia. The Smithburg facility separates natural gas liquids from dry methane gas, which is distributed to markets via gas pipelines. The facility also separates and distributes purity ethane, then sends the remaining natural gas liquids to a fractionation facility. The operator, Sherwood Midstream LLC, is a joint venture of MarkWest Liberty Midstream and Antero Midstream.
ResearchNotes:
Process description, taken from R13-3464A Fact Sheet:

"Smithburg Gas Plant is a processing plant and compressor station that processes gas from the gas wells throughout West Virginia. High pressure natural gas enters the cryogenic plants and passes through a molecular sieve to remove excess water in the gas stream. The gas then enters the cryogenic plant, which lowers the temperature of the gas in order to separate ethane and heavier hydrocarbons (Y-grade) from methane gas. After this refrigeration, the gas is ready to go to market and passes through outlet compression prior to entering the downstream pipeline to a distribution pipeline operated by a separate entity. Liquids removed from the gas stream will pass through the deethanization units to separate ethane as a purity product from the remainder of the natural gas liquid stream. Purity ethane is distributed by pipeline. Natural gas liquids are transferred via pipeline to a fractionation facility. A process/emergency flare currently exists to burn vapors released from maintenance activities and plant upsets."

Plants II-VI expected to come online by 2024, according to GlobalData (10/2021): https://www.hydrocarbonengineering.com/gas-processing/12102021/globaldata-us-to-account-for-65-of-north-americas-gas-processing-additions-by-2025/

FacilityDescription: The Smith Compressor Station is a natural gas compressor station located in Smith Township, Washington County, Pennsylvania, about half an hour southwest of Pittsburgh. Owned and operated by MarkWest Liberty Midstream & Resources LLC, a subsidiary of the Marathon Petroleum Corporation (MPLX), the Smith Compressor is one component of the extensive natural gas build-out operating in western Pennsylvania. For more information about this plant and how it ties into the fossil fuel buildout, see this document.

FacilityDescription: Solvay Specialty Polymers' Augusta Plant is located in Richmond County, Georgia and manufactures specialty polymers. According to the company, these chemicals play a critical role in the design of many everyday consumer goods, such as batteries and smart devices.
ResearchNotes:
Previously:
Dartco Manufacturing, Inc.
Amoco Performance Products, Inc.
Amoco Polymers
BP Amoco Polymers, Inc.
Solvay Advanced Polymers, LLC

Product descriptions:

Sulfone: The Sulfone monomer that the facility produces is a white crystalline powder used primarily by Solvay Specialty Polymers to produce Udel, Radel A, and Radel R at other manufacturing locations. These polymers are used to manufacture materials and parts for medical, aircraft, automotive, and electronics industries. Sulfone monomer is also used in the manufacturing of pharmaceuticals and specialty chemicals.

Amodel: Amodel is a strong, tough, high temperature polymer known as a polyphthalamide and is used in automotive, electronic, and other consumer applications. Amodel represents an entirely new class of plastics, produced for the first time commercially at the Augusta site.

Xydar: Xydar is a high temperature liquid crystal polymer. Because of its good flow properties, Xydar is frequently used to make very small, intricate parts for the computer and electronics industries.

FacilityDescription: Puget Energy built its new Tacoma Liquified Natural Gas facility in the port of Tacoma, Washington. Per Puget Energy, the facility is capable of liquifying around 225,000 gallons (about 36,100 cubic feet) of natural gas per day, while also boasting the capacity to store 1.7 million gallons (roughly 272,924 cubic feet) of liquified natural gas. Puget Energy states that the new facility serves demand for natural gas within the United States and helps provide fuel from ships travelling between Tacoma, Washington and Alaska. While the facility may provide economic benefits, many groups, including the Puyallup Tribe of Indians, Citizens for a Healthy Bay, and other legal groups, believed that the terminal would have devastating impacts on human and environmental health. As a result, the Tacoma LNG Facility was at the center of debate—the construction permit for the facility was appealed in 2019 before ultimately being approved in November of 2021 and re-appealed in December of 2021.

FacilityDescription:
The Texas LNG Terminal is a proposed liquefied natural gas export terminal located on the Brownsville Ship Channel, in Cameron County, Texas. If built, would have the capacity to export up to 4.5 million metric tons of liquefied natural gas every year.

On August 6, 2024, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit issued an opinion vacating and remanding the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's authorization for the Texas LNG Terminal. The court ruled that FERC failed to conduct a supplemental environmental review and address environmental justice and air quality issues in response to a previous court decision. On remand, the Commission will prepare a supplemental EIS and re-consider whether to grant the authorization under Section 3 of the Natural Gas Act.
ResearchNotes:

These approvals authorize impacts to wetlands, navigable waterways, and the coastal area from construction of the terminal. FacilityDescription: The Toledo Refinery has been operating in Lucas County, Ohio, since the early 1900’s. The facility—owned by BP Husky Refining, LLC—can process up to 160,000 barrels of crude oil per day. Products produced at the Toledo Refinery are used to create gasoline, diesel fuel, and jet fuel. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.

The Trenton Central RVP Station in Williams County, North Dakota was a proposed crude processing facility that would have stabilized crude oil extracted from the neighboring Williston Basin by reducing the Reid vapor pressure (RVP), in order to meet interstate transportation requirements during the cooler months of the year.

FacilityDescription: Rowdy Pipeline, LLC is building the Tuco Compressor Station, a greenfield facility, in Campbell County, Wyoming. The facility will filter, compress, and dehydrate natural gas from local producers.

The Turkey Creek Compressor Station in Evangeline Parish, Louisiana, is begin proposed as part of the Alberta Xpress and Lease Capacity Abandonment Project. The project is being developed by TC Energy and would expand capacity along the  Great Lakes Gas Transmission and ANR Pipeline systems by 165 million cubic feet per day, increasing the available capacity for LNG export facilities along the Texas and Louisiana Gulf Coast.
ResearchNotes:
LM 2/7/2022: Research notes copied from pipelines page - ANR states that construction and operation of its new Turkey Creek Compressor
Station and the acquisition of capacity on GLGT will enable it to provide Tourmaline Oil Marketing Corp. and Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) 150,000 Dth/d and 15,000 Dth/d of firm transportation service, respectively. ANR states that Tourmaline Oil Marketing Corp. would supply 140,000 Dth/d to Cheniere Energy, Inc., for export outside the United States and would sell the remaining 10,000 Dth/d of gas to domestic markets along ANR’s system. ANR also states that TVA would use its 15,000 Dth/d to generate electricity at existing generation facilities connected to the ANR system.
StreetAddress: W on Onyx Rd (towards the intersection of Johnsons Landing Rd)

FacilityDescription: The Tuscarawas Gas Processing Plant was a natural gas processing plant proposed to be located in Tuscarawas County, near Uhrichsville, Ohio. If built, it would have been able to process up to 300 million standard cubic feet per day of natural gas extracted from the Utica and Marcellus shale formations to produce "dry" natural gas and natural gas liquids, including ethane, propane, butane, and natural gasoline.
ResearchNotes: from oh epa: Construction of a greenfield natural gas processing plant in Uhrichsville, Ohio (Tuscarawas Gas Processing Plant) to process field gas collected from the Utica and Marcellus shales at off-site production operations. The Uhrichsville plant will process up to approximately 300 million standard cubic feet per day (mmscfd) of field gas to produce pipeline-grade natural gas, ethane, propane, butane, and natural gasoline.

FacilityDescription: Antero Midstream LLC owns and operates the Underwood Compressor Station, which is located in Tyler County, West Virginia. The facility receives natural gas from surrounding pipelines and compresses it for further pipeline transportation.

The Valero McKee Refinery is an existing refinery located in Moore County, Texas. It was originally built in 1933 and is now owned and operated by Valero Energy. It has the capacity to process 200,000 barrels (8.4 million gallons) of crude oil every day into products like gasoline, diesel, jet fuel, asphalt, and liquified petroleum gas (LPG). These products are transported by pipeline and rail to Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, Colorado, Oklahoma, and Mexico.
ResearchNotes: CM 2/2/24 deleted On Dec. 18, 2023, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality issued a draft operating permit renewal for Valero’s McKee Refinery. The refinery processes crude oil and other feedstocks into gasoline, diesel, and jet fuel. As of 2023, it has an operating capacity of 430,000 barrels per day. FacilityDescription: Invista S.a.r.l. owns and operates the Nylon Chemicals Americas Victoria Site in Victoria County, Texas. The facility primarily manufactures Adiponitrile (ADN) by combining hydrogen cyanide (which is produced on-site by reacting natural gas with ammonia) with butadiene. ADN has several uses, as it is the precursor to the polymer nylon, which is used in clothing, seat belts, nets, and ropes.

FacilityDescription: CNX Midstream Operating Company LLC owns and operates the Wadestown 5 Compressor Station, which is located in Monongalia County, West Virginia. The facility compresses natural gas for additional transportation via pipelines.

Atlas Pipeline Mid-Continent WestOK, a subsidiary of Targa Resources Corp., owns and operates the Waynoka Natural Gas Processing Plant in Woods County, Oklahoma. Construction of a second processing train was completed in 2012, bringing the facility's total processing capacity to 420 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day.

FacilityDescription: West Delta LNG, LLC, a subsidiary of LNG 21, LLC, is proposing to construct, own, and operate a deep water port facility in the Gulf of Mexico to serve the global liquefied natural gas market. The proposed port would be located in federal waters, approximately 10.5 nautical miles (12.1 statute miles, or 19.4 kilometers) offshore of Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana, in water depths ranging from approximately 57 to 60 feet (17.4 to 18.3 meters). The primary purpose of the proposed port would be to provide a safe and reliable facility to export domestically liquefied natural gas produced in the United States to other countries via trading carriers. The proposed port would have access to feed gas ready for liquefaction from the existing onshore Plaquemines LNG Terminal and would have a liquefaction capacity of up to 900 million standard cubic feet per day. The Maritime Administration and the U.S. Coast Guard suspended the regulatory timeline for this project in December of 2019, effectively putting it on hold to allow West Delta LNG, LLC to add relevant information to its Environmental Impact Statement.

The Westlake Ethylene Manufacturing Complex is located in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana and began operating in 1990. The complex consists of two production units, Petro I and Petro II, each capable of producing 1.6 billion pounds of ethylene per year.
ResearchNotes: Facility description sources = PSD-LA-595 (M-11) and Title V Permit No. 0520-00145-V16 (both issued 1/13/2022): https://edms.deq.louisiana.gov/app/doc/view?doc=13086817

FacilityDescription: Antero Midstream LLC owns and operates the West Mountain Compressor Station, which is located in Ritchie County, West Virginia. The facility receives natural gas from surrounding pipelines and compresses it for further pipeline transportation.

Tallgrass Midstream, LLC owns and operates the West Porcupine Compressor Station located in Campbell County, Wyoming. The facility removes liquids from incoming field gas, then compresses and dehydrates the gas for later pipeline transportation.
The Lincoln Compressor Station is a proposed compressor station located in Wetzel County, West Virginia.

FacilityDescription: The Weymouth Compressor Station is a new compressor located in Norfolk County, Massachusetts and constructed as part of the Atlantic Bridge Project.

Columbia Gulf Transmission, LLC owns and operates the White Oak Compressor Station. The compressor station, which is located in Calhoun County, West Virginia, compresses natural gas for further transportation via natural gas pipeline.

The Wild Basin Gas Processing and Crude Handling Facility is an existing gas processing plant located in McKenzie County, North Dakota - about 135 miles north west of Bismarck, North Dakota. Operations commenced at the facility in 2016 and it's currently capable of processing 320 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day and can accept 80,000 barrels per day of raw crude from the Wild Basin area of the Bakken Shale Formation.
facility_name: Wild Basin Gas Processing and Crude Handling Facility

FacilityDescription: The Willcox and Dragoon Compressor Stations are two co-located facilities that support the South Mainline Pipeline. Together they consist of three gas turbines and two natural gas fired emergency generators. The Dragoon Compressor Station was added to the Willcox location as part of the South Mainline Expansion Project in 2018.

FacilityDescription: Crestwood New Mexico Pipeline, LLC operates the Willow Lake Gas Plant located in Eddy County, New Mexico. The gas plant processes natural gas received from gathering pipelines located throughout the Delaware Basin and operates as a compressor station.
ResearchNotes:
CM 1/29/24: deleted On November 22, 2023, the New Mexico Environment Department issued a draft operating permit for the Crestwood Willow Lake Gas Processing Plant in Eddy County, New Mexico. **Public comments on the draft operating permit can be submitted until December 22, 2023. Please see the [public notice](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/a1/b1/a1b11c8076044178bd08537b1a45fefd.1701106086.pdf) for more information.**

https://air.net.env.nm.gov/rsmt/facility-report.html?ai=32575

The Willow Lake facility consists of two (2) gas processing plants to recover natural gas liquids (NGL): Willow Lake 1 consists of a turbo-expander cryogenic separation system that removes a significant fraction of the C2+ compounds from the cooled gas stream, and Willow Lake 2 consists of a refrigerated Joule-Thompson (RJT) plant that also removes C2+ compounds using a combination of mechanical refrigeration and a Joule-Thompson effect. The NGL streams from these units are routed to pressurized storage tanks prior to truck loading and transport. Willow Lake 1 has a maximum processing capacity of 20 MMSCFD of natural gas. Willow Lake 2 has a maximum processing capacity of 35 MMSCFD of natural gas.
facility_name: Crestwood Willow Lake Gas Processing Plant

FacilityDescription: The Wood River Refinery is an existing refinery located in Madison County, Illinois, 15 miles northeast of St. Louis, Missouri. It was originally built in 1917 and is now operated by Phillips 66. The Wood River Refinery manufactures transportation fuels, like gasoline, diesel, and jet fuel, as well as petrochemicals, asphalt, and petroleum coke. It has the capacity to process 367,500 barrels/day as of January 2022. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.
facility_name: Wood River Refinery and Hartford Terminal

FacilityDescription: The Woods Cross Refinery is a refinery located in Salt Lake County, Utah, approximately 10 miles north of Salt Lake City. It is currently owned and operated by the HollyFrontier Corporation and can process up to 45,000 barrels (1.9 million gallons) of refined products every day, primarily for export to the western United States. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.
Kentex Worland LLC owns and operates the Worland Compressor Station, which is located in Washakie County, Wyoming. The facility compresses field gas for future transportation via pipelines.

The Wynnewood Refinery is an existing oil refinery located in Garvin County, Oklahoma, that can process 74,500 barrels (3.13 million gallons) of crude oil per day. It was originally constructed in 1923 and is now owned and operated by Wynnewood Refining Company, a subsidiary of CVR Energy. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.

Koch Methanol's St. James Methanol Plant – which was previously named "YCI Methanol One" after the Chinese energy company backing the project – is a new methanol plant located along the West Bank of the Mississippi River, about 30 miles south of Baton Rouge.  Methanol is an alcohol (CH3OH) that is used to make plastics, paints, and other products. It can also be used as a fuel in transportation, shipping, cooking, and boilers. The existing complex began operating in 2021 and is capable of producing approximately 5,000 metric tons of methanol per day. Koch is planning to "optimize" the plant, and when completed, methanol production capacity could increase to 6,200 metric tons per day.
ResearchNotes:

Please see the [public notice](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/c0/66/c06601e9f2a14b60b123e79f3d94e281.1692979117.pdf) for more information.**

facility_name: Koch Methanol St. James Methanol Plant (previously YCI Methanol Plant)

FacilityDescription: The Baton Rouge Polyolefins Plant is an existing petrochemical manufacturing complex located in East Baton Rouge Parish, Louisiana, north of Exxon's Baton Rouge Refinery. The polyolefins plant produces high density polyethylene and polypropylene, key ingredients in the manufacturing of plastics.
ResearchNotes: CM 12/19/23 deleted: As of April 2023, ExxonMobil is considering building a chemical recycling plant at its Baton Rouge Polyolefins Plant. The plant would convert used plastic products into oil, gas, and char (a high-carbon product that can be used for fuel or soil enrichment) using pyrolysis, where the plastics would be heated to high temperatures to force them to break down. The proposal is part of Exxon’s stated goal to build 1 billion pounds of plastic recycling capacity by 2026.

FacilityDescription:
The Liberty One Methanol Plant is located in Kanawha County, West Virginia, beside the Dow Chemical Plant. Liberty One was relocated from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in 2017 and – after years of delay – reassembled in West Virginia. The Liberty One Methanol Plant would be capable of producing over 240 thousand tons of methanol from natural gas every year.

According to the project website, methanol production at Liberty One could be expanded to 350 thousand tons in the coming years. The Czech company behind the project has already announced plans to relocate a second 150 thousand ton per day methanol plant from central Europe to the Liberty One site in West Virginia.

Once construction of the Bay 3 Polyethylene Unit is completed, the Bayport Pasadena site would be capable of producing over 1 million tons of polyethylene per year. The facility is designed to receive ethylene feedstock from Bayport Polymer’s newly constructed Port Arthur Side Ethane Cracker, which is located about 80 miles east of the Pasadena site, in Jefferson County, Texas.

FacilityDescription: The Inner Harbor Desalination Plant is a proposed seawater desalination plant that would be located in Corpus Christi, Texas. The plant would remove up 83 million gallons of brackish water per day from the Inner Harbor, remove the salt, and generate 30 million gallons of freshwater per day for municipal use. The plant would discharge up to 68 million gallons of concentrated saltwater (brine) per day. Though the plant would treat water for municipal use, the additional municipal water would offset the growing demand for freshwater from new industrial users in the area.
ResearchNotes: On Flint Hills Resources property. https://www.cctexas.com/sites/default/files/CTYSEC-EBB-Inner%2520Harbor%2520Desalination%2520Plant.pdf https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-features/corpus-christi-exxon-sabic-water-supply-problem-1163453/ CM 2/2/24 deleted On Jan. 12, 2024, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) announced it had issued the City of Corpus Christi a draft wastewater discharge permit for the proposed Inner Harbor Desalination Plant in Nueces County, Texas. The permit would authorize Corpus Christi to discharge over 34 million gallons of wastewater each day to the Corpus Christi Inner Harbor. **TCEQ is accepting comments on the draft permit until at least Feb. 12, 2024. Please see the [public notice](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/3a/10/3a10e6f374d04d1bbe64d924d82b1834.1705417432.pdf) for more information.**
StreetAddress: Nueces Bay Blvd. and East Broadway St.

FacilityDescription: The La Quinta Channel Desalination Plant will be located in San Patricio County, Texas, along the La Quinta Channel. The plant would divert up to 166 million gallons of water per day from La Quinta Channel, remove the salt, and produce 40 million gallons of freshwater per day for municipal and industrial use. The plant would discharge up to 91 million gallons of concentrated saltwater (brine) back into La Quinta Channel. The plant needs to obtain wastewater and water rights permits from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.
ResearchNotes: Property owned by Occidental Chemical Corp.
facility_name: City of Corpus Christi La Quinta Channel Desalination Plant

FacilityDescription: The Freeport LNG Pretreatment Facility is located in Brazoria County, Texas, about two and a half miles north of the Freeport LNG Liquefaction Facility. The pretreatment facility removes water, carbon dioxide, natural gas liquids, and other impurities from fracked natural gas before sending it to the liquefaction plant for further processing and export. In November 2021, Freeport LNG and Talos Energy announced plans to develop a carbon capture and sequestration project next to the pretreatment facility, which could also sequester CO2 from major industrial sources located nearby.

FacilityDescription: The ASCENT Shale Cracker was originally announced in 2013 by Appalachian Shale Cracker Enterprise LLC. The company intended to build the ethylene cracker in Woods County, West Virginia. Had it been built, the facility would have primarily processed raw ethane into ethylene and propylene, which are both important in the production of plastics. Further, the facility would have also produced various types of polyethylene, a commonly produced plastic that’s typically used for packaging. However, after purchasing land for the project, in 2015 the company began to re-evaluate the prospect of building the cracker. In 2021, the facility formally withdrew their permit application.

FacilityDescription: The Starks Compressor Station is a proposed compressor station that would be located about 4.5 miles northeast of Starts, Louisiana in Calcasieu Parish. The new compressor would move fracked gas along the GPX Bidirectional Pipeline, which would ultimately supply up to 2.5 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day to the Golden Pass LNG Export Terminal.
ResearchNotes:
Due to a revised gas supply strategy, the Compressor Station is no longer planned at MP 66 and instead has been relocated north approximately 3 miles to MP 69 and is now referred to as the “MP 69 Compressor Station” or the “Starks Compressor Station”. The compressor station is now planned just north of the existing Transco Interconnect and just west of the proposed Gulf Run Interconnect. In addition to relocating the MP 66 Compressor Station to MP 69, GPPL is also planning to adjust the number and type of compressor units to a maximum of 102,000 brake horsepower (both LP boosting and HP injection compression)5 due to the reallocation of gas volumes and the resulting pipeline hydraulics and
delivery pressure requirements.-GPX Project Amend app (10/2/2020 - pg 14)

ResearchNotes:
**Louisa: this compressor mod leads to very minor increases in GHGs. Don't spend too much time on this one, since the emissions increases are so minor. Can look for a state facility ID if it's easy to find, but we don't need to spend loads of time looking for the state-issued permits. Can use the FERC EA as the reference and move on.

According to EA pg 16, "The electric motor-driven compressors at the modified Spring Green Compressor Station would not result in a direct source of emissions during normal operation. The compressor addition would, however, increase the station’s annual fugitive releases of VOCs and carbon dioxide equivalent emissions from 0.8 and 148 tons to approximately 1.6 and 276 tons, respectively."

The plant supplies hydrogen and steam to the Gulf Coast Ammonia Plant. FacilityDescription: The Oyster Creek Terminal would be part of the network of onshore facilities that would enable offshore exports of crude oil through the SPOT terminal. This terminal would include 7 aboveground storage tanks each capable of holding 685,000 barrels of oil, and a total storage capacity of 4.8 million barrels. The terminal would also have six electric oil pumps to push oil through pipelines at a rate of 85,000 barrels per hour or 2 million barrels per day.

FacilityDescription: Brightmark Plastics' Macon-Bibb facility was a proposed plastics-to-fuel plant located in Bibb County, Georgia, about an hour and a half south of Atlanta. The Macon-Bibb Plastics Renewal Facility would have been the largest plastics-to-fuel plant in the world, designed to convert 400,000 tons of plastic into 64 million gallons of ultra-low sulfur diesel fuel and naphtha blend stocks, as well as 20 million gallons of wax. In January 2022, the Macon-Bibb County Industrial Authority terminated their contract with Brightmark because the company missed a deadline to deliver their proprietary end-product to customers from their facility in Ashley, Indiana.
ResearchNotes:
The Macon facility will have the ability to divert 400,000 tons of plastic waste each year from landfills and incinerators and convert it into 64 million gallons of ultra-low sulfur diesel fuel and naphtha blend stocks, and 20 million gallons of wax.

Once complete, the new 5.3 million square-foot plant, which will utilize a state-of-the-art and proprietary plastics renewal process will sustainably recycle all plastic waste (types 1-7) that has reached the end of its useful life.

If authorized, the new 5.3 million square-foot plant would be <a href="https://www.13wmaz.com/article/news/local/ceo-of-new-macon-recycling-company-brightmark-says-plant-will-have-minimal-emissions-2/93-13236708-2dba-4b99-a56a-45ae7d60a505">largest renewable plastics plant in the world<a/>.

https://www.brightmark.com/work/the-macon-plastics-renewal-facility/

FacilityDescription: The Westlake Calvert City Vinyls Plant is an existing petrochemical facility located in Marshall County, Kentucky. This facility is comprised of a Chlor-Alkali Plant, Energy and Environmental process area, and a Monomer Plant. The Vinyls Plant primarily produces vinyl chloride monomer (VCM), which is supplied to the Westlake PVC plant. This facility is co-located with the Westlake Calvert City PVC Plant and the Westlake Calvert City Ethylene Plant.

FacilityDescription: The Westlake Calvert City PVC Plant is an existing petrochemical plant located in Marshall County, Kentucky. Using vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) received from the Westlake Calvert City Vinyls Plant, this facility produces dried PVC resin to be exported by rail and truck. This facility is co-located with the Westlake Calvert City Vinyls Plant and the Westlake Calvert City Ethylene Plant.

The Lone Star NGL Frac IV and V is a natural gas liquids (NGLs) fractionator in Chambers County, Texas, located within Energy Transfer’s Mont Belvieu Complex. This facility separates natural gas liquids into petrochemicals like ethane, propane, butane, and natural gasoline, which are then exported by pipeline and converted into high-value products, including plastics.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=665348932014335
facility_name: Lone Star NGL Frac IV and V

FacilityDescription: Lone Star NGL Frac VI is an existing natural gas liquids (NGLs) fractionator in Chambers County, Texas, located within Energy Transfer’s Mont Belvieu Complex. According to company documents, this fractionation facility receives NGLs from multiple sources, including Energy Transfer’s Lone Star Express and Justice pipelines.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=800381602017227
facility_name: Lone Star NGL Frac VI and VIII

FacilityDescription: Lone Star NGL Frac VII is an existing natural gas liquids (NGLs) fractionator in Chambers County, Texas, located within Energy Transfer’s Mont Belvieu Complex. Lone Star Frac VII can process up to 150,000 barrels of NGLs from fracked natural gas every day. These NGLs – primarily ethane, propane, butanes, and natural gasoline – are then transported and stored off-site. According to company documents, this facility receives NGLs from multiple sources, including Energy Transfer’s Lone Star Express and Justice pipelines.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=295397422018229

FacilityDescription: The South Texas Energy Complex is a proposed crude oil refinery in Duval County, TX. It was initially proposed in 2016. The refinery would have a crude fractionation capacity of 30,000 barrels per day and plans to manufacture diesel fuel, naphtha, and liquid petroleum gas products, largely for export to Mexico. According to company records, the plant will use steam methane reforming and carbon capture to create "blue hydrogen," and renewable energy and electrolysis to create "green hydrogen." The site would have a co-located geothermal energy plant and use electric vehicles.

https://www.ravenpetro.com/south-texas-project; https://www.houstonchronicle.com/local/article/Raven-Petroleum-threatens-to-pull-out-of-Duval-15231099.php

FacilityDescription: ONEOK Rockies Midstream's Bear Creek Gas Plant is an expanding 375 MMscf/d gas processing plant in Dunn County, North Dakota. The plant separates natural gas from natural gas liquids and is located next to the Killdeer Compressor Station.

FacilityDescription: The Newberry Gas Plant is part of Navitas Midstream's Midland Basin Processing Complex, which consists of several gas processing plants operating in close proximity in Midland and Glasscock Counties in Texas. The plant's two processing trains have the capacity to process up to 305 MMscf of natural gas per day. The complex receives gas from Upton, Midland, Martin, Howard, Glasscock, and Reagan counties. Processed gas from the complex is sent off-site through a number of interconnected pipelines to Waha, Katy, Agua Dulce, and North Texas, while natural gas liquids are sent through pipelines to locations on the Texas Gulf Coast including Sweeny, Mont Belvieu, and Corpus Christi, and Conway, KS.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: The Taylor Gas Plant is part of Enterprise Navitas Midstream's Midland Basin Processing Complex, which consists of five gas processing plants operating in close proximity in Midland and Glasscock Counties in Texas. The plant consists of two units with a combined capacity to process up to 475 MMscfd of natural gas. The complex receives gas from Upton, Midland, Martin, Howard, Glasscock, and Reagan counties. Processed gas from the complex is sent off-site through a number of interconnected pipelines to Waha, Katy, Agua Dulce, and North Texas, while natural gas liquids are sent through pipelines to locations on the Texas Gulf Coast including Sweeny, Mont Belvieu, and Corpus Christi, and Conway, KS.
facility_name: Midland Basin Processing Complex - Taylor and Lieker Gas Plants

FacilityDescription: The Trident Gas Plant is part of Enterprise Navitas Midstream's Midland Basin Processing Complex, which consists of several gas processing plants operating in close proximity in Midland and Glasscock Counties in Texas. The plant has the capacity to process up to 240 MMcfd of natural gas. The Enterprise announced plans to add a new 300 MMcfd plant to the site by the middle of 2023 ("Plant 6"), bringing total processing capacity to 520 MMcfd. The complex receives gas from Upton, Midland, Martin, Howard, Glasscock, and Reagan counties. Processed gas from the complex is sent off-site through a number of interconnected pipelines to Waha, Katy, Agua Dulce, and North Texas, while natural gas liquids are sent through pipelines to locations on the Texas Gulf Coast including Sweeny, Mont Belvieu, and Corpus Christi, and Conway, Kansas.
facility_name: Midland Basin Processing Complex - Trident Gas Plant

FacilityDescription: The KeyState Natural Gas Synthesis Plant is a proposed facility in West Keating Township, Clinton County, Pennsylvania, that would use fracked gas extracted from the Marcellus Shale formation to produce hydrogen, ammonia, and urea. Hydrogen would be sold for use as fuel and ammonia and urea would be sold for industrial uses. According to the company, the site would also have the capacity to store more than 500,000 tons of carbon dioxide per year.

FacilityDescription: The Harbor Island Booster Station is part of the Bluewater SPM Deepwater Port (DWP) onshore infrastructure. Located on Harbor Island off the coast of Texas, it will house the pumping infrastructure that will help transport crude oil through the proposed pipeline to the DWP. Additionally, the Harbor Island Booster Station will be the primary administration and operations building to support operations at the DWP.

FacilityDescription: Midway Terminal is a proposed pipeline breakout station and petroleum storage terminal in San Patricio County, Texas. The Midway Terminal would connect to approximately 55 miles of pipeline infrastructure and a proposed booster station on Harbor Island, which would ultimately supply 1,920,000 barrels of crude oil every day to the Bluewater Deepwater Port located approximately 25 miles offshore in the Gulf of Mexico.

FacilityDescription: The Indian Bayou Compressor is a proposed compressor station that would be located on a 40-acre tract of land in Beauregard Parish, Louisiana, approximately six miles south of Ragley. It is being constructed as part of the Driftwood Line 200 and Line 300 pipeline project, which would deliver up to 5.7 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day to LNG terminals, petrochemical facilities, and other industrial consumers around Lake Charles, Louisiana.

FacilityDescription:
The Lake Charles Methanol & Sulfuric Acid Bulk Terminal is a proposed petrochemical storage and terminal facility that would be located in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana, next to an existing tank farm. The terminal would receive liquid methanol and sulfuric acid by pipeline from the proposed Lake Charles Methanol Facility, which would be stored on-site and later exported to supply regional refiners and distributors.

Originally proposed in 2013, construction of the Methanol & Sulfuric Acid Bulk Terminal has been delayed by the Port's main supplier—Lake Charles Methanol.

FacilityDescription: Announced in June 2021, the Great Plains Hydrogen Hub would have produced "blue hydrogen" from natural gas while sequestering carbon dioxide underground. It would have been built at an existing synfuels plant (the Great Plains Synfuels Plant), which Bakken Energy planned to purchase from the Basin Electric Power's subsidiary, the Dakota Gasification Company. It would have had the design capacity to produce up to 310,000 metric tons of hydrogen per year. Plans for the project fell through in January 2023, when the companies ceased negotiations over the sale of the synfuels plant.

The project has already received $50 million in state funding from the North Dakota Department of Commerce and the North Dakota Industrial Commission.

FacilityDescription: The Davis Refinery is a proposed oil refinery located on a 620-acre site in Billings County, just west of the town of Belfield, and only three miles from Theodore Roosevelt National Park. If constructed, the Davis Refinery would be capable of processing approximately 49,500 barrels of crude oil per day extracted from the Bakken shale formation into gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, and liquefied petroleum gas (or "LPG"). The Davis Refinery was originally expected to begin operating in early 2018, but the project has been delayed by five years due to litigation and financing delays.

FacilityDescription: The Tornado Gas Plant is a natural gas processing plant located in Loving County, Texas, designed to process raw natural gas extracted from the Permian Basin into pipeline grade natural gas for delivery to Gulf Coast markets. The raw natural gas will be received via a to-be-built pipeline, and the pipeline grade natural gas will be delivered via existing pipelines. The first gas plant, Tornado I, is operational and has a gas processing capacity of 200 million standard cubic feet per day. The second gas plant, Tornado II, is expected to be operational sometime in 2022 and will have a gas processing capacity of 200 million standard cubic feet per day - doubling the facility's processing capacity.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=992343182018239

FacilityDescription: The Black River Gas Processing Complex in Eddy County, New Mexico is located near the Delaware shale basin, one of three formations that make up the prolific Permian Basin. This facility has been expanding incrementally since it was first constructed in 2015, adding 200 million cubic feet per day of gas processing capacity in 2018 and again in 2020. The Black River Gas Processing Complex is owned by DLK Black River Midstream, a subsidiary of San Mateo Midstream, and will supply fracked gas to the newly-constructed Double E Pipeline.

FacilityDescription: The Artesia Renewable Diesel Unit is a renewable diesel unit (RDU) located at the Artesia Refinery in Eddy County, New Mexico. Once constructed, the new RDU will be able to convert 9,000 barrels per day of soybean oil and other renewable feedstocks supplied by the co-located Artesia Pretreatment Unit (PTU) into diesel fuel through a process called catalytic hydrotreating.
ResearchNotes:
Artesia Renewable Diesel Company LLC (“ARDC”), a wholly owned subsidiary of HollyFrontier Renewables Holding Company LLC, which itself is a subsidiary of the HollyFrontier Corporation (“HFC”).

https://air.net.env.nm.gov/rsmt/facility-report.html?ai=39991

FacilityDescription: The Artesia Pretreatment Unit (PTU) is a proposed pretreatment unit at the Artesia Refinery in Gallup County, New Mexico. If constructed, it would process soybean oil and other renewable feedstocks (like corn oil and tallow) to supply the co-located Artesia Renewable Diesel Unit at the Navajo Artesia Refinery. The PTU may also be used to supply another renewable diesel unit that HollyFrontier is constructing at the Cheyenne Refinery in Wyoming.

The Cheyenne Renewable Diesel Plant is a renewable diesel refinery located in Laramie County, Wyoming. The facility is located at the former site of the HollyFrontier Cheyenne Oil Refinery, which was permanently shut down on June 29, 2021, and was converted to produce renewable diesel fuel.
ResearchNotes:
HollyFrontier Cheyenne Refinery (HFCR) (F000356) will be shutting down its petroleum refinery. CRDC will be using the former location to produce renewable diesel. CRDC will be using several existing process units to produce its renewable diesel. The process units that will not be reused by CRDC will be permanently shut down, and all existing permits for the HFCR will be rescinded.

CRDC will be operating the Renewable Diesel Project at the former location of the HFCR (F000356) in Cheyenne, Wyoming. The Cheyenne Renewable Diesel Company facility will use two (2) existing process units to produce renewable diesel fuel from fats, vegetable oils, and/or waste cooking oils (primarily soybean oil).

The Petersburg Compressor Station is a compressor station located in Prince George County, Virginia. This facility is part of the Virginia Electrification Project and Virginia Reliability Project (VRP).

According to the company, the plant would produce 2,950 barrels of gasoline per day from 34 million cubic feet of fracked natural gas per day supplied by Diamondback Energy production sites in the Permian Basin.

FacilityDescription: Markwest Liberty Midstream & Resources, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of MPLX LP, operates the Houston Gas Plant located in Washington County, Pennsylvania. This gas plant processes natural gas received from pipelines and fractionates natural gas liquids into products such as propane, butane, and gasoline. The currently expanding Houston Gas Plant has the capacity to process 555 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day. For more information about this plant and how it ties into the fossil fuel buildout, see this document.

FacilityDescription: The Lone Star Alkylate Production Facility would be located near Mont Belvieu, in Chambers County, Texas. The new facility, which is being developed by Energy Transfer, would convert ethylene into alkylate, which would be sold to nearby refineries and converted into gasoline and other high-octane motor vehicle fuels.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=431497062020279

FacilityDescription: The Port of Corpus Christi's proposed Harbor Island Desalination Plant would take up to 146 million gallons of water per day from the Corpus Christi Channel, a significant national estuary, and turn it into fresh water for industrial use. The plant, as proposed, would have the capacity to make 50 million gallons of fresh water per day. It would also generate 95.6 million gallons per day of concentrated saltwater (brine), which would be discharged back into Corpus Christi Channel. The Port will need to obtain a wastewater discharge permit and water diversion rights from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) to operate the plant. For additional information, visit the Point Aransas Conservancy site.
ResearchNotes:
Port of Corpus Christi Harbor Island desal plant.

Website: https://portofcc.com/capabilities/real-estate/harbor-island/

FacilityDescription: The Port of Corpus Christi's proposed La Quinta Channel Seawater Desalination Plant would be located in Portland, Texas.  It would convert 90.4 million gallons of brackish water from La Quinta Channel into 30 million gallons of freshwater each day. The treatment process would create up to 57.3 million gallons per day of concentrated saltwater (brine) which would be discharged back into the channel.
ResearchNotes: The plant will need both wastewater and water diversion rights permits from TCEQ.
facility_name: Port of Corpus Christi La Quinta Channel Seawater Desalination Plant

FacilityDescription: The Poseidon Regional Seawater Desalination Project at Ingleside would be able to treat up to 50 million gallons of seawater per day after initial construction, and expand up to 100 million gallons per day at a later date. According to the Texas Water Development Board's 2021 Coastal Region Water Plan, the water would be treated for new manufacturing and industrial uses in San Patricio County.

FacilityDescription:
Nacero's proposed $6 billion Marcellus gas-to-liquids plant would manufacture “blue” and “green” gasoline on a former coal mine in Newport Township, near Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. Equipped with carbon capture technology, the facility would convert fracked natural gas and renewable natural gas to syngas, methanol, and hydrogen. Syngas and methanol would be converted to gasoline, while hydrogen would be stored and sold separately.


In April 2024, local news reported that Nacero's flagship facility in Texas was delayed by six to ten years. Although it has not been confirmed by the company, it is likely that the Marcellus Facility is canceled.
ResearchNotes: AS 10/17/24 - updated facility description; unclear if PA project will move forward

FacilityDescription: The Mountaineer Natural Gas Liquids (NGLs) Storage Hub would be located on a 200-acre site along the Ohio River near Clarington, Ohio, and would consist of multiple underground storage caverns designed to store liquid petroleum products, natural gas liquids, saltwater, and potentially hydrogen gas. If constructed, the Mountaineer Hub would also include terminal facilities and a network of supporting infrastructure needed to process, store, and transport NGLs and other chemicals to downstream petrochemical plants.

FacilityDescription: The Spindletop Renewable Gasoline Refinery is an announced renewable gasoline plant that would be located on a 53-acre site in Nederland, Texas. The new refinery would process woody biomass sourced from the East Texas woodshed into gasoline, carbon dioxide, and hydrogen gas. The company behind the project has plans to expand operations following initial construction of the plant. Arbor Gas plans to transport hydrogen produced at Spindletop to a nearby site in Pasadena, Texas, where it would supply crude oil refineries and petrochemical plants.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=813599032021042

FacilityDescription: The Edna Station is a new crude oil and condensate storage terminal located in Jackson County, Texas, with 1.5 million barrels of storage capacity. Owned by Max Midstream, the Edna Station receives 570,000 barrels of crude oil and condensates from the Seahawk Pipeline, which connects the Edna Terminal to the Seahawk Crude Condensate Terminal in Point Comfort. According to a company news article from April 2021, Max Midstream plans to increase its storage capacity at Edna to 9 million barrels by 2023.

FacilityDescription: The CP2 LNG Terminal is a proposed liquefied natural gas terminal that would be located on Monkey Island, directly east of Venture Global's Calcasieu Pass LNG Terminal in Cameron Parish, Louisiana. The CP2 LNG Terminal would be constructed in two phases, nine liquefaction units at a time. The first phase is expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2026, with construction on the second phase expected to wrap up by the end of 2027. The terminal would connect to the proposed 91-mile-long CP Express Pipeline and, if approved, would have the capacity to export up to 28 million tons of liquefied natural gas every year. The proposed terminal could also include a carbon capture and sequestration facility that would be capable of sequestering an estimated 500,000 tons of CO2 per year in nearby saline aquifers.
ResearchNotes:
CM 12/19/23 deleted: On Sept. 19, 2023, the Louisiana Department of Natural Resources announced that a public hearing regarding the Coastal Use Permits for the proposed CP2 LNG Terminal in Cameron Parish and associated CP Express Pipeline will be held at **3 p.m. on Nov. 1, 2023,  at the Cameron Parish Police Jury West Annex at 148 Smith Cir., Cameron, LA 70631.** The facility and 91-mile pipeline would impact 1,368.5 acres of wetlands. The public notice is available [here](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/2a/26/2a2680646af0480bb336a8c2f4f261f8.1695748146.pdf) for more information.

The Terminal Facilities, which will consist of the mainland-based Terminal Site, the Marine Facilities on Monkey Island, and the LNG transfer lines and associated utilities, will be constructed on about 699.3 acres near the mouth of the Calcasieu Ship Channel in Cameron Parish, Louisiana. The proposed Terminal Site is bordered by Davis Road and marine-based industrial facilities fringing Calcasieu Pass to the northwest, Cameron Wastewater Treatment Facilities and Venture Global Calcasieu Pass, LLC’s LNG Terminal to the west; state land along the Gulf of Mexico shoreline to the south; and private open land historically used for cattle grazing to the south and east.

https://venturegloballng.com/cp2-lng/

FacilityDescription: The Moss Lake Compressor Station would be located along the proposed CP Express Pipeline, which would supply 4 billion cubic feet of natural gas to the CP2 LNG Terminal every year. The Moss Lake Compressor is proposed to be constructed near Moss Lake in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana.
ResearchNotes: The compressor station (Moss Lake Compressor Station) will be constructed near Moss Lake in Calcasieu Parish, and will include two 35,238 HP natural gas-fired compressor units to be installed in Phase 1 and three 35,238 HP natural gas-fired compressor units and one 10,500 HP booster electric-driven compressor unit to be installed in Phase 2.

FacilityDescription: 1PointFive P1, LLC, a joint venture between Occidental Petroleum and Rusheen Capital Management, plans to develop and build a Direct Air Capture (DAC) facility in the Permian Basin, in Ector County, Texas. The plant is expected to capture up to 500,000 metric tons of industrial grade carbon dioxide per year, with with the capability to scale up to 1 million metric tons per year, by heating, treating, and compressing atmospheric air using natural gas, water, and carbon-free renewable energy as inputs. Oxy has applied for permits to inject the carbon dioxide underground for long-term storage, but the captured carbon may also be utilized to make low-carbon products.

FacilityDescription: The Phillips 66 Rodeo Refinery sits on over 1,000 acres located on California's San Pablo Bay, northeast of San Francisco. The refinery could process up to 128,000 barrels of crude oil per day before it was converted into a renewable fuels plant in April 2024. Following completion of the Rodeo Renewed project in the second quarter of 2024, the refinery will be able to produce over 50,000 barrels per day of renewable fuels, including renewable diesel and up to 20,000 barrels per day of renewable jet fuel. FacilityDescription: The Olive Creek plant makes carbon black, a powdery substance used in tires, inks, plastics, and other products. The plant uses a methane pyrolysis process which uses natural gas (methane) as a feedstock and creates "turquoise hydrogen" as a byproduct. This process extracts carbon in a solid form.

The plant, which is being developed in two phases by parent company USA BioEnergy LLC, would be able to process around 2 million tons per year of woody biomass sourced from the Southeastern United States into 66 million gallons of renewable diesel and naphtha.

FacilityDescription:
The Alliance Refinery is located along the Mississippi River in Belle Chasse, Louisiana, about 25 miles south of New Orleans. It was built in 1971 and, until 2021, produced a wide range of petroleum products from crude oil, such as liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), motor gasoline, jet fuel, propane, and diesel. The refinery also produced petrochemicals such as benzene, toluene, xylene, and propylene.

The Alliance Refinery was capable of processing 269,140 barrels per day of refined products when it shut down in 2021 after being severely damaged by Hurricane Ida. In November 2021, Phillips 66 announced that it plans to convert the refinery into a terminal facility. The company sold the facility to Harvest Louisiana Terminals LLC in February 2023.
ResearchNotes: AS 2/15/23 - refinery anticipated to close 2/28/23 and sold to Harvest Louisiana Terminals LLC - permit transfer and ownership change completed 2/28/2023. app submitted 1/9/23 for minor TV permit mod associated w/ the Wastewater Treatment Unit, Permit No. 1870-V5 (steam strippers that strip volatile organic compounds (VOC) from the wastewater prior to biological treatment non-operational; permit would allow the refinery to (continue to) bypass the strippers); very minor emissions increases for vocs, **app/project NOT added to OGW** docs are on sharepoint and current as of 2/15/23

FacilityDescription: The announced 77 Station Terminal would have a storage capacity of 750,00 barrels and would be connected to either the Edna or Seahawk terminals by a new pipeline.

The Martinez Refinery is located in Contra Costa County, about an hour northeast of San Francisco, California. It was originally constructed in 1931 and reported crude oil refining capacity of 161,000 barrels per day when it shut down in April 2020. Owned by Tesoro Refining & Marketing Company LLC, a subsidiary of Marathon Petroleum Corporation, the Martinez Refinery is now being converted into a renewable diesel refinery that would be designed to process fats and vegetable oils into renewable renewable diesel, naphtha, propane, and jet fuel. FacilityDescription: The Diamond Green Diesel Renewable Fuels Plant is located next to Valero’s Port Arthur Refinery in Jefferson County, Texas. The facility produces renewable diesel fuel and other renewable fuels from waste grease, animal fats, used cooking oils, and other oils. It is capable of producing 470 million gallons of renewable diesel per year. About half of the production capacity is used to make sustainable aviation fuel.

FacilityDescription: The announced G2 Net-Zero Energy Complex and G2 LNG Terminal were proposed to be built in two phases. The first phase of the project is expected to be completed by 2025 and would include the G2 Energy Complex, designed to produce "blue" ammonia using fracked natural gas, as well as electricity and industrial gases—like argon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and oxygen. The G2 LNG Terminal was expected to be built during the second phase of construction and would have included a new liquefied natural gas export terminal capable of producing 13 million tons of LNG per year (around 1.7 billion cubic feet per day). However, the LNG export project was canceled in April 2023. For more information on carbon capture at this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.
