FacilityDescription: The Gibbstown Logistics Center sits on over 1,600 acres located next to the Delaware River in Gloucester County, New Jersey, on the grounds of Dupont's former explosives manufacturing site known as the Repauno Plant. The facility stores natural gas liquids (NGLs), like butane and propane, in underground caverns and transfers NGLs from trucks and railcars to cargo ships for export. The Gibbstown Center is owned by Delaware River Partners LLC, a subsidiary of New Fortress Energy, who has plans to expand the facility in order to accommodate exports of liquefied natural gas from the proposed Bradford County LNG terminal in Wyalusing, Pennsylvania. For more information on the Dock 2 Expansion Project and actions being taken by local community groups in opposition, please visit the Delaware Riverkeeper Network.

As of January 2022, it has a processing capacity of 40,000 barrels/day.

FacilityDescription: HIF Matagorda eFuels Plant, also referred to as "Project Helix", is a proposed industrial-scale plant that would produce synthetic versions of methanol, liquefied petroleum gas, gasoline, and jet fuel. HIF asserts that these fuels will be carbon neutral because they will be produced by using renewable energy to make green hydrogen, which would then be combined with atmospheric carbon dioxide. The plant would be built in Matagorda County, and would be located in both the Tidehaven and Palacios Independent School Districts. If built, the plant would be capable of producing up to 200 million gallons of eFuel per year.

FacilityDescription: In January 2022, the Canadian company AmmPower Corp. announced plans to develop a "green" hydrogen and ammonia production facility. The company asserts that these fuels will be carbon neutral because they will be produced by using renewable energy to make green hydrogen from water, which would then be combined with atmospheric nitrogen to produce green ammonia. The new plant would be located at the Port of South Louisiana, which covers 54 miles of the Mississippi Riverfront in St. Charles, St. John the Baptist, and St. James Parishes, and the green ammonia produced at the site could be used to fuel cargo ships at the Port.

FacilityDescription: Louisiana Green Fuels' announced Renewable Fuels Plant would be located at the Port of Columbia in Caldwell Parish, Louisiana. The plant would use forestry biomass, mostly from managed pine plantations in the region, to manufacture approximately 2,300 barrels per day of renewable diesel and renewable naphtha for shipment by rail to California. The fuels produced at the plant would qualify for carbon credits under California's Low Carbon Fuel Standard and the US EPA's Renewable Fuel Standards. The project also includes a new biomass-fueled electric power plant that would be constructed next to the refinery. The carbon dioxide produced in the refining process and at the power plant will be captured, injected and permanently stored deep underground in three Class VI wells. For more information on carbon capture at this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: The NEXT Renewable Fuels Refinery is a renewable biofuels refinery to be constructed in the Port Westward Industrial Park in Columbia County, Oregon, about 60 miles north west of Portland. The facility will have an initial production capacity of 37,500 barrels per day, and a full capacity of 50,000 barrels per day, producing renewable diesel, naphtha, and jet fuel.

The proposed OCI Methanol-to-Gasoline Facility would be located in Jefferson County, Texas, next to OCI's Beaumont Methanol Plant. The new facility would convert woodchips into biogas, which would be used to produce approximately 1 million tons of methanol per year. The methanol would then be converted into 100,000 tons per year of "bio-gasoline" for export to European markets.

FacilityDescription: The Air Products Darrow Blue Energy Facility is an proposed "blue" hydrogen manufacturing facility located in Ascension Parish, Louisiana, between Baton Rouge and New Orleans. "Blue" hydrogen is produced using fossil fuels, with carbon dioxide from the production process captured and sequestered in deep underground wells across Livingston, St. James, St. John the Baptist and Tangipahoa parishes. Air Products plans to inject a portion of the hydrogen into its 700-mile long hydrogen pipeline that runs from Galveston Bay, TX to New Orleans, and use the remainder to make “blue” ammonia for global markets. If constructed, the $4.5 billion Air Products facility would be the largest of its kind in the world. For more information on carbon capture at this facility, please see Empower's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.

FacilityDescription: The proposed Woodside Beaumont Clean Ammonia Complex would be located in Jefferson County, Texas, next to OCI's Beaumont Methanol Plant. The new facility would consist of three plants: a 6,000 metric ton per day blue ammonia plant, a 2,200 metric tons per day urea plant, and a 1,530 metric ton per day nitric acid plant. The end products will either be a urea solution to be converted to diesel exhaust fluid, or a urea ammonium nitrate fertilizer solution. The hydrogen used to produce ammonia at the Woodside Complex would be supplied by the neighboring Linde plant, which would also include a carbon capture and sequestration facility. This facility was originally being developed by OCI Global, but in September 2024 it was sold to Woodside Energy for $2.35 billion.

FacilityDescription: The proposed Crossroads Plant is located in DeSoto Parish, Louisiana, about 45 miles south of Shreveport, Louisiana. The facility consists of two plants which  treat and compress up to 430 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day. The facility produces sweet dry natural gas for export to natural gas markets via pipeline.

New Fortress Energy's Micro-fuel Handling Facility is a liquefied natural gas (LNG) import facility located at the Port of San Juan in Puerto Rico. The facility, which began operation in March 2020, supplies LNG to the neighboring San Juan Combined Cycle Power Plant via direct natural gas vapor connection and to industrial users via truck. The facility has a truck loading capacity of 87.2 million cubic feet of natural gas per day. The project was originally constructed without seeking approval from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), as New Fortress asserted that the project did not fall under FERC jurisdiction. However in March 2021, FERC issued an Order on Show Cause, stating that the facility falls under FERC jurisdiction and that New Fortress Energy must submit an application for authorization under Section 3 of the Natural Gas Act. FERC authorized the continued operation of the facility during the pending approval, and New Fortress submitted it's application for authorization in September 2021.

Grön Fuels' Low Carbon Intensity Renewable Fuels Plant is a proposed renewable fuels plant located in West Baton Rouge Parish, Louisiana. The plant would have capacity to produce 60,000 barrels per day of renewable diesel, with an option to produce renewable jet fuel. The plant could also include a carbon capture and sequestration facility that would be capable of sequestering an estimated 1 million metric tons of CO2 per year in deep saline aquifers located below the project site. If built, it would be the largest renewable fuels complex in the world. For more information on carbon capture at this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.
ResearchNotes: AS 1/18/24 - project delayed; removed from facility description: "The first phase of this $9.2 billion project is expected to be completed by 2024."
facility_name: Gron Fuels Low Carbon Intensity Renewable Fuels Plant

FacilityDescription: The El Dorado Ammonia Production Plant is an existing ammonia plant located in El Dorado, Arkansas. The plant manufactures ammonia, ammonium nitrate, sulfuric acid, nitric acid, and other chemicals used as fertilizer, in mining, and for other industrial purposes. As of 2021, the plant has the capacity to produce up to 493,000 tons of ammonia. LSB plans to retrofit the plant to use carbon capture and sequestration to reduce the plant's carbon emissions by 25 percent and convert about 75 percent of its current 'gray' ammonia to 'blue' ammonia. The plant has access to an existing ammonia pipeline, the Nustar ammonia pipeline, which originates in Southern Louisiana and runs through Arkansas, Missouri, Iowa, Nebraska, Illinois, and Indiana.

FacilityDescription: The New Hope Energy Plastics Recycling Plant, also known as the Trinity Oaks Tyler Facility, is a chemical recycling plant located in Tyler, Texas. It converts non-recyclable plastics into synthetic oil products using a process called pyrolysis, where plastics are melted, vaporized, and turned into liquid. The demonstration plant was completed in 2019 but caught fire multiple times and was plagued by allegations of worker safety violations and hazardous spills into a stream running into nearby Blackfork Creek. According to the company's CEO, the plant shut down in the summer of 2024 to make way for a large commercial-scale facility at the same location, or somewhere else along the Gulf Coast. Once the expansion project is completed in 2025, New Hope Energy will be capable of processing 500 tons per day of plastic waste into polymer feedstock. TotalEnergies has committed to purchasing 100,000 tons per year of New Hope's recycled polymer feedstock to manufacture food-grade polymers.

FacilityDescription: The Nutrien Geismar Ammonia Plant was a proposed a $2 billion ammonia plant that would have been constructed in Ascension Parish, Louisiana - where Nutrien already has an existing ammonia plant with access to the Denbury carbon dioxide pipeline and enhanced oil recovery system. The new plant would have produced 1.3 million tons of "blue" ammonia per year, and the company claimed that at least 90% of carbon emitted, or up to about 1.9 million tons of CO2 per year, was going to be captured and used for enhanced oil recovery. The plant would have been the largest "blue" ammonia plant in the world, but in June 2024 Nutrien announced that they are no longer pursuing the project.

FacilityDescription: This $2 billion ammonia plant proposed by CF Industries and Mitsui would be located in Ascension Parish, Louisiana, at the Blue Point Complex. The new plant could produce over 1.5 million tons of "blue" ammonia every year, which would be sold as marine fuel, used to generate electricity, or used as fertilizer. CF Industries anticipates that up to 1.6 million tons of carbon dioxide could be captured at the plant annually. The carbon captured at the plant will be sequestered by ExxonMobil at its Pecan Island CCS Hub.

FacilityDescription: The Corpus Christi West Refinery is an existing petroleum refinery located in Neuces County, Texas - about five miles west of downtown Corpus Christi, Texas. The Corpus Christi West Refinery is owned and operated by the Valero Energy Corporation and has been operational since 1984. Along with the adjacent Corpus Christi East Refinery, acquired by Valero in 2001, these refineries are referred to as the Bill Greehey Refinery. The Corpus Christi West Refinery has a capacity of 225,000 barrels per day, producing reformulated gas, low-sulfur diesel, and other fuels and products. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.

FacilityDescription: BASF operates a chemical manufacturing facility on the east bank of the Mississippi River in Ascension Parish, Louisiana - about 21 miles south of Baton Rouge. BASF's Geismar facility began operating in 1958 and covers about 2,600 acres. Currently, the Geismar Complex is composed of 14 plants which produce ethylene oxide/glycols, aniline, acetylene, butanediol, and other chemicals and petrochemicals. Numerous expansion projects have taken place at BASF Geismar in recent years. In January 2018, BASF announced plans to double production of MDI (methylene diphenyl diisocyanate) from 300,000 to 600,000 metric tons per year. According to the company, construction on Phase 3 of the project began in January 2023—contradicting permit documents. In August 2022, BASF also announced plans to increase production of specialty chemicals.
ResearchNotes:

Methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (MDI) is a chemical used to manufacture products like home insulation. The project would increase greenhouse gas emissions by 18,969 tons per year, or roughly the equivalent of adding 147,000 gas-powered vehicles to the roads and must begin construction by September 2024.

FacilityDescription: HIF Somervell eFuels Plant, also referred to as "Project Motion", is a proposed industrial-scale plant that would produce synthetic versions of methanol, liquefied petroleum gas, gasoline, and jet fuel. HIF asserts that these fuels will be carbon neutral because they will be produced by using renewable energy to make green hydrogen, which would then be combined with atmospheric carbon dioxide. The plant would be built in Somervell County, and would be located in the Glen Rose Independent School District. If built, the plant would be capable of producing up to 200 million gallons of eFuel per year. HIF, a Chilean company, is also considering building the plant in New Mexico, Oklahoma, Australia, or Chile.
ResearchNotes: Approximated location using maps in Chapter 313 application. (GB 6/7/2022)

FacilityDescription: Eureka Resources' Dimock Wastewater Treatment Plant was a fracking wastewater treatment plant planned for Susquehanna County, Pennsylvania - about 25 miles northwest of Scranton. The plant would have treated fracking wastewater to distill and crystalize minerals and produce treated water, both of which would have been sold for industrial and agricultural use. The plant was designed to produce 94,000 barrels of treated water per day, 30 to 40 tons of sodium chloride per day, and 23,000 gallons of concentrated calcium chloride brine per day. In July 2024, the company canceled the project for economic reasons. Eureka Resources also has plans to close other oil and gas wastewater treatment plants throughout the state.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: The Enterprise Beaumont Marine West Complex is located in Jefferson County, Texas - about 5 miles south east of downtown Beaumont, Texas. Within the complex is the Beaumont Marine West Terminal, a for-hire hydrocarbon and chemical product storage and transfer site. The terminal has access to more than 12 million barrels of refined products storage and receives products from eight refineries, representing approximately 3.3 million barrels per day of capacity. Enterprise recently proposed constructing an ethylene plant at the Beaumont Marine West Complex. It is one of three sites under consideration for the new cracker.

FacilityDescription: Penn America Energy has proposed to construct a LNG liquefaction plant and export terminal in Delaware County, Pennsylvania - about 13 miles south west of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Penn America is proposing to build the facility on a 100-acre brownfield site along the Delaware River in Chester, Pennsylvania. A site has not yet been selected, but the closed Ford factory is a likely candidate. Once operational, the facility would export up to 7 million metric tonnes of LNG each year. The facility would tap in to the Texas Eastern pipeline via Enbridge's proposed Philadelphia Lateral and a newly proposed 3 mile connector pipeline from Chester Junction to the facility. The developers estimate that the facility will increase demand for Marcellus and Utica natural gas by 1 billion cubic feet per day.
ResearchNotes:
WHYY article says old Chester Ford assembly is likely site for LNG Terminal: https://whyy.org/articles/delco-major-lng-export-terminal-environmental-justice-chester/ (GB 6/16/2022)

Capacity and upstream demand increase are from pg 34 and 44 of the economic impact analysis/slide deck. (GB 6/16/2022)
facility_name: Penn LNG Liquefaction and Export Terminal

FacilityDescription:
The announced Port Allen Renewable Gasoline Refinery would convert woody biomass from southern yellow pine plantations in Louisiana and Mississippi into gasoline, which would be blended with conventional fuels to meet renewable fuel standards in the United States and Europe. The new refinery would include a carbon capture system, capable of sequestering approximately 500,000 tons of CO2 annually.

The new plant would be located at the Port Allen Rail Terminal in West Baton Rouge Parish, Louisiana, and would be operated by Magnolia Renewable Fuels—a subsidiary of Arbor Renewable Gas LLC, which has plans to construct a similar project in Texas.
ResearchNotes: lat/long correspond to street address provided on Fastlane (20220032-ITE, submitted 01/31/2022)

FacilityDescription: The Barstow Compressor is located in Ward County, Texas, about 65 miles west of Odessa. The facility can process 200 million cubic feet of natural gas per day.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=429345912018143

FacilityDescription: The Trainer Refinery is an existing petroleum refinery in Delaware County, Pennsylvania - about 10 miles southwest of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania along the Delaware River. The 185,000 barrel per day facility produces jet fuel, gasoline, diesel, and home heating oil. The Trainer Refinery was shut down in 2011, but it was re-started in 2012 after it was sold to Monroe Energy LLC - a subsidiary of Delta Air Lines. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.

It sits on the western portion of Chevron Phillips' Cedar Bayou Chemical Plant, which supplies it with fuel from its ethylene unit. The Cedar Bayou Hydrogen Plant is capable of producing over 60 million standard cubic feet of hydrogen every day, some of which is sent back to Chevron to be used as fuel.

FacilityDescription: The Eastman Chemical Texas City site is an existing petrochemical and plastics manufacturing complex in Galveston County, Texas - about 38 miles south east of downtown Houston, Texas. Eastman Chemical purchased the site from Sterling Chemicals in 2011 and currently manufactures acetic acid, plasticizers, and other chemicals at the site. Eastman Chemical has leased portions of the Texas City site to Gulf Coast Ammonia and Air Products Inc. to construct and operate a new ammonia plant.

FacilityDescription: The Westdale Compressor Station is an existing natural gas gathering compressor station located in Red River Parish, Louisiana along the 172-mile long Line CP pipeline system.

The proposed Kenai LNG Import Terminal would convert the existing infrastructure of the Kenai LNG Plant into an LNG import terminal. The facility is located in Kenai Peninsula Borough, Alaska - 50 miles south west of Anchorage, Alaska. The Kenai LNG Plant began operating in 1969 and exported LNG, primarily to Asian countries, until 2015. Once converted into an import terminal, the facility would import up to four tanker loads of LNG per year. Imported gas would be delivered to the Kenai Refinery at a rate of 3,500 to 7,000 million British thermal units per day.

The Corona Compressor Station is an existing compressor located in Wetzel County, West Virginia. This facility was constructed in 2015, and is part of the proposed Ohio Valley Connector Expansion Project.

Located in Monroe County, Ohio, the Plasma Compressor Station has two gas-fired compressor engines with approximately 22,500 nominal horsepower total. Proposed modifications as part of the Ohio Valley Connector Expansion would support gas transport from West Virginia to the Rockies Express, Rover, and Texas Easter interconnects in Clarington, Ohio.

FacilityDescription: Vantage Energy II Access, LLC constructed the Cygrymus Compressor Station  in 2014 for natural gas gathering services in Greene County, Pennsylvania. Natural gas is gathered from wells to the compressor station before being delivered to the Eastern Gas Transmission and Storage's Sand Rock meter station. As part of the Ohio Valley Connector Expansion, Equitrans LP intends to acquire the compressor station and modify the facility for transmission services.

FacilityDescription:
The Webb County Green Hydrogen Plant is a proposed green hydrogen plant that would be located in Webb County, Texas - 28 miles east of Laredo, Texas. The facility would be able to produce 240 tons of green hydrogen per day, which would be used to generate electricity or produce fuels.

On June 1, 2022, Siete Green Fuels applied for a tax abatement (a Texas Chapter 313 value limitation agreement) from Webb Independent School District to construct its ‘green hydrogen’ plant.  Construction is expected to begin in Q4 2025, and the plant would be operational by Q4 2026.
The Pasadena Alkoxylation Plant is a proposed specialty chemicals plant that would be constructed in Harris County, Texas, about 18 miles south east of downtown Houston.

This new facility would be located near Eastman Chemicals' Texas City complex, where Air Products operates a steam methane reformer and has plans to construct a hydrogen plant.

The site produces plastics and specialty chemicals, like glycols and oxide derivatives used to manufacture antifreeze, polyester fabrics, detergents, and beauty products.

It would be built in four phases and designed to produce over 3 million metric tons of ammonia per year, which could be used in products such as fertilizers, plastics, or as a fuel for transportation and power generation.

FacilityDescription: The Mentone Gas Processing Plant is a relatively new cryogenic natural gas processing plant located in the Delaware basin of West Texas, near Mentone in Loving County. The plants at the site separate natural gas from natural gas liquids. Both the natural gas and natural gas liquids are sent off-site through pipelines. This facility has been expanding incrementally since it was first built in 2018 and, as of 2024, consists of three plants capable of processing 800 million cubic feet of natural gas every day (MMcf/d). This facility and the Mentone West Gas Plant nearby make up a larger gas processing complex.

FacilityDescription: The Fourchon LNG Terminal is a proposed liquefied natural gas (LNG) export terminal located on Belle Pass in Lafourche Parish, Louisiana, that would have a peak capacity of five million metric tonnes of LNG per year. Fourchon LNG would also dredge a ship berth and turning basin at the terminal. It was initially expected to begin operating in late 2023. However, according to government records, the project has been delayed by the coronavirus pandemic and by Hurricane Ida, which made landfall at the site in late August 2021.

FacilityDescription: The Linde Nederland Facility is a proposed hydrogen manufacturing facility that would be located in Jefferson County, Texas, about 50 miles east of Houston. The facility would supply the proposed OCI Beaumont Clean Ammonia Complex with industrial gases and would consist of air separation units, a carbon capture and sequestration facility, and an auto thermal reactor. Linde plans to sequester over 2 million metric tons of carbon dioxide per year. However, the air construction permit for the plant allows it to run without carbon capture for up to 180 days after initial startup, and once running, for up to 120 days per year.

FacilityDescription: The SOBE Thermal Energy Chemical Recycling Plant is a proposed plastics-to-fuels facility in Mahoning County, Ohio. The plant and would process an estimated 88 tons per day of waste tire chips. It would use a device called the Thermolyzer to convert the tire chips into synthetic fuel that could be used to generate steam heat in the SOBE Thermal Plant nearby. It would produce carbon black and steel as byproducts. On Aug. 11, 2023, more than 100 people gathered at an Ohio Environmental Protection Agency meeting at a community center in Youngstown, most to oppose the project, which would add to air pollution in the area already generated by a nearby steel plant and other industrial sites. In October 2023, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency sent a letter to the Ohio EPA raising "potential environmental justice concerns" about the facility. The U.S. EPA recommended that the Ohio EPA conduct a more thorough environmental justice analysis of the surrounding area, require SOBE to post test results and air monitoring records to a publicly accessible website, and revisit the facility's permit if initial tests show emissions differ from those described in SOBE's permit application. On Dec. 20, 2023, the Youngstown City Council passed a one-year moratorium on any new pyrolysis or gasification facilities in the city.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription:
Energy Transfer is planning to build a new steam cracker that would manufacture ethylene and propylene from ethane. Ethylene crackers are the first step of a process that turns components of natural gas into plastics. If built, the new cracker would be located next to the Nederland storage and export terminal in Jefferson County, Texas.

Energy Transfer’s planned facility has been awarded $134.6 million in tax breaks over 10 years by the local Nederland Independent School District. In exchange, the company said the project will create 25 jobs and that it will spend more than $1.8 billion building the plant. According to details in Energy Transfer’s air permit application, the facility could emit more than 8,500 tons per year of harmful air pollutants, including smog-forming nitrogen oxides and volatile organic compounds; fine particulates, which can cause heart and asthma attacks; sulfur dioxide, which can cause lung issues and acid rain; and toxic carbon monoxide. The ethane “cracker” would also emit more than 5.1 million tons per year of greenhouse gases – mostly carbon dioxide – roughly equivalent to the emissions from 1.24 coal-fired power plants per year or more than 1 million gasoline-powered cars and trucks driven for a year.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: The Sweetwater Carbon Storage Hub is a proposed modular direct air capture facility designed to remove 12,000 tons of CO2 annually. Initially proposed for southeastern Wyoming, the developer announced that project is now seeking a new location due to high competition for renewable energy in the state. According to plans for the Wyoming facility, the facility aimed to capture 5 million tons of CO2 by 2030, requiring around 2 gigawatts of energy annually, and would have stored capture CO2 in nearby Class VI wells. Initially, the facility would have used natural gas to reach operating temperatures of 185°F for the carbon capture modules, with plans to transition to wind and solar power over time.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.theverge.com/2022/9/23/23353054/carbon-removal-project-bison-wyoming-direct-air-capture
https://web.archive.org/web/20220926172609/https://www.carboncapture.com/project-bison

FacilityDescription: The Pasadena Refinery is a crude oil refinery operated by a subsidiary of Chevron. It is located in Pasadena, Texas in a 466 acre complex that includes the refinery, pipeline connections, and water access to receive and ship crude oil and refined products. The plant was built in 1919 and was one of the very first petroleum refineries on the Houston Ship Channel. Chevron acquired the refinery on May 1, 2019. As of January 2022, it has a processing capacity of 115,700 barrels/day. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: The proposed AmSty Chemical Recycling Plant would be located in St. James Parish, Louisiana, next to the existing Americas Styrenics polystyrene plant owned by the same company. The new plant would process between 50 to 100 tons of plastic each day into recycled styrene monomer, which would be used to manufacture more plastics. AmSty is an affiliate of Chevron Phillips Chemical Company. The new plant in St. James Parish is being developed in partnership with Norwegian plastic maker Agilyx Corporation and will be similar to the companies' pilot plant in Oregon.

The proposed AmSty Chemical Recycling Plant would process used plastic products and recycle them using technology developed by Agilyx at an Oregon pilot plant called Regenyx. Polystryene feedstock would be supplied by Agilyx's subsidiary Cyclyx. Amsty also operates the country's largest polystyrene production facility nearby - this proposed recycling facility would provide feedstock for AmSty's existing polysytrene facility eventually.

FacilityDescription: The Cook Inlet Blue Hydrogen and Ammonia Hub is a proposed hydrogen and ammonia production hub in the Cook Inlet region of Alaska that would produce ammonia from natural gas delivered via the Alaska LNG pipeline project. It would capture and sequester the carbon associated with production in underground geologic formations nearby. The exact location of this facility has not been announced.

FacilityDescription: The Formosa Baton Rouge Plastics Plant is located in east Baton Rouge, Louisiana. It produces vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) and polyvinyl chloride (PVC) using feedstock and steam produced on-site.

The Nexus Fuels Plant is a chemical recycling plant located in Fulton County, Georgia, just outside of Atlanta. The plant processes plastic waste using a process called pyrolysis, where plastics are melted, vaporized, and turned into liquid that can be used to make more plastics, waxes, or lubricants.

FacilityDescription: The Stanberry Gas Plant is an existing natural gas processing plant in Coal County, Oklahoma - about 95 miles south east of Oklahoma City. The plant began operating in 2018 but operations ceased soon after in April 2021. VM Arkoma Stack has requested a permit to restart the 230 million standard cubic feet per day plant.

The Pelican Plant is a natural gas treatment and compression facility in DeSoto Parish, Louisiana. It removes hydrogen sulfide, carbon dioxide, and liquids from an incoming gas stream then sends gas into the Louisiana Energy Access Pipeline.

FacilityDescription: The Gulf Coast Hydrogen Plant is a proposed hydrogen and ammonia production facility on the US Gulf Coast (exact location not yet determined). Air Liquide, Uniper, LyondellBasell, and Chevron Corp have agreed to study the potential project to determine viability. They hope to use both natural gas and electrolysis to produce hydrogen and plan to capture and sequester associated carbon dioxide emissions. The hydrogen produced would be used to produce ammonia on-site and sold off-site for petrochemical, power, and mobility industry uses.

FacilityDescription: The Velma Gas Plant is an existing gas processing plant in Stephens County, Oklahoma - about 70 miles south of Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. The facility was originally built in 1948 and consists of two separate cryogenic plants; the facility has a total processing capacity of 170 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day.
The Holly 3 Compressor Station is a compressor near Frierson, Louisiana. It provides compression for Clearfork's Holly Pipeline System.
ResearchNotes: owned by tgg pipeline ltd, which was owned by azure midstream until azure was purchased by clearfork midstream in early 2022.

FacilityDescription: The Holly Common Point 6 Facility is a compressor near Coushatta, Louisiana. It provides compression for Clearfork's Holly Pipeline System.

The Fulcrum Centerpoint BioFuels Plant was a proposed plastic-to-fuels plant that would have been located on the shoreline of Lake Michigan, in Lake County, Indiana, just south of Chicago. The plant planned to convert municipal solid waste comprised of 30 percent plastic into "low-carbon" diesel and jet fuel. According to the company, the project would have diverted 700,000 tons of waste from landfills every year. The project was effectively cancelled in 2024 as the parent company filed for bankruptcy and failed to purchase the proposed site property. During the permitting process community members expressed concerns about the release of dioxin and other cancer-causing chemicals from the gasification process into nearby environmental justice communities.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.in.gov/apps/idem/caats/permitDetail.xhtml
https://vfc.idem.in.gov/DocumentSearch.aspx?xAIID=17817

Project is canceled - https://www.nwitimes.com/news/local/fulcrum-gary-project/article_c8af7e00-34b1-11ef-a72b-67d3dbe7a6bb.html

FacilityDescription: The Fulcrum Sierra BioFuels Plant was a synthetic crude oil production facility that used municipal waste from nearby landfills as feedstock. The oil produced was shipped to a Marathon refinery, where it was converted into transportation fuel. While operational the facility processed approximately 175,000 tons of waste, about 20% of which was plastic, and produced 11 million gallons of fuel annually. The facility shut down in May 2024 due to financial problems at Fulcrum Bioenergy. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in September of the same year.
ResearchNotes:
biorefinery located 15 miles east of the Feedstock Processing Facility, which receives MSW that has already undergone significant recycling efforts and converts it into a feedstock

20% plastic component based on EIA data that 18.5% of MSW is plastic

no pop w/in 3 miles, N/A for all EJ variables

Nearest City: Sparks, NV

The primary Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) number for the facility is 2869 - "Industrial Organic Chemicals. Not
Elsewhere Classified - establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing industrial organic chemicals, not classified elsewhere. Products of this industry include organic chemicals such as Fischer-Tropsch Liquids (FTL alkanes) and Synthetic Paraffinic Kerosene (SPK). (2018 technical review)

Plant shut down in May 2024 - https://www.wastedive.com/news/fulcrum-bioenergy-sierra-biofuels-reno-nevada-shutdown-eric-pryor/717916/

FacilityDescription: The Red Lake Gas Plant is located in the Permian Basin of West Texas, in Martin County. The plant consists of three units, called "trains," that can each process up to 200 MMscf/d of gas per day. The first train began operating in November 2022, the second began operating in 2023, the third began operating in 2024, and a fourth train is currently under construction.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: Announced by Dow and Nexus Circular in July 2022, the Dallas Chemical Recycling Plant would be able to process over 26,000 metric tons of plastic waste annually using a process called pyrolysis, where plastics are melted, vaporized, and turned into liquid. The liquid would be delivered back to Dow Chemical and used as a raw material to create new plastics.
ResearchNotes: https://corporate.dow.com/en-us/news/press-releases/dow-and-nexus-circular-announce-plans-to-build-new-advanced-recycling-facility-in-dallas-tx.html
facility_name: Nexus Circular Dallas Chemical Recycling Plant

FacilityDescription: 1PointFive, a subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, plans to develop a Direct Air Capture (DAC) facility on the King Ranch in Kleburg County, Texas. The immense 825,000-acre South Texas ranch dates to the 1850s and played a significant role in Texas history. Occidental's plans state that the proposed facility would have the capacity to capture 30 million metric tons per year of carbon dioxide and sequester the gas in pore space in underground rock layers beneath the ranch.
ResearchNotes:
CM 12/19/23 deleted: On Aug. 11, 2023, the U.S. Department of Energy announced two carbon dioxide direct air capture (DAC) projects that, combined, will receive over $1 billion in federal grants. One, [Project Cypress](https://oilandgaswatch.org/facility/6712), will be located in southwest Louisiana and will send captured CO2 to be injected underground at the Gulf Coast Sequestration Hub. The other project will be located in Kleburg County in Texas on the historic King Ranch and will inject the CO2 underground onsite. The two projects are expected to capture and sequester more than two million tons of CO2 each year.

AS 8/14/23 - name changed to South Texas DAC Hub following recent project announcements

FacilityDescription: The proposed Ascension Clean Energy Facility would be located on the west bank of the Mississippi River, near Donaldsonville, Louisiana. If built, it would be able to produce nearly 7.9 million metric tons of liquid ammonia every year and, according to the company, would use carbon capture and storage to capture up to 98 percent of the carbon dioxide generated during the production process. The project is being developed in partnership with Denbury, Inc. – the largest CO2 pipeline operator in the U.S., which was acquired by ExxonMobil in July 2023 – and the shipping companies Hafnia and Mitsui O.S.K. Lines. For more information on carbon capture at this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.
ResearchNotes:
According to press releases, the facility will produce 7.2 million MTPA of ammonia, but PSD app states 6 ammonia trains will each have 3600 MTPD capacity = 7,884,000 MTPA

FacilityDescription:
The Willow Processing Facility is part of the proposed Willow Project, the largest proposed oil and gas development project on federal lands within the United States. The processing facility would processes the product received from production wells, separating it into gas and condensate. The processing equipment at the WPF would include emergency shutdown equipment, power generators, compressors, gas treatment facilities, heat exchangers, separators, a flare system, pumps, pigging and metering facilities, warm storage buildings, and a tank farm.

In February 2023, the BLM issued a Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement for the Willow Project. In this document, the BLM identified Alternative E as its preferred alternative.

The DNA H2Hub is a proposed hydrogen production and carbon capture hub in Pennsylvania. The facility would be a join venture between Shell, Equinor, and US Steel, funded by money in the Infrastructure Bill for hydrogen hubs. The hydrogen would be used to power heavy industries like steel production. The project is supported by the state of Pennsylvania, although funding has not yet been awarded and the exact location of the facility has not yet been announced.
ResearchNotes: https://marcellusdrilling.com/2022/11/pa-decides-to-back-shell-equinor-application-for-1b-hydrogen-hub/?event=login

FacilityDescription: The Verdigris Nitrogen Plant is an existing nitric acid, ammonia, and urea-ammonium nitrate production facility located in Rogers County, Oklahoma - about 16 miles east of downtown Tulsa, Oklahoma. Construction on the plant began in 1973, it is currently capable of producing 2.2 million tons of urea ammonium nitrate solutions and 1.1 million tons of ammonia per year.

FacilityDescription: The Regenyx Chemical Recycling Facility, located in Tigard, Oregon, was a chemical recycling plant that converted used polystyrene products back into their original components. First launched in 2018, it was designed to process 10 tons per day of polystyrene, which was used to produce plastic intermediates like naphtha, fuels like gasoline, and PET plastic. The companies behind Regenyx announced in a Feb. 29 press release that the plant will be shutting down by the end of April 2024. Although they claim the plant was “successful,” public documents showed that the facility had only processed a total of 4,400 tons between 2019 and 2021.

FacilityDescription: The Alterra Akron Plastic Recycling Facility is a chemical recycling plant located in Summit County, Ohio. The plant processes plastic waste using pyrolysis, where plastics are melted, vaporized, and turned into a synthetic oil that is used as a raw ingredient to create brand new plastics, waxes, and other petrochemical products. As of 2022, the Akron Plant could manufacture approximately 20,000 metric tons of pyrolysis oil every year.

FacilityDescription: The Obsidian Hermiston Plant is a proposed green hydrogen plant in Hermiston, Oregon. It is part of Obsidian's proposed hydrogen production, storage, and distribution hub in the pacific northwest. The plant would have a 400 MW electrolyzer and could produce 175 metric tons of hydrogen per day using renewable energy. Obsidian plans to build new solar and wind facilities nearby, which, along with existing hydroelectric power, would power the plant. The hydrogen would be sold to a range of end users, including data centers, ammonia plants, and industrial parks. Obsidian is seeking $700 million in Department of Energy funding for the hub and plans to take advantage of the $3/kg tax credit for green hydrogen passed in the Inflation Reduction Act.
ResearchNotes: CM 12/2/22: location is super approximate

FacilityDescription: The Braven Environmental Chemical Recycling Plant is located in Wake County, North Carolina. It converts used plastics into a proprietary fuel called Braven PyChem using pyrolysis, which is used to produce new plastic products. Braven sells the fuel to Chevron Phillips Chemical, who use it to produce plastic at their existing plants.

American Plant Food is also hoping to use new technology to extract ammonium sulfate from wastewater at the site.

FacilityDescription: In December 2022, the South Korea-based company LowCarbon America Corporation announced plans to develop a hydrogen plant in Polk County, Florida. The new plant would produce "blue" hydrogen fuel using fracked natural gas and carbon capture technology. According to the company, the captured carbon dioxide would be used to make calcium carbonate and sodium carbonate, both of which can be used as building materials. The hydrogen produced at the facility would be transported using high-pressure hydrogen trailers and sold to fueling stations across the U.S, as well as used in the budding Florida space industry.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: AES and Air Products on Dec. 8, 2022, announced plans to construct a green hydrogen plant in Wilbarger County, Texas. This is the companies' second proposed green hydrogen plant in Texas – the first would be located in Nolan County. The plant would have the capacity to produce 200 metric tons per day of hydrogen using renewable energy, including wind and solar generating capacity built as part of the project. The hydrogen would be sold primarily for use as trucking fuel.
ResearchNotes: location TBD https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/air-products-and-aes-announce-plans-to-invest-approximately-4-billion-to-build-first-mega-scale-green-hydrogen-production-facility-in-texas-301697873.html

FacilityDescription: The Mitsubishi Advanced Clean Energy Storage Hub (ACES) is a proposed green hydrogen production and storage facility in central Utah. It would have the capacity to produce 100 metric tonnes of hydrogen per day using electrolysis powered by renewable energy. The hydrogen would then be stored in two large salt caverns, each capable of holding the equivalent of 150 gigawatt hours of energy. The hydrogen would be used in the Intermountain Power Agency's IPP Project, which involves running a power plant off of a mix of hydrogen and natural gas beginning in 2025, eventually scaling to be powered entirely by hydrogen.
ResearchNotes: https://power.mhi.com/regions/amer/news/20220609
facility_name: Mitsubishi Advanced Clean Energy Storage Hub

FacilityDescription: Southern Rock Energy Partners' Cushing Refinery is a proposed 250,000 barrel per day crude oil refinery in Payne County, Oklahoma. It would process crude oil extracted from the Eagle Ford and Permian shale formations into gasoline, ultra-low sulfur diesel, and IMO-compliant bunker fuel and produce 91.25 million barrels per year of transportation fuels. According to the company, the new refinery would produce 95% less carbon dioxide, volatile organic compounds, and greenhouse gases than "traditional Gulf Coast refineries" by operating off of blue and green hydrogen and renewable electricity, and by capturing and sequestering carbon.

Announced in January 2023, the Grannus Blue Ammonia and Hydrogen Plant in Northern California would be capable of producing 150,000 metric tons of blue ammonia and 10,000 metric tons of blue hydrogen every year, while permanently sequestering 370,000 metric tons per year of carbon at the nearby CTV III Storage Hub. The ammonia fertilizer produced at the plant would be sold to CALAMCO, a California-based cooperative that was behind the now-canceled Taft Ammonia Plant in Bakersfield, CA.

FacilityDescription: The Chemours Fayetteville Works Plant is a chemical manufacturing plant in Fayetteville, North Carolina. It is currently under a consent order to address sources of per- and poly-fluorocarbon, or PFAS, contamination that has impacted air and water quality around the plant. The contamination has impacted water quality for thousands of people in Bladen, Cumberland, Robeson, and Sampson Counties.

The Ajax Amine Plant is a an amine treatment plant in DeSoto Parish, Louisiana. Amine treatment is the use of aqueous solutions of amines to remove hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide from natural gas.

FacilityDescription: The Gillis Treating Facility is a proposed natural gas treatment and compression facility in Beauregard Parish, Louisiana, north of Lake Charles. It would remove carbon dioxide, residual hydrogen sulfide, and water from gathered gas and would have the capacity to treat 2,200 million cubic feet per day. The plant is being developed by New Generation Gas Gathering LLC, an affiliate of Momentum Midstream, the company behind the proposed NG3 Pipeline project. According to the company, the Gillis Treating facility would be equipped with a carbon capture system that could reduce CO2 emissions by 95 percent.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription:
The Port of Corpus Christi Blue and Green Ammonia facility is a proposed blue and green ammonia production facility in Nueces County, Texas. Ammonia is used in many different industries, with applications ranging from fertilizer to refrigeration. "Blue" ammonia is industry parlance for ammonia sourced from natural gas, while "green" ammonia uses energy from wind and solar in the production process.

The project is being jointly developed by three international companies: Korea’s Lotte Chemical Corporation, Japan’s Mitsubishi Corporation, and the German utility RWE. The facility would be expanded in multiple phases and designed to produce 10 million metric tons of ammonia every year, which would be exported to European and international markets. The companies plan it to be online in 2030. The facility will be located within the Port of Corpus Christi, although an exact location has not been announced.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.ammoniaenergy.org/articles/more-ammonia-energy-giants-head-for-the-gulf-coast/

facility_name: Port of Corpus Christi Blue and Green Ammonia Facility

FacilityDescription: The Vertex Mobile Refinery is a refinery on the border of Mobile and Saraland, Alabama. It produces diesel, jet fuel, vacuum, gas oil and gasoline. As of January 2022, it has an operable capacity of 90,600 barrels of crude per day.

The Gulf Coast Fractionator is a natural gas liquids fractionation facility and petroleum refinery in Mont Belvieu, Texas, east of Houston. Its fractionation capacity was expanded to 145,000 barrels per day in 2010, and the plant was idled in January 2021 to lower operating expenses.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: The Chemours Washington Works Plant is a chemical manufacturing facility in Wood County, West Virginia, near the Ohio state line. The plant produces nonstick, heat-resistant, and stain-resistant chemicals such as Teflon, perfluoroalkoxy alkanes (PFA), and polytetrafluoroethylene (PFTE). These chemicals have been linked to many health and environmental issues because of their tendency to not break down and to and build up in concentration in the bodies of organisms that consume them, a process known as bioaccumulation.
ResearchNotes: CM 2/2/24 moved update to alerts

FacilityDescription: The Angus Compressor Station is a natural gas compression facility near the city of Grand Forks and the North Dakota state line. It is located along the TransCanada Pipeline that traverses Minnesota to Wisconsin.
ResearchNotes:
TW 02/24/23
- Created facility entry

FacilityDescription: The Pascagoula Refinery is an oil refinery in Pascagoula, Mississippi, on the Gulf Coast. It manufactures motor gasoline, liquefied petroleum gas, aviation gasoline, petroleum coke, and sulfur. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.
ResearchNotes: CM 1/30/24: deleted In late February 2023, [ProPublica unearthed](https://www.propublica.org/article/chevron-pascagoula-pollution-future-cancer-risk) information that a proposed "biofuels" project at the Chevron Pascagoula Refinery may result in emissions so toxic that one in four people exposed to it are at risk of developing cancer. The fuel would be produced by incinerating plastic waste, and the project has been approved by the EPA, although it has not yet applied for Mississippi air permits.

FacilityDescription: Greeley Project Energy is a proposed plastics pyrolysis facility in Greeley, Colorado. The facility would convert used plastics from vehicles and household waste into base products by exposing the plastic to temperatures over 500 degrees Fahrenheit. The name of the company involved has not yet been released.
ResearchNotes: address TBD, company TBD

FacilityDescription: The St. Rose Blue Ammonia Facility is a proposed ammonia production facility in St. Charles Parish, 30 minutes west of New Orleans. It would produce 8,000 metric tons of ammonia each day. The companies developing the project plan to capture about 5 million metric tons of carbon dioxide emissions per year and hope to break ground on the new plant in early 2024.

Although the exact location has not been disclosed, the terminal would be located within the Plaquemines Port, Harbor & Terminal District. If approved, the Gulfstream LNG Terminal would be capable of exporting up to 4 million metric tons of liquefied natural gas every year.

FacilityDescription: The Enbridge Houston Oil Terminal (EHOT) is a proposed crude oil terminal in Freeport, Texas, south of Houston. If it proceeds, the terminal would export crude oil through ports in Freeport and Texas City and eventually through the Sea Port Oil Terminal, located approximately 35 miles off of the Texas coast.

FacilityDescription: The Gulf Coast Sequestration Hub is a proposed carbon capture and sequestration hub that would span across 80,000 acres in southwest Louisiana. Once fully completed, the hub is expected to be the largest geologic carbon capture sequestration project in the U.S. and one of the largest in the world, with the capacity to sequester over 4 million tons of CO₂ annually. For more information on this facility, please see Empower LLC's report onCarbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.

The Power LNG Export Terminal is a proposed liquefied natural gas export terminal on Galveston Island, Texas. The terminal would be part of the Newport Galveston Facility, an existing 55-acre marine and industrial park. Natural gas would be supplied by Energy Transfer's Houston Pipeline System and the terminal would have the capacity to export over 7 billion cubic feet of natural gas per year.
ResearchNotes: CM 12/19/23 deleted: On Jan. 23, 2023, Power LNG applied to export liquefied natural gas from a proposed export terminal on Galveston Island, Texas. The terminal would be located on Harborside Drive, less than a mile from neighborhoods and commercial areas. The terminal would have have the capacity to export the equivalent of more than 7 billion cubic feet of natural gas per year.

FacilityDescription: Hidrogenii, a joint venture between the Olin Corporation and Plug Power, is proposing to build a liquid hydrogen production facility in Iberville Parish, Louisiana, south of Baton Rouge. The new plant will initially be able to process 15 metric tons of liquid hydrogen every day, which would be supplied by the neighboring Olin Chlor Alkali Plant. The company has plans to expand production to 500 metric tons per day by 2025 and 1,000 metric tons per day by 2028.
ResearchNotes: AI for the neighboring chlor alkali plant = 2644 (Pioneer Americas LLC dba Olin Chlor Alkali Products - St Gabriel Facility)

CountyorParish: Chambers County, Liberty County, Jefferson County
FacilityDescription: The Bluebonnet CCS Hub is a proposed carbon capture and sequestration facility located across 55,000 acres in Chambers, Liberty, and Jefferson County. It would have the capacity to store up to 8 million metric tons per year of carbon dioxide emitted from refineries and chemical plants along the Gulf Coast, with a potential expansion capacity of 26 million metric tons per year. In October 2024, 1PointFive won $39 million in funding from the Department of Energy to continue developing two of their sequestration projects, including the Bluebonnet Hub.

FacilityDescription: The Phoenix Plastics Renewal Project is a proposed plastic recycling plant in Phoenix, Arizona. It would convert used plastics (numbers 3-7) into fuel using a proprietary chemical recycling process. The facility would have the capacity to process 10 tons of mixed plastics per day.
ResearchNotes: https://www.recyclingtoday.com/news/renew-phoenix-3-7-plastics-to-fuel/

FacilityDescription: The Prima Groveton Plastics Recycling Facility is a chemical recycling plant in the village of Groveton in Northumberland, Coos County, New Hampshire. The facility produces synthetic diesel from powdered sawdust, vegetable oil, and non-recyclable non-chlorinated plastics.

The Myplas chemical recycling plant in Rogers, Minnesota, was designed to process up to 90 million pounds of high- and low-density polyethylene films into plastic pellets. Although the plant was completed in December 2023, it was idled less than two months later after running into unexpected financial challenges. According to news reports, the facility may reopen under new ownership.
ResearchNotes: AS 10/3 - language in facility description updated to reflect that the facility is operating

FacilityDescription: The Houston Refinery is a refinery in Houston, Texas with the capacity to process 268,000 barrels per day. The refinery was built in 1918 as one of the first refineries on the gulf coast, and LyondellBasell plans to close operations at the end of 2025.
ResearchNotes:
PMF 11/21/24: Added photo.

CM 12/19/23 deleted: On October 3, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality issued a notice of preliminary decision for the renewal of the wastewater discharge permit (TX0003247) for LyondellBasell’s Houston Refinery. Comments on the proposed permit can be submitted at least until November 5, 2023.

On March 13, 2023, LyondellBasell announced plans to convert its Houston Refinery into a hydrogen plant. The company intended to close the refinery by the end of 2023, but extended the closure timeline to 2025 on [May 31, 2023](https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/energy/article/lyondellbasell-delays-closure-houston-refinery-18127638.php). The site is already connected via pipeline to LyondellBasell’s [Channelview](https://oilandgaswatch.org/facility/799) ethylene cracker facilities, making it a likely site for continued industrial use.

FacilityDescription: The MarkWest Bluestone Gas Processing Plant is a natural gas processing plant in Butler County, Pennsylvania, just north of Pittsburgh.
ResearchNotes:
CM 10/17/23 deleted latest news: On April 15, 2023, the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection issued a draft permit for the MarkWest Bluestone Gas Processing Plant that would allow MarkWest to build a new vapor combustion unit at the facility. **Public comment on the proposal is open until May 15, 2023, and can be submitted to egustafson@pa.gov.**

https://www.ahs.dep.pa.gov/eFACTSWeb/searchResults_singleFacility.aspx?FacilityID=737571

FacilityDescription: Texas Green Fuels' Galveston Bay Clean Fuels Export Complex is an ammonia, hydrogen, and methanol production facility proposed for Galveston Bay, Texas, although an exact location has not been announced. According to the company, the facility would rely solely on renewable energy sources for its electricity demand and would use water from the Brazos River Basin in order to produce hydrogen via electrolysis. The complex would include a deepwater dock capable of loading Very Large Gas Carriers so that hydrogen, ammonia, and methanol can be exported. Construction of the new facility is expected to begin in 2025, with completion expected in 2028. Although Texas Green Fuels LLC claims it will use renewable energy for all electricity requirements, the company’s website indicates that carbon capture may still be necessary to remove “any CO2 that may be generated during production."
ResearchNotes:
As 4/17/24 - updated location to center of Galveston Bay and added a statement of uncertainty to facility description following an email from an OGW user (Anna Lark, Senior Development Associate for Sonder Energy); coordinates were previously in a residential area with no dock access.

An existing network of hydrogen pipelines would transport the gas for sale to industrial users. Hydrogen could also be stored in salt caverns in the Galveston Bay area.
facility_name: Galveston Bay Clean Fuels Export Complex

FacilityDescription: The DG Fuels' proposed Sustainable Aviation Fuel Facility would be located on the Loring Air Force Base in Aroostook County, Maine, near the Canadian border. The new facility would produce aviation fuel using hydroelectric power and biomass from timber and agricultural waste and would begin operations in 2027, if it proceeds. The company is planning to build similar plants in Louisiana, Nebraska, and Minnesota.
facility_name: DG Fuels Aroostook Sustainable Aviation Fuel Facility

FacilityDescription: DG Fuels' proposed Sustainable Aviation Fuel Facility would be located on the west bank of the Mississippi River, in St. James Parish, Louisiana. The facility would produce up to 180 million gallons of sustainable aviation fuel annually, using blue hydrogen and sugar cane waste to make a lower-carbon form of kerosene. That would be enough for 30,000 trans-Atlantic flights each year, according to the companies behind the project. The company is planning to build similar plants in Minnesota, Maine, and Nebraska.
ResearchNotes: location from Scott Eustis (4/4/23 email) and communication with RISE St James
facility_name: DG Fuels St James Sustainable Aviation Fuel Facility

FacilityDescription: The proposed Freepoint Gulf Coast Chemical Recycling Facility would be located in Ascension Parish, Louisiana, next to Shell's Convent Refinery. The new plant would process plastic waste using a process called pyrolysis, where plastics are melted, vaporized, and turned into liquid that can be used to make more plastics. The facility would be designed to process 192,000 metric tons of recycled polymer feedstock every year, which would be sold exclusively to Shell. Freepoint already has plans to increase capacity to 288,000 metric tons per year, making it one of the largest chemical recycling plants in the world.

FacilityDescription: The Illinois Plastic Recycling Plant is a proposed plant in either Will or Grundy County that would use pyrolysis to process waste plastics. The plant is the subject of a bill in the Illinois Legislature (HB 1616) that would extend the  construction deadline from 2025 to 2027. Details on the project are sparse as of March 2023 - the company associated with the plant is not yet public, nor is a proposed location or capacity.
ResearchNotes: https://www.wastedive.com/news/illinois-chemical-recycling-bill-eps-foam/645173/

FacilityDescription: The TruStyrenyx Channahon Plant is a proposed chemical recycling facility in Channahon, Illinois. It would convert used polystyrene back into styrene monomer, which could be used to manufacture food-grade plastic products and packaging.
ResearchNotes:
location is approximate.
https://wasteadvantagemag.com/agilyx-and-ineos-styrolution-advance-development-of-large-scale-trustyrenyx-chemical-recycling-plant/

FacilityDescription: The Qilak LNG North Slope Terminal is a proposed liquefied natural gas terminal that would allow LNG to be exported directly from the North Slope of Alaska to Asian markets. The North Slope location would cut delivery times in half compared to LNG terminals on the US Gulf Coast, allowing Qilak to compete with Russian LNG exports according to the company.
ResearchNotes: location is approximate

FacilityDescription: The Northridge Gas Plant is a natural gas processing plant located in the Arkoma-Woodford Shale in Hughes County, Oklahoma. The facility has a processing capacity of 200 million cubic feet per day and is fed natural gas by 140 miles of gathering lines.

The Blue Sky River Parish Sequestration Hub is a proposed carbon dioxide sequestration and storage area near Geismar and Donaldsonville, Louisiana. Blue Sky has secured rights to the pore space underlying about 30,000 surface acres and it anticipates having the capacity to store at least 14 million tons of CO2 annually and 350 million tons total. For more information on this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.
facility_name: Blue Sky River Parish Sequestration Hub

FacilityDescription: The ARCH2 Washington Hydrogen Plant was a proposed hydrogen production facility in Wood County, West Virginia, near the site of the Chemours Washington Works Plant. It would have manufacture hydrogen using electrolysis, where electricity is used to split water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen. It would have been part of the proposed Appalachian Regional Clean Hydrogen Hub (ARCH2), but the project was cancelled in late 2024.

FacilityDescription: The HOBO Diesel Plant is a proposed diesel production plant in Clinton County, Iowa. It would produce 138 million gallons of diesel per year using agricultural feedstock like used cooking oil, animal fat, and soybean oil.
ResearchNotes: capacity based on 9000 bpd capacity from permit application

FacilityDescription: Citroniq's polypropylene plant will have an annual capacity of 400,000 metric tons and be located south of Falls City, Nebraska, within the Mid-America Rail Campus. The plant would make "green" polypropylene from corn and, according to the company, would sequester up to 2 million tons of carbon dioxide annually as solid polypropylene pellets. This calculation is based on natural carbon sequestration that occurs during plant growth; Citroniq states that it "permanently captures" the carbon dioxide in its polypropylene pellets, which are then used long-term or recycled. The U.S. recycles only 1% of polypropylene, according to the American Chemistry Council.

This facility would serve as a back-up natural gas supply for the Greensville County Power Station and the Brunswick County Power Station located in Southside Virginia.

FacilityDescription: The Louisiana Offshore CO2 Hub is a proposed carbon storage complex in the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Louisiana. It would be able to hold up to 300 million tons of carbon dioxide and would involve repurposing existing oil wells in the area to serve as sequestration wells. Carbon dioxide would be transported to the wells using a proposed 110-mile pipeline from Geismar, Louisiana, to Grand Isle, Louisiana. For more information on this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.

FacilityDescription: The Port Allen Catalyst Plant is a refinery hydrotreating catalyst plant in West Baton Rouge Parish, Louisiana. It produces alumina powders used to manufacture hydrotreating catalysts that remove sulfur and nitrogen contaminants from gas and diesel, allowing the fuels to meet road transportations specifications. The plant began operations in 2010.
ResearchNotes: CM 12/19/23 deleted: On May 15, 2023, Shell Catalysts and Technologies announced that it has reached a final investment decision on a proposed expansion of its Port Allen Catalyst Plant and Refinery in Louisiana. The proposed expansion, which began construction earlier this year, would increase catalyst manufacturing capacity by 15,000 tons per year.

FacilityDescription: The BP and Linde Carbon Capture Project would capture and store carbon dioxide emissions from Linde's hydrogen production facilities in the Texas Gulf Coast region. The carbon dioxide would then be used to produce more hydrogen as well as injected into storage wells nearby. The project would have the capacity to store 15 million metric tons of carbon dioxide per year.

FacilityDescription: The Longleaf CCS Hub is a proposed carbon sequestration hub in Mobile County, Alabama. Tenaska plans to inject 5 million metric tons of carbon dioxide per year in the Lower Cretaceous Paluxy Formation, the Lower Cretaceous Washita-Fredericksburg Interval and the Upper Cretaceous Lower Tuscaloosa Massive sand. The CO2 will be captured from the James M. Barry electrical generation plant, the Williams Gas Processing Facility, and a nearby steel plant.

FacilityDescription: The SkyNRG Washington Plant is a proposed sustainable aviation fuel production facility in Washington state - a precise location has not yet been announced. The facility would have the capacity to produce 30 million gallons of fuel each year using green hydrogen and natural gas produced using biomatter.
ResearchNotes: https://skynrg.com/producing-saf/skynrg-pacific-northwest/

FacilityDescription: ExxonMobil's Pecan Island Area Project is a proposed carbon capture project located in Vermillion Parish, Louisiana, near the city of Abbeville. ExxonMobil plans to sequester 3.2 million metric tons of CO2 per year through two injection wells, with the goal to expand up to 10 million metric tons per year. The project would be built as part of EnLink's 29-mile CO2 Pipeline, which would transport carbon dioxide emitted from oil, gas, and petrochemical plants along the industrial corridor near Donaldsonville, Louisiana. This sequestration hub would receive carbon captured at CF Industries's proposed blue ammonia plant in Ascension Parish. For more information on this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana. On March 1, 2024, ExxonMobil withdrew their application for a coastal use permit to drill two appraisal wells at this site. The status of this project is unknown.
ResearchNotes: PB 11/2/23: added Class VI permit and updated site description
facility_name: ExxonMobil Pecan Island Area CCS Project

FacilityDescription: The Pinnacle Polymers Garyville Plant is a polypropylene manufacturing plant in St. John the Baptist Parish, one hour west of New Orleans and next door to the Marathon Garyville Refinery. The plant produces more than one billion pounds of polypropylene each year for use in injection molding, extrusion, and fiber markets.
ResearchNotes: CM 12/19/23 deleted: As of early June 2023, Pinnacle Polymers plans to expand its polypropylene production capacity from 1.25 billion pounds per year to 1.3 billion pounds per year at its Garyville, Louisiana facility.

FacilityDescription: The Westlake Vinyls VCM-E Facility is a vinyl chloride production plant in Ascension Parish, Louisiana, south of Baton Rouge. It manufactures polyvinyl chloride (PVC) and vinyl chloride copolymers which are used in a wide range plastic products, including drainage pipes, medical devices, and flooring.
ResearchNotes: CM 12/19/23 deleted: On Aug. 10, 2023, Westlake Vinyls submitted an application to expand ethylene dichloride production at its Geismar, Louisiana facility by 605 million pounds per year. Ethylene dichloride is used to produce precursors to PVC plastic and poses significant health risks to humans.

It was designed to export around 4.2 million metric tons of LNG per year and expected to be completed in 2026. FacilityDescription: Taminco, an affiliate of Eastman Chemical Company, owns a chemical manufacturing facility in Iberville Parish, Louisiana, just south of Baton Rouge. The plant manufactures alkyl amines from ammonia, which are used to make synthetic dyes, pharmaceuticals, epoxy resins, and to remove carbon dioxide and hydrogen sulfide from natural gas and refinery process streams. It also manufactures many other organic chemicals, including diethylhydroxylamine (DEHA) - a chemical used in water treatment and synthetic rubber production, and as a photographic developer, antioxidant, and corrosion inhibitor - as well as ethoxylates, chemicals that are often added to personal care products, laundry detergents, cleaning products, and paint.
ResearchNotes:
process description from V16 app
The Taminco St. Gabriel Plant operates six process units which manufacture a variety of amine compounds.
Co-Pro and MIPA units, are designed to manufacture higher alkyl amines from ammonia and appropriate alcohols.
DEHA, Amietols, DMAPA, and Ethoxylates units.
The DEHA unit manufactures diethylhydroxylamine (DEHA) by reacting triethylamine (TEA) and hydrogen peroxide. Alkylanolamines, or amietols, are produced through a basic reaction occurring in a batch mix reactor between alkyl amines and ethylene oxide. Multiple specialty Ethoxylates products, or alkylanolamines, made with higher amines are produced in the Ethoxylates (or P47) unit. The basic reaction occurs in a plug flow reactor between alkyl amines and ethylene oxide. Production of DMAPA in the DMAPA unit is based on a hydrogenated reaction of the reactants dimethylamine and acrylonitrile.
https://edms.deq.louisiana.gov/app/doc/view?doc=11860565

FacilityDescription: The Houston Carbon Capture Hub is a proposed carbon capture and sequestration project that would capture carbon dioxide emissions from industrial facilities in the Houston area, including petrochemical plants and refineries. The Hub is being developed by 14 companies, led by ExxonMobil, and would be designed to store up to 50 million metric tons of carbon dioxide per year by 2030 and 100 million metric tons by 2040. The carbon dioxide would be stored at both onshore and offshore sites around Houston, Texas.

FacilityDescription: The Revalyu Statesboro Plant is a polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic bottle recycling plant planned for Bulloch County, Georgia. It would be the company's first advanced PET recycling facility in the U.S., with capacity to process 200 million pounds (90,000 metric tons) of post-consumer PET plastic per year. The facility would use glycolysis to recycle the bottles, which involves exposing the PET plastic to glycols in order to break the polymer down into its constituent parts.

FacilityDescription: The Wanhua MDI Plant was a proposed methylene diphenyl diisocyanate manufacturing (MDI) facility in St. James Parish, Louisiana. MDI is used to make polyurethane automotive parts, foams, and other household products like waterproof sealants. The site would have produced 400 kilotons of MDI per year, but the project was canceled in 2019 following legal challenges, community opposition, and rising materials prices.

The Sea 3 Providence Terminal is a marine liquefied propane gas (LPG) storage and transport facility in Providence County, Rhode Island on the northwest bank of the Providence River. The terminal stores LPG in a 19-million-gallon high-rise tank from which it can be loaded onto transport vessels and sold throughout the region. Sea 3 bought the property in 2018, but it has not been active since 2015.
ResearchNotes: https://ejatlas.org/conflict/sea-3-liquid-propane-gas-expansion-providence-rhode-island-usa

FacilityDescription: The Bayou Bend CCS Hub is a proposed carbon capture and sequestration project in Chambers and Jefferson Counties, Texas, that would capture carbon dioxide emissions from industrial facilities along the Houston Ship Channel and in Beaumont and Port Arthur. It would include multiple underground storage sites that span across 100,000 acres onshore, as well as 40,000 acres offshore in the Texas Gulf Coast. According to the companies developing the project - Chevron, Talos, and Carbonvert - it would have an estimated storage capacity of around 1 billion tons of carbon dioxide, making it one of the largest carbon capture projects in the United States.

FacilityDescription: The Harvest Bend CCS Hub is a proposed carbon capture and sequestration project in Louisiana that would capture carbon dioxide emissions from industrial facilities along the Mississippi River corridor from New Orleans to Baton Rouge. The project would utilize portions of EnLink's existing regional pipeline network of approximately 4,000 miles and would include multiple underground storage sites that span over 110,000 acres onshore. Talos Energy has already leased 26,000 acres in Iberville, St. James, Assumption and Lafourche Parishes to develop the project, which would have an estimated storage capacity of around 620 million metric tons of carbon dioxide. For more information on this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.

FacilityDescription: The Coastal Bend CCS Hub is a proposed carbon capture and sequestration project in southeast Texas that would capture carbon dioxide emissions from industrial facilities in Corpus Christi. It would include multiple underground storage sites that span across 13,000 acres onshore and would have an estimated storage capacity between 50 and 100 million metric tons of carbon dioxide. The project - which is being developed by Talos Energy, Howard Energy Partners, the Port of Corpus Christi Authority, and Texas A&M University - was awarded a $9 million grant from the U.S. Department of Energy in February 2023.

FacilityDescription: The Beaver Lake Renewable Energy Plant is a proposed methanol production facility in Rapides Parish, Louisiana. The plant would use wood fiber to manufacture 400,000 tons of methanol each year using renewable energy or biomass energy, which would be sold for use as ship fuel. Sun Gas Renewables also plans to incorporate carbon dioxide capture at the facility which would be sequestered underground offsite. The plant would be developed in partnership with C2X LLC and is one of multiple green methanol production facilities the companies are planning to build in North America.

It would produce hydrogen using natural gas, which would be used to power data centers, greenhouses, and other industries. The company plans to capture carbon dioxide emissions and inject them underground beneath state-owned land, potentially including wildlife management areas.

The plant would use electrolysis, where electricity is used to break water into hydrogen and oxygen, to produce the hydrogen. It would have the capacity to manufacture 12,000 kg of hydrogen per day which would be sold for use in the chemical and industrial sectors.

FacilityDescription: The Black Bear Compressor Station is a proposed natural gas compression facility in Marshall County, West Virginia, part of the state's Northern Panhandle. The facility would receive gas from nearby wells, compress and dehydrate it, and transport it offsite via pipeline.
ResearchNotes: CM 10/17/23 deleted latest news: On Aug. 16, 2023, the West Virginia Department of Environmental Protection (WVDEP) issued a draft permit for the proposed natural gas compression station. The compressor could emit as much as 119,717 tons of greenhouse gases each year, as much as 15,000 homes’ annual energy use. **The WVDEP is accepting public comments on the draft permit until Sept. 20; comments should be emailed to [Roy.F.Kees@wv.gov](Roy.F.Kees@wv.gov).**

FacilityDescription: Montezuma Carbon is planning to build a sequestration hub near Collinsville, on the northeastern side of the San Francisco Bay. This hub is planned to accept between 3 and 8 million tons of carbon dioxide annually from sources in the North Bay industrial corridor, including refineries, hydrogen plants, and power plants.

The Vervain Project sequestration hub was located in McLean County, about 40 miles southeast of Peoria. This site would have been part of Heartland Greenway's proposed carbon capture, utilization, and sequestration system which will transport carbon dioxide from biofuel and fertilizer plants in Iowa, Illinois, Minnesota, North Dakota, and Nebraska to central Illinois for geologic sequestration. This hub was planned to sequester up to 15 million metric tons of carbon dioxide per year. In October 2023, Navigator announced the cancellation of the pipeline project.

This carbon sequestration hub was located in Christian County, southeast of Springfield, IL. This site would have been part of Heartland Greenway's proposed carbon capture, utilization, and sequestration system which would have transported carbon dioxide from industrial sites in Iowa, Illinois, Minnesota, North Dakota, and Nebraska to central Illinois for geologic sequestration. This hub was planned to inject 6 million metric tons of carbon dioxide per year for 30 years using six injection wells. In October 2023, Navigator announced the cancellation of the pipeline project.

The Elk Hills 26R Storage Project is located in the Elk Hills Oil Field, about 20 miles west of Bakersfield. Carbon Terravault plans to inject up to 1.46 million metric tons of carbon dioxide annually through four injection wells for 26 years. Currently, the company has only one confirmed emission source; 200,000 metric tons of CO2 will come from gas treatment operations at the Elk Hills Oil Field. Previously, the company also expected to sequester carbon from a proposed hydrogen plant and Avnos Direct Air Capture facility, but plans have since fallen through.
ResearchNotes: PB 8/12/24: updated description to include changes in initial CO2 sources and updated coordinates from draft permit
facility_name: CTV I Elk Hills 26R Storage Project

FacilityDescription: The Elk Hills A1-A2 Storage Project is a carbon sequestration hub located in the Elk Hills Oil Field, 20 miles west of Bakersfield. Carbon TerraVault is planning to sequester up to 750,000 metric tons of carbon annually from multiple industrial sources in the southern San Joaquin Valley, including the Elk Hills NGCC Power Plant.
facility_name: CTV I Elk Hills A1-A2 Storage Project

FacilityDescription: The CTV II Storage Project is a carbon sequestration hub located in San Joaquin County, where Carbon TerraVault plans to sequester carbon from direct air capture and other CO2 sources in the area. The exact location of the project and injection rate has been claimed as "confidential business information."

The CTV IV Storage Project is a carbon sequestration hub located in Sacramento County, where Carbon TerraVault plans to sequester carbon from direct air capture and industrial sources in the Sacramento Valley area. The hub is expected to have a total permitted storage capacity of 34 million metric tons of carbon dioxide. The exact location of the project and injection rate has been claimed as "confidential business information."
