FacilityDescription: Aera Energy's CarbonFrontier CCS Project is a proposed carbon sequestration hub located in Kern County, about seven miles southwest of Lost Hills. This site would sequester carbon from Aera's operations in the nearby South Belridge oil field. Aera proposes to sequester 3.6 million metric tons of carbon dioxide per year in the North Belridge oil field for seven years.

The Avangrid Hydrogen Plant is a proposed hydrogen production facility in the Navajo Nation in San Juan and Torrance Counties. It would be powered by renewable energy sources. It was initially proposed as part of the Western Interstate Hydrogen Hub (WISHH), which was not selected for DOE funding. The Governor of New Mexico and partners have stated that they nevertheless plan to move forward with the hub.

FacilityDescription: The Wabash Gasification Plant was a coal gasification facility in Vigo County, Indiana. It was constructed in 1994 and operated until 2016, when it was shuttered due to economic conditions. Wabash Valley Resources plans to re-open the plant as a 500,000 metric ton per year blue ammonia production facility. The new plant would use petcoke - a waste product generated during the oil refining process - as a feedstock. In September 2024, the Department of Energy announced a conditional commitment for a loan guarantee of up to $1.559 billion to develop the project.

This hub would receive carbon dioxide captured from the Cameron LNG facility and potentially other industrial sources. FacilityDescription: The Central Louisiana Regional Carbon Storage (CENLA) Hub is located in central Louisiana, near Alexandria. This sequestration hub will receive carbon dioxide captured from Energy Transfer's natural gas production facilities in the Haynesville Shale, which will be transported to the hub via a proposed pipeline. This large hub will consist of two planned sequestration facilities. The Rapides One CCS site will have 6 injection wells and the Vernon site will have an additional 6 wells. For more information on this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana

FacilityDescription:
The Conway Fractionator is a natural gas liquids fractionation and treatment facility in McPherson County, Kansas. Fractionation facilities separate liquid natural gas into individual products used for fuel and as raw ingredients in chemical manufacturing.

The Conway Fractionation Hub, which includes interconnected facilities in about a 50-mile radius, consists of three fractionators: one in Hutchison, Kansas, one in Bushton, Kansas, and this one in McPherson. The hub also includes a fractionator 100 miles south in Medford, Oklahoma. It is the second-most actively traded U.S. natural gas liquid market, after the Mont Belvieu Fractionator in Texas, and receives liquid mix with methane gas removed from Oklahoma, Colorado, Texas, Wyoming, and New Mexico.
ResearchNotes: CM 12/19/23 deleted: On Sept. 15, 2023, the Kansas Division of Environment issued a [draft permit](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/76/29/7629d00c410e4371aaa6522c76243c59.1694798217.pdf) that would authorize Mid-Continent Fractionation and Storage LLC to add new equipment to its Conway Fractionator. Fractionation facilities separate liquid natural gas into individual products used for fuel and as raw ingredients in chemical manufacturing. The Conway Fractionation Hub, which includes the Conway Fractionator in McPherson, Kansas, is the second largest fractionation hub in the country. **Public comments on the proposal can be submitted until Oct. 16, 2023; please see the [public notice](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/5a/bf/5abfaa035a0c4bb4b0e36f636a24c604.1694798217.pdf) for more information.**

FacilityDescription: This $2 billion ammonia plant proposed by CF Industries and POSCO Holdings would be located in Ascension Parish, Louisiana, at the Blue Point Complex, where two other blue ammonia plants have been proposed. This plant would utilize autothermal reforming, a more energy efficient alternative to traditional steam methane reforming, to produce hydrogen for use in the ammonia manufacturing process. Carbon dioxide emissions would then be captured and sequestered. Ammonia produced at the facility would be exported for use as fuel at POSCO's South Korean facilities.
ResearchNotes:
CM 12/19/23 deleted: On Sept. 14, 2023, CF Industries and POSCO Holdings [announced](https://www.opportunitylouisiana.gov/led-news/news-releases/news/2023/09/14/cf-industries-proposes-new-$2-billion-low-carbon-ammonia-production-facility-in-ascension-parish) plans to build a $2 billion blue ammonia plant in Ascension Parish, Louisiana. This plant would be located next to CF Industries and Mitsui’s [previously announced](https://oilandgaswatch.org/facility/5117) blue ammonia complex, which could produce over 1.5 million tons of "blue" ammonia every year and is expected to begin operating by 2027.

https://www.opportunitylouisiana.gov/led-news/news-releases/news/2023/09/14/cf-industries-proposes-new-$2-billion-low-carbon-ammonia-production-facility-in-ascension-parish

This 18,000-acre site has an estimated storage capacity of 80 million metric tons of carbon dioxide. This hub will be part of Denbury's carbon capture, utilization, and storage system, which receives carbon dioxide from industrial sources across the Gulf Coast. Denbury plans to sequester between 10 to 20 million metric tons of carbon dioxide collectively each year at their Aries and Gemini hubs. For more information on this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.

FacilityDescription: The Davis-Besse Hydrogen Plant is a proposed hydrogen production plant in Ottawa County, Ohio. It would generate hydrogen for distribution across the Great Lakes region as part of the proposed Great Lakes Hydrogen Hub. The plant would be located at the existing Davis-Besse Nuclear Power Station, and hydrogen would be produced using electrolysis powered by nuclear power from the station. The plant would have the capacity to produce at least 100 metric tons of hydrogen each day, which would primarily be used to power decarbonized transportation.
ResearchNotes: https://www.ans.org/news/article-4980/great-lakes-hydrogen-hub-applies-for-doe-funding/

FacilityDescription: The Cameron Parish CO2 Hub, also known as the GeoDura Carbon Storage Hub, is a proposed carbon sequestration site that would store carbon dioxide underneath state waters offshore of Cameron Parish. The 24,000-acre site has a total storage capacity of over 250 million metric tons of CO2.

FacilityDescription: Avnos is developing a Direct Air Capture (DAC) facility in Bakersfield, CA. The pilot facility, which received funding from the U.S. Department of Energy and SoCalGas, captures 30 tons of CO2 a year, but does not currently store the CO2. The full-scale facility, which is planned to begin operating in 2024, will be able to capture up to 300 tons of carbon dioxide per year. The captured carbon dioxide was originally planned to be sequestered at the nearby Elk Hills sequestration facility, but plans have since fallen through.

FacilityDescription: Denbury's Orion Sequestration Hub was located in Baldwin County, near Mobile, AL. The site, which stretched across 75,000 acres, had the capacity to store over 300 million metric tons of CO2. Between 10 to 20 million metric tons could be injected annually at this hub. Denbury had planned to connect this site to their existing pipeline network, which is currently about 90 miles away. However, in 2024, the company withdrew their application to inject carbon dioxide at this site. The current status of this project is unknown.

FacilityDescription: In June 2023, Denbury announced a joint venture with Lapis Energy to build and operate a geologic sequestration hub located in St. Charles Parish, Louisiana, approximately 20 miles west of New Orleans. The 14,000 acre site has an estimated storage capacity of 200 million metric tons, and Denbury anticipates injecting between 5 to 10 million metric tons of carbon dioxide each year. About 45 miles of additional pipeline would need to be built to connect this hub to Denbury's existing CO2 pipeline network.
ResearchNotes: https://investors.denbury.com/investors/news/news-details/2023/Denbury-Expands-Leading-CO2-Sequestration-Portfolio-with-Two-New-Sites-in-Louisiana-2023-jpblmvsVEX/default.aspx

FacilityDescription: In June 2023, Denbury announced a new geologic sequestration hub located in St. Helena Parish, about 50 miles northeast of Baton Rouge, Louisiana. The 8,500-acre site has an estimated storage capacity of 100 million metric tons, and Denbury anticipates injecting between 5 to 10 million metric tons of carbon dioxide each year. Denbury plans to connect this pipeline to their existing CO2 pipeline network.
ResearchNotes:
https://investors.denbury.com/investors/news/news-details/2023/Denbury-Expands-Leading-CO2-Sequestration-Portfolio-with-Two-New-Sites-in-Louisiana-2023-jpblmvsVEX/default.aspx

https://www.denbury.com/operations/carbon-solutions/carbon-sequestration/

FacilityDescription: Denbury's proposed Gemini Sequestration Hub is located near Donaldsonville, Louisiana, by the Mississippi River. This 11,000-acre site has an estimated storage capacity of 220 million metric tons of carbon dioxide. This hub will be part of Denbury's carbon capture, utilization, and storage system, which receives carbon dioxide from industrial sources across the Gulf Coast. Denbury plans to sequester between 10 to 20 million metric tons of carbon dioxide collectively each year at their Aries and Gemini hubs. For more information on this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.

The Texas Sabine Pass NGLs Terminal is a proposed natural gas liquids storage and export terminal that would be located along the Sabine Pass Channel in Jefferson County, Texas, just south of Port Arthur. It would include four docks, each with the capacity to load Very Large Gas Carriers (VLGCs), Very Large Ethane Carriers (VLECs), and other vessels. The export terminal would receive ethane and other natural gas liquids from the proposed TXGC Sabine Pass Pipeline, which would transport NGL products from ONEOK's Mont Belvieu Fractionation Plant.
ResearchNotes: CM 12/19/23 deleted: TXGC LLC plans to build a natural gas liquids export terminal in Sabine Pass, Texas, as well as a pipeline connecting the Mont Belvieu Fractionator in Chambers County, Texas to the new NGLs terminal. The proposed export terminal and pipeline would impact more than 550 total acres of wetland. **The US Army Corps of Engineers is accepting public comments on the application until October 20: please see the [public notice](https://www.swg.usace.army.mil/Media/Public-Notices/Article/3530472/swg-2022-00684-txgc-properties-llc-and-txgc-pipelines-llc-sabine-pass-and-multi/) for more information.**

FacilityDescription: Denbury's Corvus Sequestration Hub is located in northeastern Wyoming, near  Gillette. This 15,000-acre plot is found along Denbury's currently operating Greencore CO2 Pipeline. The site has a total storage capacity of 40 million metric tons of CO2, and Denbury plans to sequester between 2 to 5 metric tons annually.

FacilityDescription: The Bishopville LNG Storage Facility would be located in Bishopville, Worcester County, Maryland. The Bishopville Facility would utilize approximately 10.56 acres to house five one-hundred-thousand-gallon horizontal storage tanks. The facility would be capable of storing approximately 475,000 gallons (or 39,627 dekatherms) of liquefied natural gas (LNG) and would have sendout capability of 14,000 dekatherms per day (Dth/d).

FacilityDescription: This proposed carbon sequestration hub would be located in the Permian Basin of West Texas. In October 2023, Ozona announced plans to increase carbon sequestration capacity to more than 10,000 acres in Loving County. The site will have an estimated storage capacity of 120 million metric tons of carbon dioxide. Ozona plans to drill multiple sequestration wells, each able to inject 25,000 barrels per day. The carbon dioxide will be sourced from multiple industrial sites in the Permian, including natural gas processing plants, other regional oil and gas operators, as well as industrial and power generation under development in the area.

FacilityDescription: The Enbridge Ingleside Blue Ammonia Plant is a proposed hydrogen and ammonia production facility in San Patricio County, Texas. It would be located at the Enbridge Ingleside Energy Center and involve construction of new utility-scale "low-carbon" hydrogen and ammonia production and export units. The plant would use natural gas as a feedstock, but the companies intend to use carbon capture infrastructure to sequester up to 95 percent of the new emissions to make "blue" hydrogen and ammonia. It is being jointly developed by Enbridge Inc. and Norway’s Yara International ASA and will have the capacity to produce over 2.9 million metric tons of ammonia per year if completed.

FacilityDescription: The Freepoint Eloy Chemical Recycling Plant is a proposed chemical recycling facility in Pinal County, Arizona. It would have the capacity to process 175,200 metric tons of plastics each year using a process called pyrolysis, where plastics are melted, vaporized, and turned into hydrocarbon liquids like naphtha, diesel, and gas oil. This is one of three chemical recycling plants that Freepoint has proposed to build across the U.S.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.azcommerce.com/news-events/news/2023/9/freepoint-eco-systems-to-construct-advanced-recycling-facility-in-eloy/

This is Freepoint’s third proposed chemical recycling plant, none of which have begun operating.

FacilityDescription: AdvanSix Chemicals and Resins Hopewell Plant is located southeast of Richmond, Virginia on the James River. The plant manufactures caprolactam, which is used to make nylon 6, and ammonium sulfate fertilizer. It is the nation's largest single-site manufacturer of the fertilizer. The plant is located in  the Environmental Justice community of Hopewell City, Virginia, and was built in the early 1900s by DuPont. The plant is surrounded by a paperboard manufacturing site, a biomass-burning power plant, and several other chemical manufacturing sites.
ResearchNotes: CM 2/2/24 deleted On Jan. 12, 2024, the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality issued a [draft operating permit](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/1d/4e/1d4ea7e392274449a9b94d25a6e655a5.1705082883.pdf) renewal for the AdvanSix Hopewell Plant in Prince George County, Virginia. **Public comments on the proposed permit renewal can be submitted until Feb. 12, 2024. It also issued a draft discharge permit for a neighboring municipal wastewater treatment plant, called Hopewell Water Renewal, which treats process wastewater from the AdvanSix site before discharging it to the James River and nearby tributaries. **Public comments will be accepted between October 31 and November 30, 2023.**

FacilityDescription: Milestone Carbon has acquired pore space rights to over 10,000 acres in the Midland and Upton counties of Texas, with a potential storage capacity of 30 million metric tons of CO2. The company has also submitted an application for a Class VI injection well, where they will be able to sequester carbon from other emitters.

FacilityDescription: The Moriah Energy Center is a proposed liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage facility in Person County, North Carolina, about an hour northwest of Raleigh. FacilityDescription: Enterprise's Pasadena Plant is a petrochemical facility in Harris County, Texas that manufactures, blends, stores, and transports petrochemicals. The raw materials, mainly light distillates, potassium hydroxide, liquid potassium carbonate, mineral oil and raffinate, are delivered to the plant via pipelines, trucks, barges and rail cars. Finished materials are stored on-site in storage tanks and subsequently distributed via pipeline, rail, truck, or barge.

FacilityDescription: MEGlobal's Oyster Creek facility in Brazoria County, Texas, manufactures monoethylene glycol - or MEG for short - a petrochemical used to make polyester fibers, polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastics, including bottles and packaging, antifreeze, and other products. The MEG plant uses ethylene produced at Dow's neighboring Freeport plant. MEGlobal is an affiliate of the Kuwaiti petrochemical company EQUATE.

FacilityDescription: Empire's Follansbee Plant is a part of the company's Riverfront Industrial Complex at the Port of West Virginia. The complex is being expanded to include a hydrogen plant as a part of the proposed Appalachian Regional Clean Hydrogen Hub (ARCH2). Empire is also proposing to build a syngas plant, which would produce syngas by processing plastic waste using pyrolysis. The hydrogen produced at the site would be used as a transportation and/or industrial fuel, and syngas would be used to generate electricity.

FacilityDescription: The FusionOne New Iberia Hydrogen Plant is a proposed hydrogen production facility in Iberia Parish, Louisiana. The new plant would be built at the Port of Iberia, at a site previously operated by Cameron Solutions, which built and repaired equipment used in the oil and gas industry before closing in July 2021. The FusionOne plant would process plastic waste and old tires in a high-temperature, low-oxygen environment to produce syngas, which is a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen. The hydrogen would then be purified and used as fuel.

FacilityDescription: The Freestone Power Generation Plant is a natural gas-fired power plant located in Freestone County, Texas - about 70 miles southeast of Dallas, Texas. The plant produces electricity by firing natural gas in four combustion turbine generators capable of producing 794 MW of electricity.
ResearchNotes: AS 2/15/24 - marked private because this power plant is not within the scope of OGW

FacilityDescription: The Dominion Greensville LNG Storage Facility is a proposed liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage facility in Greensville County, Virginia. The facility would have the capacity to store up to 25 million gallons of LNG which could be used as a backup fuel for the Greensville County Power Station. The new facility would also include 15 million cubic feet per day of liquefaction capacity, 500 million cubic feet per day of regasification capacity, and pretreatment equipment.

FacilityDescription: The Kuraray Pasadena EVAL Plant is an ethylene vinyl-alcohol copolymers (EVOH) production plant in Harris County, Texas. EVAL, Kuraray's trademarked name for EVOH, is a chemical used in plastic products like water bottles and food packaging to keep air out.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=485384902001134

FacilityDescription: The ARCH2 Ashtabula Hydrogen Plant is a proposed hydrogen production facility in Ashtabula County, Ohio. It will accept industrial off-gas and isolate the hydrogen for sale as fuel.
ResearchNotes: https://www.cantonrep.com/story/news/local/stark-county/2023/10/30/canton-could-play-key-part-in-appalachian-regional-clean-hydrogen-hub/71307481007/

FacilityDescription: SI Group's Bayton Operations is a chemical manufacturing and storage facility in Harris County, Texas.  SI Group purchased Baytown Operations from TPC Group in 2016. The facility's polymerization unit processes polypropylene feedstock into light polygas, nonene, dodecene, and fuel oil. Additionally, Bayport provides terminal services for surrounding facilities.

It produces renewable diesel, propane, and naphtha from waste products like soybean oil. Once construction of a second processing train is completed, it will have capacity to produce up to 435 million gallons of renewable fuels every year.

FacilityDescription: Evergreen Sequestration Hub is a proposed carbon storage site located in southwestern Louisiana, in Calcasieu and Beauregard Parishes. The 20,000-acre site has an estimated storage capacity of more than 250 million metric tons of CO2. Molpus will continue to manage the land as a sustainably managed working forest, while Trace Carbon Solutions injects carbon dioxide into underground geologic formations.
ResearchNotes: https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20230928442213/en/Trace-Carbon-Solutions-and-Molpus-Woodlands-Group-Announce-the-Evergreen-Sequestration-Hub-in-Louisiana

FacilityDescription: This proposed carbon sequestration hub is located in the southeastern corner of Wyoming in Laramie County. The hub is expected to sequester 5.1 million metric tons of carbon dioxide per year through six planned injection wells. The company has already signed an agreement to sequester from an ethanol plant in Nebraska, but carbon will also be captured from other industrial sources and transported to the hub by Trailblazer CO2 pipelines.
ResearchNotes: https://ir-tge.tallgrassenergylp.com/news-market-information/press-releases/press-release/2022/Tallgrass-to-Capture-and-Sequester-CO2-Emissions-From-ADM-Corn-Processing-Complex-in-Nebraska/default.aspx

FacilityDescription: ExxonMobil's Shute Creek Treating Facility is a gas processing plant located in southwestern Wyoming, near LaBarge. According to the company, the facility currently captures around 20% of all the human-made CO2 captured annually around the world, but this still falls short of the project's targets. While ExxonMobil sequesters carbon dioxide underground through two on-site injection wells, most of the captured carbon dioxide is sold to be used to extract oil, a process called enhanced oil recovery.
ResearchNotes: PB 12/18/2023: location data from GHGRP (https://ghgdata.epa.gov/ghgp/service/html/2022?id=1002150&et=undefined). Site has an approved MRV plan.

FacilityDescription: This proposed sequestration hub is located in Cameron Parish, Louisiana, near Lake Sabine. ConocoPhillips is currently assessing the viability of geologic sequestration in the area.
ResearchNotes: CM 1/30/24: deleted On November 30, 2023, the Galveston District of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers issued a [notice](https://www.swg.usace.army.mil/Media/Public-Notices/Article/3602402/swg-2023-00278-conocophillips-company-wetlands-adjacent-to-the-gulf-of-mexico-c/) asking for comments on a permit that would authorize wetlands impacts from the proposed Gumbo South carbon sequestration project. The permit would authorize about five acres of wetland impacts for the construction of an appraisal well that would be used to assess the geologic sequestration potential of the area. **Public comments can be submitted until January 2, 2024. Please see the [public notice](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/32/9c/329cfd1cf1414f7ca84c2e0a333d1fc3.1703004248.pdf) for more information.**

FacilityDescription: The Gevo NZ1 Project is a proposed sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) facility in Kingsbury County, South Dakota. It would produce 60 million gallons per year of SAF and 5 million additional gallons of fuel for other uses. Gevo plans to use 70% wind power during the production process and employ carbon capture to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from the remaining production. In October 2024, the company developing the project was awarded a $1.46 billion conditional load guarantee from the U.S. Department of Energy.

FacilityDescription: The Cormorant Clean Energy Project is a proposed 880,000-ton-per-year ammonia production facility in Jefferson County, Texas. The company intends to capture more than 99 percent of the carbon dioxide produced at the facility, amounting to more than 1.4 million tons each year. The ammonia produced would be sold for use in transportation, industry, and agriculture.

FacilityDescription: The Larose Gas Processing Plant is a natural gas processing plant located in Lafourche Parish, Louisiana - about 35 miles southwest of New Orleans, Louisiana - that has been operating since 1998. With a capacity of 600 million standard cubic feet per day the plant produces stabilized condensate, Y-grade natural gas liquids, and residue gas.
ResearchNotes: CM 4/2/24 marked private, no project

FacilityDescription: The TransGas Ammonia Plant is a proposed ammonia production facility in Mingo County, West Virginia. It would consist of six 6,000-metric-ton-per-day manufacturing units, according to its air construction permit, for a total annual production capacity of 13.14 million metric tons of ammonia if all of its ammonia production units are built. The ammonia would be used primarily as fuel and produced using natural gas through autothermal reforming. TransGas plans to capture and sequester carbon dioxide generated throughout the production process.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: The Avina Southern California Hydrogen Plant is a proposed green hydrogen production facility in the Los Angeles area. It would produce hydrogen using renewable energy-powered electrolysis for use as truck fuel. Avina plans to sell the hydrogen wholesale and allow hydrogen refueling onsite.

FacilityDescription: Pineywoods CCS Hub is a proposed carbon sequestration site located in southeastern Texas, in Liberty and Hardin counties. The hub would sequester carbon dioxide from manufacturers, power producers, and other carbon emitters in the vicinity of Houston, Beaumont, and Port Arthur.
ResearchNotes: https://pineywoodsccshub.com/

FacilityDescription: The Avina Gulf Coast Methanol Plant is a proposed green methanol production facility on the US Gulf Coast. The facility would produce more than 70,000 tons per year of hydrogen using electrolysis and more than 300,000 tons per year of methanol for use as shipping fuel. Avina has not yet released more information about where the plan to build the plant.
ResearchNotes: https://avinah2.com/projects/project/

FacilityDescription: The Avina Northern Indiana Hydrogen Plant is a proposed liquefied green hydrogen production facility in northern Indiana. The facility would have the capacity to produce 15 metric tons of hydrogen per day using electrolysis powered by renewable energy. Avina plans to sell the hydrogen for use in heavy industry.
ResearchNotes: https://avinah2.com/projects/green-hydrogen-for-an-larger-existing-industrial-customer-on-the-gulf-coast-texas/

FacilityDescription: The Tri-State CCS Hub is a proposed carbon sequestration project that would consist of multiple injection sites in Ohio, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia. For the Ohio project (called the "Buckeye" project), Tenaska is considering injection sites in Harrison, Jefferson, and Carroll counties. In Pennsylvania (the "Oak Grove" project), Tenaska is considering Greene and Washington counties. In West Virginia ("Redbud"), the company is considering Hancock, Brooke and Marshall counties. In November 2023, the project received $55 million in funding from the Department of Energy.
ResearchNotes: https://tristateccs.com/

FacilityDescription: The Avina Minnesota Hydrogen Plant is a proposed green hydrogen production facility in eastern Minnesota. It would produce 15 metric tons per day of hydrogen using electrolysis, which would be used to power refinery operations at Flint Hills Resources' Pine Bend Refinery or Marathon Petroleum's St. Paul Park Refinery. Avina's plant will be co-located with one of these refineries to allow onsite deliveries.

FacilityDescription: The Plaquemines LNG Generating Station was a proposed 148-megawatt gas-fired power plant in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana. It would have generated power for use at the Plaquemines LNG export terminal and/or the proposed Delta LNG export terminal. According to it's initial air permit application, the plant would have been located within either of the LNG terminal sites and would have been used on an as-needed basis, such as during periods of maintenance, repair, or unplanned events when one or more of the LNG terminals' electrical power sources were unavailable. In November 2024, Venture Global asked to withdraw its permit application because it decided not to pursue the project.
ResearchNotes: updated facility description to reflect project cancelation

FacilityDescription: The proposed High West Sequestration Hub is located in St. Charles and Jefferson Parishes in southeast Louisiana, near New Orleans. The hub will inject carbon dioxide from local emission sources into an underground storage reservoir. The 21,000-acre site could have the potential to store between 140 and 1,000 million metric tons of carbon dioxide, subject to further evaluations.
ResearchNotes: https://bkv.com/news/bkv-nuquest-carbon-sequestration-agreement-louisiana

FacilityDescription: 3 Bear Libby Gas Plant is an existing cryogenic gas processing plant located in Lea County, New Mexico, that separates natural gas liquids from fracked natural gas.
ResearchNotes:
https://air.net.env.nm.gov/rsmt/facility-report.html?ai=38067

Process description from M2 permit:  Libby separates natural gas liquids (NGL’s) from the field gas, producing natural gas liquids and a residue gas for transmission to a pipeline owned by others. The process utilizes a cryogenic
gas separation plant and associated compressors for collecting field gas from the gathering system nearby. Gas and NGL’s are piped to the respective nearby interconnect metering stations, by others. The plant is to be located within 5 miles of the residue gas and NGL pipelines.

FacilityDescription: 3 Brothers Compressor Station is located in Washington County, PA.

50 Buttes Gas Plant is a 180 MMcf/d gas processing plant located in Campbell County, Wyoming. The plant began operating in 2014 with 70 MMcf/d capacity, according to company records, and has been subsequently expanded. It is part of Meritage Midstream's Thunder Creek system, which includes hundreds of miles of gas  and natural gas liquids pipelines, several compressor stations, natural gas liquids handling facilities, and additional gas processing plants in Wyoming's Powder River Basin.

The Borger Nitrogen Operations Plant is located in Hutchinson County, Texas. The facility is owned and operated by Nutrien—a company formed by the merging of PotashCorp and Agrium. Using natural gas as feedstock, the facility produces anhydrous ammonia and urea, which are both important products in the production of fertilizer.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=430060532002089

FacilityDescription: The Albany Compressor Station is a newly constructed compressor station located in Dougherty County, Georgia. This facility was initially constructed during Phase II of the Sabal Trail Project as part of the larger Southeast Market Pipeline Project.

Columbia Gulf Transmission Company owns and operates the Alexandria Compressor Station. The facility, which is located in Rapides Parish, Louisiana, compresses natural gas received via pipeline for additional pipeline transportation. Notably, the facility’s recent upgrades were part of the Louisiana Xpress Project.
ResearchNotes: LM 11/19/2021: lat/long taken from address outlined on pg. 14 of 2019 final permit 2360-00075-V7

FacilityDescription: Kinder Morgan's 90 mmscfd Altamont Main Gas Processing Plant processes natural gas to extract natural gas liquids, including butane, propane, and natural gasoline. The natural gas liquids are shipped off-site on trucks. Dry natural gas from the plant is either used on-site as fuel, or sent off-site for sale or to fuel other nearby Kinder Morgan facilities.

Dyno Nobel, a subsidiary of the Australian corporation Incitec Pivot Limited, operates the ammonia production facility located in Jefferson Parish, Louisiana, on the west bank of the Mississippi River near New Orleans. The facility uses natural gas as both a fuel and a feedstock to produce liquid ammonia— Dyno Nobel estimates that the facility is capable of producing 1.01 million tons of liquid ammonia per year, which is used to produce explosives.
ResearchNotes: https://www.dynonobel.com/~/media/Files/Dyno/ResourceHub/Media%20Articles/Waggaman%20Plant.pdf produces explosives

FacilityDescription: TopChem Pollock's proposed ammonia production facility would have been located in Grant Parish, Louisiana, at the site of the former Vanguard Biodiesel Production Plant. The TopChem Ammonia Plant was first authorized in 2016, but—after nearly six years of delay—the project was still struggling to secure the financial backing necessary to move forward. TopChem Pollock applied for a third extension to construct the proposed facility on May 10, 2021, citing Covid-induced financing delays. However, TopChem rescinded the applications on November 8, 2022. The company has not indicated whether it plans to re-apply.

Previously the Vanguard Biodiesel Production Plant (operated under Permit No. 1120-00003-05 issued on June 8, 2007)

FacilityDescription: The Taft Ammonia Fertilizer Plant, operated by Taft Ammonia Company LLC, is a joint venture of Grannus LLC and CALAMCO. The ammonia manufacturing plant would generate its own power from an on-site gas-fired generator and produce an estimated 250 tons of ammonia per day, from natural gas and water.

This is an Anhydrous Ammonia Fertilizer Manufacturing Facility

It will also house a laboratory, three wells, water treatment and discharge buildings, an ammonia storage tank, and a 6-mile natural gas pipeline.
Construction will take 18 to 26 months. Once complete, the plant will produce around 250 tons of anhydrous ammonia per day."

FacilityDescription: The Nebraska Nitrogen Plant is a relatively new nitrogen fertilizer plant located in Geneva, Nebraska, two hours southeast of Omaha. It produces up to 100 tons per day of anhydrous ammonia from natural gas (or 37,000 tons annually), and can store up to 20,000 tons of finished product on site. Construction of the facility began in 2016 and was completed in 2017. It began operating in 2018. The facility is operated by Nebraska Nitrogen Geneva LLC, a subsidiary Rocky Mountain Resources (RMR). RMR purchased the facility in 2021. It was formerly known as the Fortigen Ammonia Production Facility.
ResearchNotes: Previously Fortigen Ammonia Production Facility

FacilityDescription: Annova LNG proposed to build the Annova LNG Brownsville facility in Cameron County, Texas. The proposed facility would have exported liquified natural gas. However, Annova LNG was forced to cancel the project after the COVID-19 pandemic decreased demand for liquified natural gas, which significantly impacted the LNG market’s projected growth and subsequently caused Annova LNG to reevaluate its investment.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=599552092017013
StreetAddress: USFWS Access Road (left from intersection of Boca Chica Blvd and Kingston Ave)

FacilityDescription: The Armagh Compressor Station is a compressor in New Florence, Pennsylvania.
The Aurora Compressor Station is a compressor near Bill, Wyoming.
Located in Axis, Alabama, the Axis chemical plant primarily produces latex and polyetherketoneketone plastic. Arkema, a French chemicals company, owns and operates the Axis chemical plant.

The BASF/Total Port Arthur Olefins Complex is a petrochemical plant located in Jefferson County, Texas. It contains one of the largest ethane crackers in the world, capable of producing over 1 million tons of ethylene per year, along with other petrochemicals, like propylene and butadiene. The plant is co-located with Total’s Port Arthur Refinery and the Port Arthur Side Ethane Cracker. In <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20241003152123/https://www.recyclingtoday.com/news/basf-brings-chemically-recycled-products-to-us/">February 2024<a/>, BASF and TotalEnergies finished construction of a new chemical recycling unit at the Port Arthur complex.

FacilityDescription: ExxonMobil's Baton Rouge Refinery has been operating since the early 1900s in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. It produces products like gasoline, diesel, jet and aviation fuel, lubricating oils, and waxes. As of January 2022, it has the capacity to process 642,000 barrels/day

FacilityDescription: Roehm America’s proposed Bay City MMA Plant would be located in Matagorda County, Texas and would be designed to convert natural gas and ethylene into methyl methacrylate (MMA)—a petrochemical used to manufacture pesticides, industrial solvents, surface coatings, and polyesters. The new MMA plant would be located next to OQ Chemicals' Bay City manufacturing complex, which would supply it with steam, water, nitrogen, and other feedstocks.
ResearchNotes:
https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=659605362021131 Coordinates updated w/ revised facility footprint taken from 11/2021 313 application (AS 2/23/2022) The plant will be located adjacent to the manufacturing complex operated by OQ Chemicals Corporation (“OQ Site”, RN105195655), which will supply feedstock and basic site utilities (potable water, process water, compressed air, nitrogen, and steam) to the new MMA unit. The new MMA plant will include a formaldehyde production unit, which will supply aqueous formaldehyde (“formalin”) for internal consumption. Product MMA will be loaded out by truck and rail by Röhm, or shipped off-site via pipeline to an unaffiliated marine terminal. Previous facility description (AS 1/18/22) The Roehm America Bay City Site is a new petrochemical manufacturing complex proposed for Matagorda County, Texas, which would be capable of producing 250,000 tons per year of methyl methacrylate (MMA) from ethylene and natural gas. MMA is an organic chemical used to manufacture pesticides, industrial solvents, surface coatings, and polyesters.

The facility's initial Clean Air Act construction permits are currently open for public comment. Click here for more information.

FacilityDescription: The ExxonMobil Chemical Baytown Olefins Plant is an ethylene plant located along the Houston Ship Channel, roughly 25 miles east of Houston, Texas. The Olefins Plant was originally built in 1979 and is located within ExxonMobil’s Baytown Complex—one of the largest refining and petrochemical complexes in the world. A new ethylene cracker was commissioned at the Baytown Olefins Plant in 2018. The newly built cracker supplies ethylene to Exxon’s Mont Belvieu Plastics Plant in Chambers County, where it’s converted into polyethylene and other ingredients used to manufacture plastics. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility. Additional information is available on the company’s website.

FacilityDescription: Phillips 66 Pipeline LLC owns and operates the Phillips 66 Pipeline Beaumont Terminal Jefferson County, Texas. The storage terminal receives, stores, and distributes various volatile organic liquids including crude oil, crude condensate, and refined petroleum products. The Beauregard Parish Compressor Station is a proposed natural gas compressor that would be located near Ragley, Louisiana. It's one of three new compressor stations being proposed as part of the Texas and Louisiana Connector Pipeline Projects, which would supply the Port Arthur LNG Export Terminal in Jefferson County, Texas.

FacilityDescription: The Big Lake Fuels Methanol Plant was a proposed methanol manufacturing facility that would have been located in Lake Charles, Louisiana. First authorized in 2014, the plant was initially proposed as the "G2G Plant," a gas-to-liquids production facility that would convert methanol into gasoline. After years of delay, the plant's original design was modified to only include the natural gas to methanol portion of the facility. The facility was ultimately cancelled in May 2024 after the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality granted Big Lake Fuels' request to rescind the facility's construction permits. If constructed, the Big Lake Fuels Methanol Plant would have been able to produce 5,000 metric tons of methanol from fracked natural gas every day.

FacilityDescription: The Borger Refinery was initially built in 1926 and covers about 6,000 acres in Borger, Texas. The refinery processes medium sour crude oil and natural gas liquids from Western and Northern Texas and Canada. It creates gasoline, diesel, aviation fuel, petroleum coke, sulfur, solvents, and the raw ingredients from natural gas liquids that are used in petrochemical and plastics. As of August 2021, the refinery could separate (or "fractionate") up to 22,500 barrels per day of natural gas liquids into products like ethane and propane. According to company records, these products are distributed throughout West Texas, New Mexico, Colorado, and the central United States. FacilityDescription: The South Texas Gateway Terminal is a crude oil storage facility and export terminal located on the Corpus Christi Bay in Ingleside, Texas. This relatively new facility began operating in 2020 and has capacity to store over three million barrels of crude oil products every year.
ResearchNotes:
https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=414359892018107

https://southtxgateway.com/

South Texas Gateway Operating LLC operates a Gateway Terminal that transports and stores crude oil product, accommodates outbound product transport via ships, and includes the capability for pipeline receipt and delivery. All
product tanks at the Gateway Terminal supply all docks and pipelines. The Gateway Terminal receives and loads out crude product at marine docks controlled by four vapor combustion units (VCUs). Crude oil is stored in 23 internal floating roof (IFR) tanks and a surge relief IFR tank. Pipelines are used throughout the terminal to transport product to and from the terminal and throughout the terminal as well as crude blending activities. The Gateway Terminal operates one
emergency generator and one fire water pump, all powered by diesel compression ignition engines with a diesel fuel tank. Fugitive emissions are emitted from components in gas, vapor, light liquid, and heavy liquid service.

FacilityDescription: The Bucking Horse Gas Plant is owned and operated by Jackalope Gas Gathering Services, Inc. and is located in Converse County, Wyoming. The facility consists of 2 cryogenic gas processing plants. Cryogenic gas processing consists of cooling a gas stream to very low temperatures in order to extract “light” hydrocarbons, such as ethane, propane, and butane, from natural gas liquids. The facility has the capacity to process over 200 million metric standard cubic feet of natural gas per day.
ResearchNotes: Coordinates updated based on aerial imagery (AS 3/4/2022)

FacilityDescription: The Buffalo Compression Facility, located in Brooke County, West Virginia, is owned and operated by Appalachia Midstream Services LLC. The facility compresses natural gas from wells in the surrounding area.
Mid-America Midstream Gas Services, a subsidiary of Chesapeake Energy, owns and operates the Buffalo Creek Processing Plant. The gas processing plant is located in Beckham County, Oklahoma.

The MarkWest Cadiz Gas Plant is a natural gas processing plant located in Harrison County, near Cadiz, Ohio. It separates natural gas and ethane from mixed natural gas liquids gathered from gas wells in the Utica and Marcellus shale formations. The plant has expanded incrementally since 2012.
ResearchNotes:
From Sarah Kula: The MarkWest Cadiz Gas Plant is an operating natural gas processing plant in Harrison County near Cadiz, Ohio. The Cadiz Plant processes field gas that is mainly gathered from the Utica and Marcellus shale formations. MarkWest first received a permit in 2012 to construct the initial unit (Cadiz I) and has since added a 40,000 barrel/day de-ethanization unit and two 200 million standard cubic feet per day (mmscfd) natural gas processing units (Cadiz II and Cadiz III). The Cadiz I was designed to process 140 mmsfcd of field gas to produce pipeline-grade natural gas, propane, and natural gas liquids.  Cadiz II and Cadiz III increased that capacity to 525 mmscfd.

The Cadiz plant is connected to the Appalachia-to-Texas (Atex) pipeline, which originates in Washington County, PA. Through Atex, Cadiz connects to the MarkWest Houston Plant in Pennsylvania, the Blue Racer Natrium plant in West Virginia, and the Utica East Ohio Scio plant. According to MarkWest, all natural gas liquids (NGLs) “other than purity ethane . . . produced at [the] Cadiz Complex, Seneca Complex, Harmon Creek Complex, Majorsville Complex, Mobley Complex and Sherwood Complex are gathered to the Houston Complex or to the Hopedale Complex through a system of NGL pipelines to allow for fractionation into purity NGL products.”  There are also pipelines that connect Cadiz to MarkWest’s Seneca and Utopia complexes for transportation of propane, ethane, and/or heavier liquids.

Additional notes:
-	The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection has approved Shell’s Falcon Ethane Pipeline, which would extend from the MarkWest Houston Facility to the Shell Chemical Appalachia Petrochemical Complex. This pipeline would connect the Cadiz Gas Plant to the Shell petrochemical complex in Beaver County.

FacilityDescription: The Calcasieu Pass LNG Terminal is a new liquefied natural gas export terminal located in Cameron Parish, in Southwest Louisiana. It was commissioned in late 2022 and can process over 12 million metric tons of liquefied natural gas every year.

FacilityDescription: Midship Pipeline Company, LLC owns and operates the Calumet Compressor Station, which is located in Canadian County, Oklahoma. The facility is part of the Midcontinent Supply Header Interstate Pipeline Project. The Calumet Compressor Station dehydrates and compresses natural gas from nearby pipeline gathering system. The compressed gas is then sent downstream via pipeline.

The Westlake Calvert City Ethylene Plant is an existing ethylene plant located in Marshall County, Kentucky. This facility produces high-purity ethylene through thermal cracking of ethane feedstock. In addition to ethylene, coproducts produced at this facility include propylene, aromatic gasoline, fuel oil, and fuel gas. This facility is co-located with the Westlake Calvert City Vinyls Plant and the Westlake Calvert City PVC Plant.

The Cameron LNG Facility is a liquefied natural gas terminal in Cameron Parish, Louisiana, located about two miles north of the city of Hackberry on the Calcasieu Ship Channel, in southwestern Louisiana. The import terminal, which has been operating since 2009, has the capacity to process and transport around 1.8 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day that has been imported to the United States from foreign markets.

Cameron LNG LLC, a subsidiary of Sempra Energy, announced plans to construct a new liquefied natural gas export terminal adjacent to the existing facility in early 2011. The Cameron LNG export terminal, which consists of three liquefaction trains capable of processing up to 15 million metric tons of LNG per year (around 2.33 billion cubic feet per day), began operating in 2019.

In June 2021, Hackberry Carbon Sequestration LLC submitted an application to the EPA for a Class VI Underground Injection Control permit. The Hackberry Carbon Sequestration project would be designed to permanently sequester up to 2 million tons of carbon dioxide per year from the Cameron LNG facility.
The Canton North Compressor Station is an existing compressor station located in Doddridge County, West Virginia.

The Sinclair Casper Refinery was built in 1923 in Natrona County, Wyoming. It processes sweet crude oil (crude oil that contains less than 0.42 percent sulfur) from Wyoming and neighboring states into gasoline and diesel. These products are sold across Wyoming, Nebraska, South Dakota, Montana, Colorado, Idaho, Nevada, and Utah. As of January 2022, it has a processing capacity of 30,000 barrels/day. FacilityDescription: The Channelview Complex is a petrochemical manufacturing facility located on the Texas Gulf Coast, about twenty miles from downtown Houston. Originally built in 1957, the Channelview Complex spans 4,000 acres and houses two petrochemical plants. The North Plant is operated by Equistar Chemicals LP and the South Plant is operated by Lyondell Chemical Company—both subsidiaries of the Dutch multinational company LyondellBasell Industries, which is one of the largest plastics, chemicals and refining companies in the world. Equistar’s Channelview North Plant manufactures ethylene, propylene, butadiene, and benzene, which are used to produce propylene oxide, styrene monomer, and gasoline-blending products at Lyondell’s Channelview South Plant. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility. Additional information is available on the company’s website.

FacilityDescription: Celanese Clear Lake Plant is located in Pasadena, Texas, approximately 30 miles southeast of Houston. The operator, Fairway Methanol LLC, is jointly owned by Dallas-based Celanese Corporation and Mitsui & Co., Ltd., of Japan. The facility can manufacture up to 1.62 million metric tons of methanol and 1.3 million metric tons of acetic acid. Acetic acid is produced from methanol and used to make other chemicals, like vinyl acetate monomer, a common ingredient in packaging, coatings, and paints. New projects completed in January 2024 allow the Clear Lake plant to use carbon dioxide and hydrogen as a feedstock, and also capture CO2 to reuse in the manufacturing process.

The Corpus Christi LNG Terminal is a liquefied natural gas terminal capable of liquefying natural gas for export and gasifying imported LNG for pipeline distribution. It is located in Gregory, Texas, approximately 15 miles northwest of Corpus Christi, and owned by Corpus Christi Liquefaction, LLC, a subsidiary of Cheniere Energy. The facility currently consists of three liquefaction trains capable of processing a total of 15 million metric tons of LNG annually. The Stage III Expansion project would add seven liquefaction trains and increase the terminal’s total liquefaction capacity to approximately 25 million metric tons per year.

FacilityDescription: The Corpus Christi Polymer Plant is a proposed petrochemical manufacturing facility located in Nueces County, Texas. Once completed, this integrated PTA-PET plant would be able to produce 1.1 million metric tons of PET (polyethylene terephthalate) and 1.3 million metric tons of PTA (purified terephthalic acid) every year, making it the largest facility of its kind in the world. Freshwater for the plant will be supplied by an on-site seawater desalination plant authorized to divert up to 16,000 gallons per minute from the Corpus Christi Inner Harbor.

FacilityDescription: The Corpus Christi Terminal in Nueces County, Texas is a crude oil and condensate terminal that can store up to 6 million barrels of petroleum and natural gas liquids. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality authorized construction of a new condensate splitter in 2015, designed to process 100,000 barrels of condensate and crude oil every day. The first phase of construction was completed in November 2016, but the 50,000 barrel per day processing train was shut down just three months later for commercial and legal reasons. Although the first processing train is operating, according to the facility's <a href="https://us-east-1.storage.xata.sh/m70jvto4abm3e3k10mvcm5cp12a7knv0">operating permit<a/>, the second processing train has not been constructed and would be "installed in the future."

FacilityDescription: The Cove Point LNG Terminal is a liquefied natural gas export terminal located on the Chesapeake Bay in Calvert County, Maryland, about 45 miles southeast of Washington, DC. The terminal also has import and gas storage capabilities. It was originally constructed in 1972 solely as an import facility. In 2018, the Cove Point LNG Terminal’s exporting operation came online, along with a 130-megawatt power plant that provides the energy necessary to liquify natural gas on-site for export. The terminal has the capacity to produce 5.75 million metric tons of LNG per year for export. The 88-mile Cove Point Pipeline, with its two associated compressor stations, provides natural gas to the terminal. The pipeline was originally constructed in 1972 to service the import operation. When the export operation was added, the compressor stations associated with the pipeline—the Pleasant Valley Compressor Station in Fairfax County, Virginia, and the Loudoun Compressor Station in Loudoun County, Virginia—were expanded to boost their compression capability and to facilitate the transportation of more gas to the terminal.
ResearchNotes:

Owned by Covestro, the former materials science division of Bayer, the Baytown Plant is the company's largest manufacturing site in North America.

FacilityDescription: Gas Transmission Northwest, LLC is building the Coyote Springs Compressor Station, a greenfield facility, in Morrow County, Oregon. The compressor station will expand the capacity of an existing pipeline by increasing the pressure of incoming natural gas.

The Texas GulfLink Deepwater Port is a proposed oil export terminal that would be located in the Gulf of Mexico, approximately 30 miles off the coast of Brazoria County, Texas. The Deepwater Port is part of a larger infrastructure project, consisting of around 57 miles of new pipeline that would connect the Port to the proposed Jones Creek Crude Storage Terminal to be located approximately one hour south of Houston. If approved, the GulfLink project would have capacity to export 1,000,000 barrels of crude oil per day.

The Delfin LNG Deepwater Port is a proposed liquefied natural gas terminal located off the coast of Cameron Parish, Louisiana. Once fully-constructed, it would be capable of exporting up to 12 million metric tons of liquefied natural gas every year (about 1.6 billion cubic feet per day).

The onshore facilities would also be connected to an offshore pipeline, which would transport natural gas to a separate offshore liquefaction facility, the Delfin LNG Deepwater Port.

FacilityDescription: The Demicks Lake Gas Plant is a natural gas processing plant located in McKenzie County, North Dakota, designed to separate fracked gas extracted from the Bakken shale formation into dry natural gas (which is mostly methane) and natural gas liquids. The plant has been constructed in phases, with Demicks Lake I and II completed in 2019 and 2020. The third plant, Demicks Lake III, was completed in 2023 and increased the plant's total gas processing capacity from 400 to 600 million standard cubic feet per day.

FacilityDescription: The Ingevity DeRidder Facility has been operating since 1977 in Beauregard Parish, approximately 45 miles north of Lake Charles, Louisiana. The chemical plant manufactures emulsifiers, rosin, and tall oil fatty acids, used for products like adhesives, asphalt, drilling and oilfield chemicals. An expansion project completed in 2022 increased the company’s caprolactone polyol production by 40%, used mainly for industrial equipment, adhesives, coatings, and automotive applications.

The Dickinson Refinery in Stark County, North Dakota, was the first new oil refinery built in the United States in over three decades. It began operating in 2014, but was shut down just four years later to convert the refinery into a renewable diesel plant that processes tallow and vegetable oils. The Dickinson Refinery is owned and operated by Dakota Prairie Refining LLC, an affiliate of Marathon Petroleum.

FacilityDescription: The CF Industries Donaldsonville Nitrogen Complex is the world’s largest ammonia production facility, with the capacity to manufacture up to 8 million tons of nitrogen products each year. It spans 1,400 next to the Mississippi River in Donaldsonville, Louisiana, an hour west of New Orleans. The plant manufactures ammonia, granular urea, urea ammonium nitrate, and diesel exhaust fluid for agricultural and industrial uses. Production starts with the manufacture of ammonia, which is used to produce urea and nitric acid, which are further used to manufacture urea ammonium nitrate and diesel exhaust fluid. Ammonia production at the plant began in 1966. It is also the state’s largest source of greenhouse gases and toxic air and water pollution. The plant is responsible for 185 accidental releases of chemicals since 2006 into a neighborhood that is three quarters Black or Latino, with more than half of local households earning less than $25,000 per year.
ResearchNotes:

The company is scheduled to begin construction on the project in 2023 and begin operation at the beginning of 2024. It would involve increases in carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxide emissions from the facility.

FacilityDescription: The Koch Fertilizer Plant began operating in 1973 and is located in Enid, Oklahoma, approximately 85 miles north of Oklahoma City. FacilityDescription: The Cronus Ammonia Plant is a proposed fertilizer manufacturing facility located in central Illinois, about three hours south of Chicago. It was first announced in 2013 and originally designed to manufacture ammonia and urea, key ingredients in the production of nitrogenous fertilizers. After nearly five years of delay, the privately-owned company behind the project revised the plant’s original design to only include the ammonia portion of the project. According to the company website, the new Cronus Ammonia Plant could begin operating in early 2024 if the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency issues a new Clean Air Act pre-construction permit.

The plant would produce up to 3,031 tons of ammonia fertilizer per day and could emit over 2 million tons of greenhouse gases per year, equivalent to half of the emissions from a coal-fired power plant. **Comments on the draft permit can be submitted until December 15, 2023. Please see the [public notice](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/fa/f3/faf32345dd374904939f404f47b83cf0.1700673560.pdf) for more information.**

FacilityDescription: The Koch Iowa Fertilizer Complex is a nitrogen fertilizer manufacturing plant located in southeast Iowa. It was the first greenfield, natural gas-based fertilizer plant built in more than 25 years and is one is one of the largest in the country, capable of producing up to 2.2 million tons of nitrogen fertilizer products every year. This facility was formerly owned by the Iowa Fertilizer Company, a subsidiary of OCI Global, and known as the IFC Fertilizer Complex, but in August 2024 it was sold to a subsidiary of Koch Industries.
ResearchNotes:
GB 12/10/24: Updated facility name and linkages to reflect that Koch purchased this facility.

The primary raw material is natural gas which is delivered by pipeline. The facility manufactures anhydrous ammonia, urea ammonium nitrate (UAN), granular urea, and diesel exhaust fluid (DEF). By-products of the process are liquid urea and nitric acid. All of the final products will be transported from the facility by either truck or rail. There are several production areas within the plant. In addition there is support equipment such as auxiliary boilers, emergency generators, and cooling towers.

Product Description Maximum Daily Production Rates (tons/day)
Urea Ammonium Nitrate (UAN) = 4,740
Granular Urea = 1,320
Ammonia = 2,425
Diesel Exhaust Fluid = 990
facility_name: Koch Iowa Fertilizer Complex (formerly IFC Fertilizer Complex)

FacilityDescription: Formosa's FG LA Complex (also known as the "Sunshine Project") is a proposed petrochemical and plastics manufacturing plant located in St. James Parish, Louisiana, along the Mississippi River. If built, the plant would convert ethane and propane (types of natural gas liquids, or "NGLs") into petrochemicals like ethylene, propylene, and ethylene glycol, which it would use to make plastics like high-density polyethylene, low-density polyethylene, and polypropylene. It would have the capacity to produce 2.4 million tonnes of ethylene per year. The manufacturing site will also include utilities that treat water and generate electricity and steam for use on-site, a flare system, chemical and product storage, and loading facilities for importing and exporting raw ingredients and finished products. The manufacturing complex will be served by two 33-mile, 16-inch ethane and ethylene pipelines operated by Boardwalk Louisiana Midstream, LLC.

FacilityDescription: The Flint Hills Resources (FHR) Corpus Christi West Refinery is a crude oil refinery located in Nueces County, Texas. Originally built in 1953, the refinery produces fuels for San Antonio, Austin, and the Dallas-Fort Worth area. It also produces petrochemicals. A major expansion project was completed in 2018, increasing crude processing capacity at the refinery to 269,700 barrels per day. The West Plant is connected to Flint Hills’ East Plant (another refinery) and the company’s crude oil terminal in Ingleside, Texas. Flint Hills is a subsidiary of Koch Industries.

FacilityDescription: The Freeport LNG Liquefaction Facility is a liquefied natural gas export terminal located on Quintana Island, near the city of Freeport, in Brazoria County, Texas. The terminal consists of three liquefaction trains, each capable of processing up to 6 million tons of LNG every year (approximately 870 billion cubic feet). An expansion project to build a fourth liquefaction train was authorized in 2018. If built, the Train 4 project would increase liquefaction capacity at the Freeport LNG terminal by an additional 5 million tons per year. The Export Terminal receives gas from the Freeport LNG Pretreatment Facility, located about two and a half miles north. After an explosion in June 2022 that created a 450-foot fireball, the facility shut down for more than six months. In February 2023, federal regulators granted permission for the plant to resume operations.

FacilityDescription: As part of the Alaska LNG Project's Gas Treatment Facilities, the new Gas Treatment Plant (GTP) will incorporate three gas treatment systems that would process, in all, about 3.9 billion cubic feet (Bcf) per day of sour feed gas. Located in Prudhoe Bay on the North Slope, the GTP will received the feed gas produced from the Point Thomson Unit  (PTU) and the Prudhoe Bay Unit (PBU). These gas sources contain carbon dioxide, hydrogen sulfide, water, and other impurities that require removal prior to liquefaction. The GTP would remove these byproducts from the natural gas, then chill, compress, and send out processed natural gas into the mainline pipeline. The byproducts removed from the natural gas would be transported by pipelines to the PBU for injection into the production field. Construction of the GTP will also require the construction of a 141-acrea gravel mine near the Putuligayuk River, extensive modifications to the existing West Dock Causeway, and the construction of a 35-acre, 250 million gallon capacity water reservoir to supply GTP operation. The GTP and its associated facilities and projects will permanently impact 1,036 acres.

FacilityDescription: The Goodluck Compressor Station is a compressor in Metcalfe County, Kentucky. It was constructed as part of the Gulf Coast Express Pipeline Expansion Project and helps transport natural gas along the Gulf Coast Express Pipeline.

The Grand Forks Fertilizer Plant is a fertilizer manufacturing plant that Northern Plains Nitrogen, LLP, has proposed to construct in Grand Forks County, North Dakota. The plant would have capacity to produce 885,125 tons of ammonia per year and other nitrogen-based products in varying quantities, both for direct sale as fertilizer and for use as feedstock in downstream urea and urea ammonium nitrate facilities. The plant would use natural gas as a feedstock and to generate heat for production processes. Natural gas would be delivered via an interconnection with existing natural gas infrastructure in the area or directly from the Bakken Shale through a new pipeline. Northern Plains Nitrogen still had not begun construction on the facility six years after receiving its original air quality permit. The North Dakota Department of Environmental Quality denied the company’s fourth request for an extension of the permit in 2021 and invalidated it after the Environmental Integrity Project, in partnership with the Environmental Law and Policy Center, petitioned the state agency to do so. In January 2022, the company announced plans to resurrect the project in partnership with Summit Carbon Solutions, which is developing the largest carbon capture and storage project in the world, with capacity to capture and permanently store 12 million tons of carbon dioxide every year. According to the release, Northern Plains plans to annually capture 500,000 tons of carbon dioxide emissions, which Summit would transport and store in central North Dakota.

FacilityDescription: The Gulf Coast Ammonia Plant is located within Eastman Chemicals’ Texas City chemical complex in Galveston County, Texas, about 40 miles southeast from downtown Houston. The plant receives hydrogen and steam from Air Products’ co-located Steam Methane Reforming plant and nitrogen from an on-site air separation unit. Once construction is completed, the Gulf Coast Ammonia plant will be able to produce up to 1.35 million metric tons of liquid ammonia every year.
ResearchNotes:
https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=249395322017030

AS 9/15/22: Removed from facility description: Air Products Industrial Gas (Air Products) is currently developing a large, single-train ammonia synthesis loop known as the Gulf Coast Ammonia Plant in Galveston County, Texas. Air Products will build, own, and operate a steam methane reformer and 30 miles of associated pipelines to provide the ammonia plant with gaseous hydrogen, an onsite air separation unit to supply the plant with gaseous nitrogen, and a steam turbine generator to supply power and other utilities to operate the new Gulf Coast Ammonia Plant. The facility will also include a storage tank anticipated to be able to store up to 70,000 metric tons of liquid anhydrous ammonia.

Gulf Coast Ammonia predicts that the plant will have an annual production capacity of up to 1.35 million metric tons per year. The ammonia produced would then be transported either via Air Products’ pipelines or marine docks, which would be managed by Oiltanking North America.

Notably, the air separator unit will be built and operated on property leased from Eastman Chemical. The plant will use gaseous hydrogen and nitrogen to produce liquid ammonia.

FacilityDescription: Gulf Coast Growth Ventures' Petrochemical and Plastics Manufacturing Complex is a newly-constructed petrochemical complex in San Patricio County, Texas, north of Corpus Christi. The complex has an annual production capacity of 1.8 million metric tons of ethylene, 1.3 million metric tons of polyethylene, and 1.1 million metric tons of monoethylene glycol, which is produced from ethylene and can be used to make polyethylene terephthalate (PET) resins and polyester fibers. The facility, which is jointly owned by SABIC of Saudi Arabia and ExxonMobil, also features a supporting utilities plant that provides onsite power generation. In 2017, local authorities approved $249 million in school district property tax breaks and $210 million in county tax incentives for ExxonMobil and SABIC. As of Oct. 4, 2023, the facility had committed 63 air and water pollution violations, according to Texas Commission on Environmental Quality records.

FacilityDescription: IGP Methanol LLC’s Gulf Coast Methanol Complex was a proposed methanol production plant that would have been located along the banks of the Mississippi River, approximately 25 miles south of New Orleans. Consisting of four identical methanol production units, it would have been the largest methanol plant in the world, with capacity to produce up to 7.3 million metric tons of methanol per year— more than the United States’ total methanol production capacity in 2019 (about 6.1 million metric tons, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA, 2019)). In 2021, the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality confirmed that the air permit authorizing construction of the facility had expired because the company failed to begin construction within a reasonable time. If the project were to move forward, the company would have to apply for a new permits. However, representatives of IGP Methanol LLC have made statements indicating that the company intends to scale back the size and capacity of the plant significantly, citing the high concentration of methanol plants in the region.

FacilityDescription: The Gulf LNG Terminal is an existing liquefied natural gas import terminal in Jackson County, Mississippi, located southeast of the City of Pascagoula on the Mississippi Sound. The Import Terminal has the capacity to process and transport around 1.5 billion cubic feet per day of natural gas that has been imported to the United States from foreign markets. In September 2015, Gulf LNG Liquefaction Company, LLC (a subsidiary of Kinder Morgan) submitted an incomplete Clean Air Act application to construct a new liquefied natural gas export terminal adjacent to the existing facility. The proposed Gulf LNG Export Terminal would consist of two liquefaction trains capable of processing up to 10.85 million tons of liquefied natural gas every year (about 1.4 billion cubic feet per day). The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission authorized the expansion project on July 19, 2019.

ResearchNotes:
CM 12/19/23 deleted: On October 4, 2023, Cameron Interstate Pipeline LLC applied to expand the Holbrook Compressor Station in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana. The facility was originally permitted as a major source under the PSD program. However, the compressor station has never been operated as a PSD major  source. Only seven of the 12 permitted compressor engines are installed and operating, which results in a potential to emit of NOx below the PSD major source threshold. Therefore, the Title V permit was revised to reflect minor source status under the PSD program.

FacilityDescription: The HollyFrontier Tulsa Refinery is an existing crude oil refinery located in Tulsa, Oklahoma. This facility was constructed over a century ago and is now owned and operated by the HollyFrontier Corporation. It consists of two plants, the East Refinery and the West Refinery, which are connected by pipeline and can process up to 125,000 barrels of crude oil per day (5.25 million gallons). Click here and here to view fenceline monitoring results from the east and west portions of this facility, respectively.
ResearchNotes:
The facility is a major source for Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) and a major source of Hazardous Air Pollutants (HAPs).

HollyFrontier Tulsa Refining LLC (HFTR) owns and operates three facilities, the East Refinery (HFTREast), the West Refinery (HFTR-West), and the Holly Energy Partners (HEP). These facilities are considered collocated and part of a single facility site for the purpose of Title V applicability; however, they are operated under separate Part 70 permits.

HollyFrontier Tulsa Refining LLC (HFTR) and Holly Energy Partners (HEP) operate the Tulsa Refinery and product loading terminal under three separate permits. The two refineries owned by HFTR were acquired at separate times, therefore, are permitted separately. The loading terminal is owned and operated by HEP, resulting in another separate permit for it. However, the two refineries and loading terminal are interconnected and collocated, requiring that they be treated as a single facility when conducting a PSD analysis.

FacilityDescription: One of eight new natural-gas fired compressor stations proposed for the Alaska Nikiski LNG Pipeline.

The MarkWest Hopedale Fractionation Facility processes bulk natural gas liquids from the Marcellus and Utica shale fields into constituent products. Located in Jewett, Ohio (approximately 60 miles west of Pittsburgh, PA), the five fractionation trains at the facility can process approximately 320,000 barrels of natural gas liquids per day. Propane and butane processed at Hopedale is transported east, loaded onto marine vessels, and delivered to domestic and international markets.

From SK: The MarkWest Hopedale Fractionation Facility is a midstream facility in Jewett, Harrison County, Ohio that processes natural gas liquids (NGLs) from processing plants in both the Marcellus and Utica shale Fields. Hopedale currently has a processing capacity of 240,000 barrels per day (bpd), which is double its capacity from 2015.6 Additionally, MarkWest plans an expansion that will further increase the Hopedale complex’s capacity by 80,000 bpd.7

According to MarkWest, “[a]ll NGLs, other than purity ethane . . . produced at [the] Cadiz Complex, Seneca Complex, Harmon Creek Complex, Majorsville Complex, Mobley Complex and Sherwood Complex are gathered to the Houston Complex or to the Hopedale Complex through a system of NGL pipelines to allow for fractionation into purity NGL products.”8 Since December of 2018, MarkWest began transporting propane and butane from Hopedale to the Marcus Hook Facility on the eastern border of Pennsylvania “where it is loaded onto marine vessels and delivered to domestic and international markets.”9

The gas plant receives raw natural gas from local oil and gas producers then processes it into both propane and a which is a mixture of natural gas liquids that have not yet been separated referred to as a Y-grade liquid.

The Jones Creek Storage Terminal is a proposed crude oil storage facility that would be located in Brazoria County, Texas, approximately one hour south of Houston. The Jones Creek Terminal is part of a larger infrastructure project, consisting of approximately 57 miles of new pipeline that would connect the Terminal to the proposed Texas GulfLink Deepwater Port to be located in the Gulf of Mexico, approximately 30 miles off the coast of Brazoria County. If built, the Jones Creek Terminal would have capacity to store 9.2 million barrels of crude oil.

FacilityDescription: The Jordan Cove LNG terminal was a proposed facility in Coos County, Oregon that would have been capable of producing up to 7.8 million tons of liquefied natural gas every year for export. The natural gas for the facility would have been supplied by the Pacific Connector Gas Pipeline, a proposed 229-mile-long pipeline that would have been built as part of the Jordan Cove Energy Project. Since it was initially proposal in 2007, the Jordan Cove Energy Project has faced heavy opposition. In their latest attempt to revive the project, Pembina, the Canadian corporation behind Jordan Cove, was unable to secure the necessary environmental permits from the state of Oregon and officially canceled the project in December 2021.

On June 11, 2021, Northwest Innovation Works announced the cancellation of the construction of this facility, as the facility was unable to secure the necessary state permits to proceed with the project.

FacilityDescription:
The Kenai Nitrogen Operations Facility is a proposed fertilizer plant located on the Kenai Peninsula, near Nikiski, Alaska. This facility was first constructed in 1968 and doubled in size roughly a decade later, making it the second largest producer of ammonia and urea in the United States until it was shut down in 2007. At the time of its closure, the Kenai Nitrogen Facility could produce nearly 2 million metric tons of ammonia and urea per year, primarily for export to overseas markets in South Korea, Mexico, and Taiwan. The facility’s current owner, Nutrien Ltd., proposed to resurrect the mothballed plant in 2013. After more than six years of delay, the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation renewed the project’s air construction permit and restarted the clock to build the Kenai Nitrogen Operations Facility in early 2021.

Additional public records from the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation related to the plant can be found here.

FacilityDescription: The Lafferty Compressor Station is located in Ritchie County, West Virginia. Antero Midstream LLC owns and operates the facility, which compresses natural gas from surrounding pipelines for future pipeline transportation.

The Westlake Ethylene Plant is an ethylene cracker located in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana, designed to convert ethane and propane (types of natural gas liquids, or "NGLs") into more than 1 billion pounds of ethylene and 148 million pounds of propylene every year, as well as other byproducts like methane and hydrogen. The plant was formerly owned by Equistar Chemicals and shut down in 2001. Indorama Ventures Olefins purchased the idled cracker in 2015 and began a major renovation, which was completed in December 2018. According to the company’s permit application, “the plant experienced significant start-up related issues” that resulted in excessive flaring and was shut down again in June 2019. Indorama Ventures Olefins implemented "more than 300 actions and improvements” before restarting the cracker in early January 2020.

FacilityDescription: The proposed Lake Charles LNG Export Terminal would be located in Calcasieu Parish, in Southwestern Louisiana, next to the existing Lake Charles LNG import terminal. Owned and operated by affiliates of Energy Transfer LP, the export terminal was originally authorized in 2015 but, after nearly seven year and three permit extensions, is still struggling to secure the long-term offtake agreements and the financial backing necessary to move forward. If built, the Lake Charles LNG Export Terminal would be capable of producing up to 16.45 million tons of liquefied natural gas every year.
ResearchNotes:
CM 12/19/23 deleted: On August 18, 2023, Lake Charles Exports LLC [applied](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/08/00/0800d24d1a664bf69c34b7bb59349f13.1698692853.pdf) for authorization to export about 851 million cubic feet of liquefied natural gas per year from its proposed LNG export terminal in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana. **Public comments on the application can be submitted until November 6. Please see the [public notice](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2023/09/05/2023-19053/lake-charles-exports-llc-application-for-long-term-authorization-to-export-liquefied-natural-gas-to) for more information. You can also submit comments using the Sierra Club’s website [here](https://act.sierraclub.org/actions/National?actionId=AR0402483).**

On April 21, 2023, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) [denied]( https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/e6/bc/e6bc92842692467ca2d5e3b326028ed8.1682446619.pdf) Lake Charles LNG’s request for a three-year extension to export LNG to any country with which the U.S. has not entered into a free trade agreement. The DOE also issued a [new policy]( https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/51/56/5156f50a0e06473fa69a6c490f8f73cd.1682451515.pdf), stating that it will no longer consider applications for extensions unless an applicant can show it has physically begun construction and that it faced extenuating circumstances beyond its control to meeting the deadline.
