FacilityDescription: The Lake Charles Methanol Facility is a proposed methanol plant that would be located in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana, about 10 miles southwest of Lake Charles. It was first authorized in 2016 and designed to convert petroleum coke into methanol, hydrogen, and other industrial gases and chemical products, like sulfuric acid. The company planned to transport the methanol and sulfuric acid by pipeline to a neighboring tank farm owned by the Port of Lake Charles, where the chemicals were to be stored and later exported. After seven years of delay, multiple permit extensions, and a $2 billion loan from the U.S. Department of Energy, Lake Charles Methanol decided to scrap the original project and pursue a more traditional approach to methanol production using natural gas. According to the project website, Lake Charles Methanol plans to capture and permanently sequester 1 million metric tons of CO2 per year, which would be transported through Exxon’s Denbury pipeline. For more information on carbon capture at this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.
ResearchNotes:
CM 12/19/23 deleted: On October 26, Lake Charles Methanol submitted a [new application](https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/53/89/53897041b42a4d00b04a6530c5a9ed61.1700495379.pdf) to the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality to build a methanol plant in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana. The facility was first authorized in 2016, but after seven years of delays the company is applying for fresh construction permits. The new plant would be able to process 10,000 metric tons of methanol per day. Construction could begin as early as June 2024, with operations expected to begin in June 2027.

FacilityDescription: The Lake Charles Refinery is an oil refinery in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana. As of January 2022, it has a processing capacity of 273,000 barrels/day.
The Lambert Compressor Station is a proposed compressor station that would be located in Pittsylvania County, Virginia, along the Mountain Valley Pipelines' 75-mile Southgate pipeline.

The La Porte Complex is a petrochemical plant located on the Houston Ship Channel in Harris County, Texas. The complex manufactures ethylene, propylene, linear low-density polyethylene and low-density polyethylene, acetic acid, and vinyl acetate monomer. The plant is owned by Equistar Chemicals, a subsidiary of the Dutch multinational company LyondellBasell Industries, one of the largest plastics, chemicals and refining companies in the world. FacilityDescription: Ohio Gathering Company, LLC owns and operates the Larew Compressor Station. The facility, which is located in Monroe County, Ohio, gathers and compresses natural gas for future pipeline transportation.
The Lateral B8 Compressor Station is owned and operated by Hillcorp Energy Company, and is located in Uinta County, Wyoming. The facility compresses natural gas for pipeline transportation.

The Lemont Refinery is an existing oil refinery located in Will County, Illinois. It was originally constructed in the early 1920s and is owned and operated by the Citgo Petroleum Corporation. The Lemont Refinery has the capacity to process 177,000 barrels (7.4 million gallons) of crude oil every day into products like gasoline, diesel, jet fuel, and solvents. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.
ResearchNotes: LM 11/24/21: updated location to be on actual refinery

FacilityDescription: The Lima Refinery is a refinery in Allen County, Ohio. It was originally constructed in 1886 and is now owned and operated by Lima Refining Company, a subsidiary of Cenovus Energy. It has a crude oil capacity of 175,000 barrels (7.35 million gallons) per day and produces gasoline, gasoline blend stocks, diesel, jet fuel, petrochemicals, and other refined products. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.
ResearchNotes: CM 2/2/24 moved latest update to alerts collection LM 11/24/21: updated location to be on actual refinery

FacilityDescription: The Limetree Bay Refinery is a closed refinery located in St. Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands. The refinery had been idled since 2012, and restarted under new ownership in February 2021. The U.S. EPA ordered the refinery to stop operating in May 2021 after a series of pollution events that sprayed nearby neighborhoods with petroleum mist and caused residents to experience trouble breathing. Limetree Bay Energy decommissioned the refinery and laid off about 271 employees, according to reporting from Reuters. For additional information about the status of the refinery, visit EPA's website. Click here to view fenceline monitoring results from this facility.

Operating in Allen County, Ohio, the Matheson Tri-Gas plant primarily produces hydrogen by reforming natural gas. Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc., the owner of the plant, renamed the plant from the “Linde Lima Plant” to “Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc.” in 2019.

The Lake Charles Chemical Complex in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana began operating in 2001. It produces ethylene and petrochemicals used to manufacture soaps, detergents, shampoos, polyester fibers, and more. In January 2021, Sasol and LyondellBasell formed a 50/50 joint venture company named Louisiana Integrated Polyethylene JV. Through the joint venture, LyondellBasell acquired 50 percent of Sasol’s 1.5 million ton ethane cracker, two 1 million ton low and linear-low density polyethylene plants, and all associated infrastructure.

Part of the Alaska Nikiski LNG project, the liquefaction facility (LNG Plant), located on the Kenai Peninsula, will process, store, and transport up to 20 million tons of LNG per year carried by the mainline Alaska LNG pipeline. According to the company, the proposed facility will include three LNG trains, two 240,000 cubic meter storage tanks, terminal facilities and marine services, and two loading berths to accommodate LNG carriers up to 217,000 cubic meters. Construction and operation of the LNG Plant would require 902 acres. The existing Kenai Spur Highway would be relocated to accommodate the LNG Plant. Operation of the LNG Plant would result in discharges of treated wastewater, boiler blowdown waters, reverse osmosis reject water, and site stormwater to Cook Inlet.

Additional public records from the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation can be found here.
The Little Missouri Gas Plant and Smokey Compressor Station are located in McKenzie County, North Dakota.
ResearchNotes: https://ceris.deq.nd.gov/ext/nsite/site/9170198996565466187/

FacilityDescription: Columbia Gulf Transmission, LLC owns and operates the Lone Oak Compressor Station. The facility, which is located Marshall County, West Virginia, compresses natural gas for pipeline transportation.
The Longhorn Compressor Station is an 11-engine compressor in Loving, New Mexico.

Targa's Longhorn Gas Plant was originally built in Wise County, Texas and was designed to process 200 million standard cubic feet of fracked gas every day from the Midland shale basin. To accommodate surging oil and gas production in the Permian Basin, the plant was shut down in October 2020 and relocated to Reagan County in West Texas. The Longhorn plant is now the new "Heim Plant," named after Targa's former vice chairman and COO, Michael Heim.

In 2015, Trunkline proposed to expand the Longville Compressor as part of the Lake Charles LNG Pipeline Modifications Project, which would supply an additional 2.6 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day to the proposed Lake Charles LNG Export Terminal.

FacilityDescription: Columbia Gas Transmission LLC owns and operates the Lost River Compressor Station. The facility is located in Hardy County, West Virginia, and compresses natural gas for transportation via pipelines.

The Eurochem Fertilizer Plant was a proposed $1.5 billion fertilizer production and distribution center in St. John the Baptist Parish, Louisiana. Eurochem first proposed the project in 2013 and selected the site in 2015. Following long delays in planning and construction, Eurochem withdrew an application for an NSR permit for the plant in March 2022, effectively canceling the proposed plant.
The Lucerne Natural Gas Processing Plant in Weld County, Colorado is the largest of a nine-plant system in the DJ Basin. It has an 800 mcf/day capacity.
ResearchNotes: Lucerne 2 is an existing major source with respect to Title V and Nonattainment New Source Review (NANSR) and is an area source with respect to 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 63 National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants (NESHAP) for Source Categories and is a minor source with respect to Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD)

FacilityDescription: The Bayer Crop Science Luling Plant is an herbicide production facility located in Luling, Louisiana, on the Mississippi River, half an hour from New Orleans. Previously owned by the Monsanto Company, the site is now owned by the German company, Bayer AG, within their crop science division. Bayer acquired Monsanto in 2018. A variety of pesticides are produced on site, including glyphosate. The latter is the active ingredient in Roundup herbicide. This facility is the single largest producer of glyphosate in the world.
ResearchNotes: Previously Monsanto Luling Plant

FacilityDescription: Dominion Energy’s Magna liquefied natural gas (LNG) facility is located in Magna, Utah, just west of Salt Lake City. The facility receives natural gas from a pipeline, removes contaminants, then liquefies and stores the LNG on site. It has a storage capacity of up to 15 million gallons of liquid natural gas.
ResearchNotes: Dominion Energy Utah (Dominion) owns and operates a liquid natural gas storage facility located in Magna, Utah. The facility will take natural gas from a feed line, remove contaminants from the gas and liquefying the purified product for bulk storage on site. The stored liquid product is reintroduced as gas by pipeline during peak demand hours. The facility is capable of storing up to 15 million gallons of liquid natural gas.

FacilityDescription: The Magnolia LNG Facility is a proposed liquefied natural gas terminal located in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana. If fully-constructed, it would be capable of producing up to 8.8 million tons of liquefied natural gas every year (about 1.16 billion cubic feet per day).

MarkWest’s Majorsville Gas Plant processes wet gas from wells in Southwest Pennsylvania and West Virginia into ethane, dry gas, and a mixture of heavier natural gas liquids. The gas plant is located in Marshall County, West Virginia, approximately 15 miles east of Wheeling, West Virginia and 53 miles southwest of Pittsburgh, PA. The facility has the capacity to process up to 1.5 billion standard cubic feet of natural gas per day. The plant has been expanded incrementally over time.
ResearchNotes:
From permit H fact sheet: "MarkWest Liberty Midstream & Resources L.L.C. owns and operates the Majorsville Gas Plant. As
designed the facility will have capacity for 1,500 mmscf/day.
The Majorsville Processing Plant is used as a gathering station for gas wells throughout southwest
Pennsylvania and West Virginia. Upon entering the plant the gas goes through a molecular sieve which is
designed to remove liquids from the gas stream. Heaters are used to regenerate the mol sieve on a regular
basis to remove the water and hydrocarbons. After the mol sieve the gas will be cooled through a
cryogenic plant with mechanical refrigeration which serves to remove propane and heavier hydrocarbons
in the gas stream. The natural gas liquids from the new plant will then pass through a stabilizer to remove
any carry-over methane and ethane in the liquid stream. The remaining gas stream (mostly methane and
ethane) will pass through the deethanizers so that ethane can be separated and recovered from the gas
stream. The ethane will then be transferred via pipeline to market. The remaining natural gas will pass
through the existing compression engines or one of the electric-driven engines prior to entering the
downstream pipeline to market. Electric pumps will be located on the site to transfer the recovered liquids
to another facility for recycling or further processing." p.5

FacilityDescription: The Marcus Hook Industrial Complex in Pennsylvania is a refurbished refinery that now serves as a natural gas liquids (NGLs) hub. In 2020, the Philadelphia Inquirer reported that the complex now receives about 200,000 barrels of gas liquids a day, with the majority of the NGLs exported to Europe.

Mitsubishi Chemical Corporation's MMA Manufacturing Facility was a proposed petrochemical manufacturing complex that would have been located in Ascension Parish, Louisiana. MMA, or methyl methacrylate, is an organic chemical made from ethylene and natural gas and used to manufacture pesticides, industrial solvents, surface coatings, and polyesters. The plant, which would have been the largest of its kind in the world, was designed to produce up to 385,000 tons of MMA per year. Mitsubishi canceled the project in early 2025.

FacilityDescription: Targa Midstream Services LLC operates the Targa Mont Belvieu Complex in Chambers County, Texas. Targa’s facility processes natural gas liquids received from the Permian Basin, North Texas, and Southern Oklahoma via the Grand Prix NGL Pipeline into hydrocarbons such as ethane, propane, isobutene, normal butane, and natural gasoline. Once construction of the tenth fractionation train is completed, the Complex will be capable of processing over 1 billion barrels of natural gas liquids per day. Two additional fractionation trains are being built at the nearby Mont Belvieu North facility.

Mont Belvieu Fractionator (until 5/6/2014)

The Mont Belvieu Fractionator operates under Title V Operating Permit No. O‐612.
O615 is for the co-located Mont Belvieu Terminal.

Belvieu Fractionator separates mixed natural gas liquids (NGLs) into speciated products and transfers the products via pipeline network to the Mont Belvieu Terminal. The Mont Belvieu Terminal utilizes solution-mined
caverns for the storage of LSNG, LPG, light olefin feedstocks, and light naphtha. The terminal is connected through a distribution network of interstate and intrastate pipelines to third party storage, refining, and petrochemical facilities as well as to the neighboring Targa owned and operated Mont Belvieu Plant. No liquid processing is done at this terminal.

Three expansion projects at the existing Mont Belvieu Fractionation Complex, including: construction of two 100,000 barrel per day (bpd) natural gas liquids fractionation trains (Trains 5 and 6); a subsequent expansion to construct three additional 120,000 bpd fractionators (Trains 7-9); and a third expansion project to authorize the construction of Train 10. This facility has been expanding incrementally since 2013.

Columbia Gas Transmission LLC owns and operates the Mount Olive Compressor Station. The facility is in Jackson County, West Virginia and compresses natural gas received via pipeline for additional transport.

The Mt. Airy Terminal is an existing facility located in St. John the Baptist Parish, Louisiana, that stores and distributes a number of petrochemical and chemical products, including VGO (vacuum gas oil), asphalt, diesel, ethanol, methanol, and benzene.

FacilityDescription: The Nacero Penwell Facility is a proposed gas-to-liquids plant located in Ector County, Texas. It was originally designed to convert natural gas to methanol and then convert methanol into 115,000 barrels per day of refined gasoline products. However, in January 2023, the company announced that the Penwell Facility would now produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). According to the project website, it would also be able to use captured biogas as a feedstock and would be powered solely by renewable power. In October 2024, Nacero canceled the clean air act permits authorizing construction of the original gas-to-gasoline plant. It is unclear when it plans to reapply, but local news reports suggest that the project has been delayed by six to ten years.
ResearchNotes: AS 10/16/24 - updated facility description after permit cancelation. previously: The Nacero Penwell Facility is a proposed natural gas-to-gasoline plant located in Ector County, Texas. Once constructed, it would have the capacity to convert over 30,000 metric tons per day of methanol into 115,000 barrels per day of refined gasoline products. Although the company boasts about carbon capture, the carbon dioxide made by the plant would be used to "enhance" or boost oil recovery. While injecting carbon dioxide underground is considered carbon sequestration, using it to extract more oil and gas offsets many of its benefits. --- https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=867586602021043 AS 9/2/22: facility description updated to include ccs system Facility description sources: https://www.ogj.com/refining-processing/gas-processing/new-plants/article/14202012/nacero-lets-contract-for-proposed-texas-gtg-plant https://cleanair.org/wp-content/uploads/Nacero_FS-FINAL_wLinks_Update12-21-21.pdf https://www.wnep.com/article/news/local/luzerne-county/nacero-gasoline-build-6-billion-plant-in-luzerne-county-pennsylvania-marcellus/523-9e473b39-9a99-42ab-9f5e-658ab83a730b https://www.pahomepage.com/news/i-team/nacero-announces-new-facility-coming-to-luzerne-county/ https://www.senatorgeneyaw.com/2022/01/12/yaw-veto-override-necessary-to-protect-pennsylvanians-from-gov-wolfs-carbon-tax/

FacilityDescription: The Natrium Extraction and Fractionation Facility in Marshall County, West Virginia is designed to process natural gas extracted from the Marcellus shale basin and fractionate natural gas liquids. Blue Racer isajoint venture to own, operate, develop, and acquire midstream assets in the Utica Shale and certain adjacent areas in the Marcellus Shale. Blue Racer’s assets include 723 miles of gathering pipelines, and the Natrium complex in Marshall County, West Virginia, with a cryogenic processing capacity of 800 MMcf/d and fractionation capacity of approximately 134 Mbbls/d. Blue Racer also owns the Berne complex in Monroe County, Ohio, with a cryogenic processing capacity of 400 MMcf/d, and NGL and condensate pipelines connecting Natrium
to Berne. Blue Racer provides gathering, processing, and marketing service primarily under percentage of liquids and fixed fee agreements.

FacilityDescription: The Nederland terminal, located between Beaumont and Port Arthur, Texas, is the largest above-ground crude oil storage facility in the U.S. According to its operator Energy Transfer, the terminal receives, stores, and distributes crude oil, NGLs, feedstocks, petrochemicals, and bunker oils (used for fueling ships and other marine vessels). As the endpoint for multiple long-haul pipelines, including the Bakken Pipeline and the Permian Express System, the terminal has a total storage capacity of approximately 31 million bbls in approximately 150 above ground storage tanks. The Blue Marlin Offshore Port project includes a new approximately 37.0-mile-long crude oil pipeline to connect the Nederland terminal through Orange County, Texas, to the existing Stingray Pipeline at Station 501 in Cameron Parish, Louisiana.

FacilityDescription: The proposed Nopetro LNG Production Facility would produce liquefied natural gas on a 60-acre site in Port St. Joe, Florida. The facility would have the capacity to process 3.86 billion cubic feet of LNG per year for export to Central and South America and the Caribbean. The facility would transport LNG-filled shipping containers onto trucks, drive them to the dock approximately 1,329 feet from the facility, then load the containers onto cargo ships for export. Because the facility is using trucks, not pipelines, to transport LNG, Nopetro LNG submitted a Petition for Declaratory Order to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), claiming the facility is not subject to FERC jurisdiction. On March 25, 2022, FERC issued an order agreeing with the company, stating that the project would not be subject to the Commission’s jurisdiction under the Natural Gas Act. Nopetro LNG originally planned to expand the facility to include three natural gas liquefaction trains. On July 18, 2023, officials with Miami-based Nopetro Energy told the Port St. Joe Star, a local newspaper, that they would "no longer pursue" plans to build an LNG terminal in St. Joe, about two hours southwest of Tallahassee.

FacilityDescription: The PCS Lima Nitrogen Plant is a nitrogen fertilizer production facility located in Lima, Ohio, about two hours north of Cincinnati. The plant primarily produces ammonia and urea-based fertilizer products. It is the second-largest nitrogen fertilizer plant in the United States, and is located next to the BP Husky Oil Refinery and a General Dynamics armored tank plant. The facility is owned by PCS Nitrogen Ohio, L.P., a subsidiary of Nutrien Ltd. Nutrien is a Canadian company that formed in 2018 and is headquartered in Saskatchewan. The company is the third largest producer of nitrogen fertilizer in the world. It was initially constructed in 1971.

FacilityDescription: In September 2022, Venture Global signed a CCS agreement with Louisiana Department of Natural Resources, allowing the company to develop a roughly 9,000-acre injection site offshore of Plaquemines Parish. This site would sequester carbon dioxide captured from the company's Plaquemines LNG Terminal. Venture Global announced a combined 500,000 metric tons of CO2 would be sequestered from their Calcasieu Pass and Plaquemines facilities, though it is unclear how much of that CO2 would be injected at the Plaquemines site. For more information on this facility, please see Empower LLC's report on Carbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.

Once both facilities are operational, Venture Global plans to inject 1 million metric tons of CO2 annually into a single injection well. For more information on this facility, please see Empower LLC's report onCarbon Capture and Sequestration in Louisiana.

FacilityDescription: The Blue Blade Energy SAF Plant is a proposed sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) plant in the Midwest. The plant is a joint venture between United Airlines, Tallgrass, and Green Plains Inc. The plant would provide SAF to fuel flights between United's hub airports in Chicago and Denver.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.united.com/en/us/newsroom/announcements/cision-125256
https://s201.q4cdn.com/120229500/files/doc_news/2022/09/Green-Plains-Tallgrass-and-PNNL-Awarded-DOE-Funding-for-Sustainable-Aviation-Fuel-Technology.pdf

FacilityDescription: The New Energy Chemicals Port Lavaca Plant is a proposed chemical production facility in Calhoun County, Texas. The facility would receive ethanol from New Energy Chemicals' biomass refinery in Mason City, Iowa and produce sustainable aviation fuel and bio-based ethylene.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.chemanalyst.com/NewsAndDeals/NewsDetails/new-energy-chemicals-to-supply-ethylene-for-dow-plastic-solutions-25936
https://newenergyblue.com/
facility_name: New Energy Chemicals Port LaVaca Plant

FacilityDescription: The Bayou Fuels Natchez Plant is a proposed sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production facility in Adams County, Mississippi. The plant would produce SAF using woody biomass waste and sell it to Southwest Airlines and IAG/British Airways. Bayou Fuels plans to capture carbon dioxide produced at the plant to reduce its carbon footprint.
ResearchNotes:
location estimated from map provided here: https://velocys.com/projects/bayou-fuels/
https://www.bayoufuels.com/facility/

FacilityDescription: The Battlefield Gas Plant is a natural gas treatment plant in DeSoto Parish, Louisiana. It processes natural gas from nearby wells before compressing it for transport.

The Florida Regional DAC Hub is a proposed direct air capture facility located in northwestern Florida in Bay County. Carbon America is collaborating with the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and other technology partners to explore the feasibility of capturing at least 50,000 metric tons of CO2 per year. In August 2023, the project was awarded up to $2.8 million in federal funding by the Department of Energy. While the project is expected to integrate a regional carbon storage hub, the DOE announcement mentions the possibility of partnering with companies seeking to utilize CO2 in industrial processes.
ResearchNotes: https://www.carbonamerica.com/fldac

FacilityDescription: The Colorado Regional DAC Hub is a proposed direct air capture facility located near Pueblo, Colorado. Carbon America is collaborating with the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and other technology partners to explore the feasibility of capturing at least 50,000 metric tons of CO2 per year. In August 2023, the project was awarded up to $3 million in federal funding by the Department of Energy. While the project is expected to integrate a regional carbon storage hub, the DOE announcement mentions the possibility of partnering with companies seeking to utilize CO2 in industrial processes.
ResearchNotes: https://www.carbonamerica.com/codac

FacilityDescription: The proposed Aera Direct Air Capture Hub is located in Kern County, California, at the Belridge oil field. The Hub would capture carbon emissions from the atmosphere and sequester them nearby at Aera Energy's CarbonFrontier storage hub. In August 2023, the U.S. Department of Energy awarded up to $4.5 million to Aera Federal, along with partners Batelle, Mosaic Materials, and Carbon Capture, for a feasibility study.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.energy.gov/fecm/project-selections-foa-2735-regional-direct-air-capture-hubs-topic-area-1-feasibility-and
https://www.aeraenergy.com/aera-dac-feasability/

FacilityDescription: ASRC Energy Services is conducting a pre-feasibility study for a potential direct air capture facility in Alaska. The company is currently evaluating locations in the North Slope, the Interior (Fairbanks), and/or South Central (Anchorage, Kenai Peninsula, Mat-Su). The study will also review existing technologies and identify potential modifications required to operate in the Arctic. In August 2023, the project was selected by the Department of Energy to receive up to $3 million in federal funding.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.energy.gov/fecm/project-selections-foa-2735-regional-direct-air-capture-hubs-topic-area-1-feasibility-and
https://www.akleg.gov/basis/get_documents.asp?session=33&docid=28089

FacilityDescription: The Enterprise Mentone West Gas Plant is a gas processing plant in Loving County, Texas. This facility and the Mentone Gas Plant nearby make up a larger gas processing complex.
ResearchNotes: https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=278479172024009

FacilityDescription: The Illinois Basin Regional DAC Hub is a proposed direct air capture facility located in Illinois (the exact location has not yet been announced). The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and other technology partners are exploring the feasibility of capturing at least 50,000 metric tons of CO2 per year. In August 2023, the project was awarded up to $3 million in federal funding by the Department of Energy. While the project is expected to store the carbon dioxide underground, the DOE announcement mentions the possibility of partnering with companies seeking to utilize CO2 in industrial processes.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.energy.gov/fecm/project-selections-foa-2735-regional-direct-air-capture-hubs-topic-area-1-feasibility-and
https://prairie.illinois.edu/features/evolving-energy/#:~:text=The%20Illinois%20Basin%20Regional%20DAC,of%20CO2%20per%20year.

FacilityDescription: Chevron is proposing to build a direct air capture facility in the San Joaquin Valley in Central California. This project builds on other low-carbon technology pilots and proposed projects planned at Chevron's assets in the Valley. In August 2023, the Department of Energy awarded the project $3 million for a feasibility study.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.energy.gov/fecm/project-selections-foa-2735-regional-direct-air-capture-hubs-topic-area-1-feasibility-and
https://energycapitalhtx.com/doe-direct-air-capture-project
facility_name: Western Regional Direct Air Capture Hub

FacilityDescription: General Electric is proposing to build a direct air capture facility in the greater Houston Area, at the Pineywoods CCS Hub. It would be capable of removing 1 million metric tons of CO2 from the atmosphere annually using renewable or nuclear energy. The CO2 could be stored underground or utilized. In August 2023, the Department of Energy selected the project to receive $2.6 million in federal funding for a feasibility study.
ResearchNotes: PB 4/4/24: DOE announcement says it will be located at the Tenaska hub (the Pineywood Hub most likely), so assuming the counties are the same https://www.energy.gov/fecm/project-selections-foa-2735-regional-direct-air-capture-hubs-topic-area-1-feasibility-and

FacilityDescription: The proposed Orchard hub is located in Gaines County, Texas. The company has applied to construct 7 injection wells to store carbon dioxide underground.
ResearchNotes: applied for Class VI permits in early 2023 but has no website or press releases

FacilityDescription: ExxonMobil is proposing to build a carbon sequestration hub in Jefferson County, Texas. The Rose Carbon Storage Hub will have three injection wells used to store carbon underground.
ResearchNotes: has applied for Class VI permits, but very little info publicly available

FacilityDescription: The proposed West Bay Carbon Storage Hub is located in Galveston County, Texas, near Houston. In late 2023, BP applied for Class VI permits to construct and operate three carbon dioxide injection wells at the site.
ResearchNotes:
has applied for 3 Class VI permits

May be part of this collaboration between BP and Linde: https://www.bp.com/en/global/corporate/news-and-insights/press-releases/bp-and-linde-plan-major-ccs-project-to-advance-decarbonization-efforts-across-texas-gulf-coast.html
facility_name: BP West Bay Carbon Storage Hub

FacilityDescription: In March 2024, Technip Energies and LanzaTech Global were awarded $200 million in Bipartisan Infrastructure Law and Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) funding by the U.S. Department of Energy to develop a technology that produces ethylene from captured carbon dioxide. The new technology would be integrated directly into existing ethane crackers, where it will capture CO2 emissions from the production process and convert the captured carbon into "sustainable" ethylene. Ethylene is a key ingredient in the manufacturing of plastics and chemicals.
ResearchNotes:
https://ir.lanzatech.com/news-releases/news-release-details/technip-energies-and-lanzatech-selected-us-department-energy

https://web.archive.org/web/20240415180735/https://ir.lanzatech.com/news-releases/news-release-details/technip-energies-and-lanzatech-selected-us-department-energy

FacilityDescription: Orchard One is a proposed direct air capture and sequestration facility located in central Wyoming. Spiritus plans to capture up to 2 million tons of CO2 from the atmosphere each year using a proprietary technology that claims to use a  lower temperature than other DAC facilities while reducing costs to under $100 per ton. The captured carbon will be sequestered on-site by partner Casper Carbon Capture. If constructed, the facility will be the first of Spiritus's "Carbon Orchard" sites.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.energytech.com/energy-efficiency/article/21285044/spiritus-announces-direct-air-capture-carbon-orchard-in-wyoming-to-sequester-2-million-metric-tons-of-carbon-annually

https://www.spiritus.com/about

FacilityDescription: The Magnolia Amine Plant is located in northwestern Louisiana, in Red River Parish. The plant uses an aqueous solution of amines to remove carbon dioxide and hydrogen sulfide from natural gas. Enable Midstream Partners is also planning to install carbon capture equipment at the facility, with the captured carbon dioxide sent off-site to a sequestration facility.

Brightmark's Thomaston Circularity Center is a proposed chemical recycling plant in Upson County, Georgia. It would process over 400,000 tons of used plastic products per year using pyrolysis, where plastics are melted down into fuel or ingredients used to manufacture new plastics.
ResearchNotes:
AS 10/23/24 - updated facility name; https://thomastoncircularitycenter.com/

https://www.brightmark.com/newsroom/brightmark-announces-intent-to-invest-950-million-in-upson-county-georgia-to-tackle-plastic-pollution

FacilityDescription: The Targa Pembrook Gas Plant is a natural gas processing plant in Upton County, Texas.
ResearchNotes:
https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=876394612001134
Pembrook 1 completed 2019

FacilityDescription: The proposed NBU CCS site is located near CapturePoint's enhanced oil recovery field in Osage Nation territory, northwest of Tulsa, OK. The company plans to inject CO2 between 3,500 and 4,300 feet underground, underneath the oil field operations, for long-term geologic sequestration. The site has an estimated storage capacity of 100 million metric tons of CO2, and will store CO2 from a sustainable aviation fuel production facility in Cherryvale, Kansas.
facility_name: CapturePoint North Burbank Unit CCS Site

FacilityDescription: Galveston LNG Bunker Port is a proposed natural gas liquefaction facility located on Shoal Point in Texas City, TX. The facility will have two natural gas liquefaction trains that will produce approximately 600,000 gallons of LNG per day to be used as marine fuel.
ResearchNotes:
PB 5/24/24: updated coordinates from usace public notice

location estimated from map on website: https://www.galvestonlng.com/project

FacilityDescription: The Caliche Beaumont Sequestration Project is a proposed carbon sequestration hub in Jefferson County, Texas. In June 2023, Caliche Development Partners signed a lease agreement with the Beaumont City Council for 4,000 contiguous acres, an area that could hold an estimated 30 million metric tons of CO2. In exchange for the lease agreement, CDP will pay the city an estimated $24 million over the life of the project. CDP applied to construct three injection wells for long-term carbon storage in May 2024, but the captured carbon may also be used as a feedstock for various applications.
ResearchNotes: applied for class vi permits on 5/1/24, but docs not yet available

FacilityDescription: The PIT Hydrogen & SAF Hub is a proposed hydrogen and sustainable aviation fuel production facility at the Pittsburgh International Airport in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The facility could produce up to 68,000 metric tons of hydrogen fuel or up to 70 million gallons of sustainable aviation fuel per year. It could also produce both fuels simultaneously, though at a lower rate. The facility would use both natural gas and fugitive methane escaping from coal mines, though the project "hinges on federal tax credits" for the use of fugitive coal methane.
ResearchNotes:
https://www.safpittsburgh.com/
https://investors.cnx.com/news-releases/2024/05-15-2024-114532918

FacilityDescription: The Brown 4 sequestration site is a proposed carbon sequestration facility in Manistee County, Michigan. Lambda Energy plans to sequester carbon from ethanol plants, cement plants, natural gas processing plants, and other industrial sources in the Niagaran Pinnacle Reefs, an underground hydrocarbon reservoir comprised of multiple compartmentalized "reefs" that can act like storage tanks. Lambda, the largest oil and gas producer in the state, will convert their legacy oil and gas-producing reefs for long-term carbon storage.
ResearchNotes: https://lambdaenergyllc.com/co2-sequestration

FacilityDescription: Hanwha Corporation and INEOS Nitriles are exploring building a million metric ton per year ammonia production plant in the US. The ammonia from the plant would be made from natural gas with carbon sequestration. According to the press release INEOS issued in May 2024, the two companies plan to make a final investment decision in 2026 and bring the plant online by 2030. The ammonia would be used to reduce the carbon footprint of INEOS's acrylonitrile products. INEOS has two acrylonitrile plants in the US, one in Green Lake, Texas and the other in Lima, Ohio.
ResearchNotes: https://www.ineos.com/news/shared-news/hanwha-and-ineos-agree-heads-of-terms-to-study-a-low-carbon-ammonia-facility-in-the-usa/

FacilityDescription: Heirloom has announced plans to construct two direct air capture facilities at the Port of Caddo-Bossier in Shreveport, Louisiana. The larger facility, which will be capable of removing 300,000 tons of CO2 per year from the atmosphere, is part of Project Cypress, which receives funding from the Department of Energy's Regional DAC Hubs program. Heirloom has also proposed a second DAC facility near the Project Cypress facility, which is expected to remove an additional 17,000 tons of CO2 annually once operational in 2026. The company is partnering with CapturePoint for long-term underground carbon storage.

The Heirloom Tracy Facility is a direct air capture facility located in Tracy, California, east of San Francisco. The facility uses limestone to absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, and captures the CO2 by heating the limestone in a kiln powered by renewable energy.

The Jupiter Sulphur Ponca City Fertilizer Plant is located in Kay County, about 85 miles north of Oklahoma City. The plant receives acid gases, primarily hydrogen sulfide, from the co-located Phillips 66 Ponca City Refinery and produces elemental sulfur and several ammonium compounds commonly used in fertilizer, including ammonium thiosulfate and ammonium bisulfite.
facility_name: Jupiter Sulphur Ponca City Fertilizer Plant

CountyorParish: Lincoln County, Sweetwater County, Uinta County
FacilityDescription: This proposed carbon sequestration hub is located in southwestern Wyoming, in Lincoln, Sweetwater, and Uinta counties. Moxa Carbon has applied for the subsurface right-of-way to store carbon in more than 600,000 acres of public lands. The injection wells would be located on non-federal land, but the carbon would be injected into federal pore space.
ResearchNotes: coordinates approximated from map: https://eplanning.blm.gov/eplanning-ui/project/2023000/510

FacilityDescription: The Baytown Energy Center is a natural gas combined-cycle power plant located in Baytown, Texas. The 896-MW plant provides power and steam to the nearby Covestro manufacturing facility and also supplies power to the Texas electrical grid. Calpine is planning to retrofit the plant to capture 2 million metric tons of CO2 per year for storage in underground saline sites on the Gulf Coast. The Department of Energy has awarded the project up to $270 million in funding.

The AmSty St. James Facility is a styrene production plant located about 30 miles southeast of Baton Rouge, Louisiana. The facility began operating in 1971 and has two styrene production lines, the plant produces styrene monomer and polystyrene plastics.

The MMEX Green Ammonia Project is a proposed green hydrogen and ammonia production facility that would be located in Pecos County, Texas. The facility would produce up to 55 tons of hydrogen per day using solar power. This hydrogen would be used to produce ammonia, up to 209,300 tons per year initially with plans to eventually double production capacity. This facility would be part of the proposed Trans Permian H2 Hub.
ResearchNotes:
AS 11/7/24 - updated ammonia capacity to 209,300 based on SEC filing and most recent investor presentation
https://mmexresources.com/sec-filing/current-report-on-form-8-k-feb-05-2024/
statement about doubling capacity comes from homepage (see below)

Based on OGJ article, this facility will be located at the same complex as the Pecos County Refinery and the MMEX Blue Hydrogen Proejct
facility_name: Trans Permian H2 Hub: MMEX Green Hydrogen to Green Ammonia Project

FacilityDescription: The MMEX Blue Hydrogen Project is a proposed blue hydrogen production facility that would be located in Pecos County, Texas. The facility would use natural gas to produce hydrogen via autothermal reforming; carbon dioxide produced during the process would be captured. The hydrogen would be used as fuel at a nearby power plant alongside natural gas, eventually the power plant would run solely on hydrogen. This facility would be part of the proposed Trans Permian H2 Hub.
ResearchNotes:
Information comes from MMEX Resources website: https://mmexresources.com/

Good OGJ article on the proposed development https://www.ogj.com/refining-processing/refining/article/14234422/mmex-advances-west-texas-integrated-refining-hydrogen-complex

Based on OGJ article, this facility will be located at the same complex as the Pecos County Refinery and the MMEX Green Ammonia to Green Hydrogen Project.
facility_name: Trans Permian H2 Hub: MMEX Blue Hydrogen Project

FacilityDescription: The Pecos County Refinery is a proposed oil refinery that would be located in Pecos County, Texas. The refinery would be able to produce up to 11,600 barrels per day of gasoline, ultra-low sulphur diesel, and low-sulphur fuel oil. The developer plans to use carbon capture technology at the refinery that could reduce CO2 emissions by up to 95%.
ResearchNotes:
Information comes from permit materials and MMEX Resources' website https://mmexresources.com/

Good OGJ article on the proposed complex https://www.ogj.com/refining-processing/refining/article/14234422/mmex-advances-west-texas-integrated-refining-hydrogen-complex

The Pecos County Refinery will be in the same complex as the MMEX Blue Hydrogen and MMEX Green Hydrogen/Green Ammonia Projects. Point location comes from TCEQ permit app.

FacilityDescription: The Westfield Compressor Station is a new compressor station proposed as part of the Heartland Project.
The Laraway Compressor Station is a new facility proposed as part of the Greenway Project.
The Sandwich Compressor Station is an existing facility located in Kendall County, Illinois.
The Pulaski Compressor Station is a new facility proposed as part of the Heartland Project.

Project Crossroads is a proposed carbon storage hub consisting of multiple sequestration sites in northern Indiana, northeastern Illinois, and southwestern Michigan. In Indiana, BP is considering locations in Newton, Jasper, Pulaski, White and Benton Counties. The hub would store up to 23 million metric tons of CO2 per year from BP's Whiting Refinery, steel mills, and factories in Northwest Indiana. In November 2023, the Department of Energy chose the project to receive $98 million in federal funding.
ResearchNotes: https://mrvan.house.gov/media/in-the-news/department-energy-provides-98-million-carbon-storage-hub-bp-whiting-refinery

FacilityDescription: Tenaska is proposing to build the Hickory CCS Hub in Indiana, west of Lafayette. The facility, which would have up to five storage wells, would inject carbon dioxide into between 15 and 25 thousand acres of underground pore space. Tenaska is currently acquiring land and assessing the feasibility of the project. On January 2, 2024, the Warren County Commissioners denied Tenaska's application to use the county right-of-way to perform seismic surveys.
ResearchNotes:
30 year injection, 10-15 years of monitoring - https://cms5.revize.com/revize/warren/August%2021%202023%20Commissioner%20Minutes.pdf

https://hickoryccs.com/

FacilityDescription: The Lake Charles Blue Ammonia Plant is a proposed ammonia production facility that would be located in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana. The facility would produce ammonia from fracked natural gas and be able to produce up to 1.2 million metric tons of ammonia per year. According to the parent companies, the facility would utilize carbon capture and sequestration technology. Ammonia produced at the facility would primarily be exported to Japan and used as fuel.
ResearchNotes:

FacilityDescription: The International-Matex Tank Terminals LLC (IMTT) St. Rose Terminal is a "for-hire" bulk liquids storage facility located in St. Rose, Louisiana. It stores vegetable oils, petroleum, petroleum products, fuel oils, and chemicals. The terminal also plans to store ammonia produced at the proposed St. Rose Ammonia Plant in four refrigerated tanks. IMTT purchased the former St. Rose Refinery and the terminal from Shell in 2019. The refinery was permanently shut down in January 2018, according to the Energy Information Administration.

Air Liquide plans to build and operate a hydrogen liquefaction facility co-located with EQT's proposed syngas plant. The exact location is still under consideration but it may be located in southwest Pennsylvania. The company plans to convert excess hydrogen from EQT's facility into low-carbon fuel for long-distance trucking. The plant would be part of the Appalachian Regional Clean Hydrogen Hub (ARCH2).
ResearchNotes:
https://www.bizjournals.com/pittsburgh/news/2023/10/24/hydrogen-hub-unveils-more-region-plans.html

might be located southwest PA - https://www.energy.gov/sites/default/files/2023-10/H2Hubs_Appalachian_Community_Briefing.pdf
facility_name: ARCH2 Air Liquide Hydrogen Liquefaction Plant

FacilityDescription: The EQT Syngas Plant is a proposed syngas production facility that would be co-located with the proposed Air Liquide Hydrogen Liquefaction Plant. The exact location is still under consideration but it may be located in southwest Pennsylvania. The plant would use autothermal reforming to convert natural gas into syngas, which would then be processed further into low carbon aviation fuel, hydrogen, and other liquid fuels. Excess hydrogen would be sent to the Air Liquide facility and converted into low-carbon fuel for long-distance trucking. The plant would be part of the Appalachian Regional Clean Hydrogen Hub (ARCH2).
ResearchNotes:
Facility info comes from:
https://ir.eqt.com/newsroom/news-releases/news-release-details/2024/EQT-Advances-into-Phase-1-Planning-of-Clean-Hydrogen-Project/default.aspx

https://www.energy.gov/sites/default/files/2024-08/H2Hubs%20Appalachian%20Factsheet%20Booklet_08012024.pdf

might be located southwest PA - https://www.energy.gov/sites/default/files/2023-10/H2Hubs_Appalachian_Community_Briefing.pdf

FacilityDescription: CNX Resources was planning to build a "clean" hydrogen plant in southern West Virginia. The plant would have produced hydrogen via the autothermal reforming of natural gas, which would have been used to produce ammonia for potential end-users in the agriculture and marine industries. The plant would have been part of the proposed Appalachian Regional Clean Hydrogen Hub (ARCH2), but the project was cancelled in late 2024.
ResearchNotes:
AS 10/21/24 - project canceled; updated facility description

This information came from the following fact sheet: https://www.energy.gov/sites/default/files/2024-08/H2Hubs%20Appalachian%20Factsheet%20Booklet_08012024.pdf

FacilityDescription: The W.R. Grace Chemical Recycling Plant is a proposed chemical recycling plant that would be located in Howard County, Maryland. The pilot-scale facility will use catalysts in a high-temperature, low-oxygen environment to convert plastic pellets into various hydrocarbons, which could be used to produce new plastics.

Plug Power plans to produce hydrogen by retrofitting and expanding hydrogen  production and liquefaction equipment at an existing chemical plant. The plant would use industrial off-gas from a chemical plant, or possibly electrolysis, to produce hydrogen.
ResearchNotes:
Information comes from DOE fact sheet on ARCH2 projects:
https://www.energy.gov/sites/default/files/2024-08/H2Hubs%20Appalachian%20Factsheet%20Booklet_08012024.pdf

FacilityDescription: The ConocoPhillips Refugio CCS Hub is a proposed carbon sequestration site in Refugio and Aransas Counties in southern Texas, near Corpus Christi. The company would sequester CO2 from a proposed hydrogen/ammonia production facility. In early 2024, ConocoPhillips received approval to drill two stratigraphic test wells to collect geotechnical information about the site.

Project Bantam is a direct air capture facility located onsite at CapturePoint's Oklahoma Carbon Hub, in northeastern Oklahoma. The plant has the initial nameplate capacity to capture 5,000 tons of CO2 annually, but the company plans to expand up to millions of tons per year. The captured carbon will be used in CapturePoint's enhanced oil recovery operations, but CapturePoint is also developing a Class VI geologic sequestration facility on the same site.

The Newell Refinery has been operating in Hancock County, West Virginia since 1972 and is the state's only active refinery. The facility can process up to 23,500 barrels of crude oil per day to produce ultra-low sulfur diesel and gasoline, waxes and petroleum resins, base oils, and other products.
ResearchNotes:
Refining capacity and products produced from, https://ergon.com/industry/ESS/ergon-west-virginia

Only refinery in WV claim, https://www.energywv.org/wv-energy-profile/petroleum, also supported by EIA data,  https://www.eia.gov/petroleum/refinerycapacity/table3.pdf

FacilityDescription: The Cana Gas Plant  was initially constructed in 2010 and is located in central Oklahoma, about 30 miles west of Oklahoma City. The plant is designed to process up to 465 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day.
ResearchNotes: GB 8/20/2024: No street address in draft permit, but does mention facility is near El Reno, OK. Cannot figure out ECHO/FRS ID - there are at least four entries for a Cana Gas Plant in the same general location. Will request permit app in hopes of getting street address and federal IDs.

FacilityDescription: Midland Carbon's Loving CCS Hub is a proposed carbon sequestration facility in Loving County, Texas. The company will inject carbon dioxide from nearby oil and gas processing facilities, power plants, and cement plants into deep underground brine aquifer formations.
ResearchNotes: https://www.milestone-es.com/About-Us/News-and-Events/Milestone-Carbon-Announces-Land-Agreement-for-Carbon-Hub-Development-in-the-Permian-Basin/ - 22,000 acres in Loving and Midland Counties. Not sure how large the Loving site will be.

FacilityDescription: The Aethon Energy CCS Hub is a proposed carbon sequestration facility in central Louisiana, in Vernon and Sabine Parishes. Aethon Energy, a natural gas producer, is planning to capture and store carbon emissions from its operations in the Haynesville Shale.

Westlake Lake Charles South is an existing petrochemical facility that manufactures chlorinated organic products. The facility produces vinyl chloride, ethyl chloride, ethylene dichloride, solvents, caustics, and other chemicals.
ResearchNotes:
PMF 9/12/24: Added photo code in description.

KD 8/26/24 - AI 1255 was associated with LACC Westlake ethylene plant, but facility is separate from this Lake Charles South Plant.

FacilityDescription: The St. Mary Parish Hub is a proposed carbon sequestration facility in St. Mary Parish, Louisiana. The site has the estimated storage capacity to hold between 75 to 100 million metric tons of CO2.
ResearchNotes: https://onstreamco2.com/
facility_name: St. Mary Parish Carbon Storage Hub

FacilityDescription: The Nanushuk Project Seawater Treatment Plant (STP)is a proposed facility along the shoreline of Olitok Point, Alaska. The Facility would support operation of the Pikka Development Project.

FacilityDescription: The Nanushuk Processing Facility is a proposed facility in Alaska's North Slope Borough. The Facility would support operation of the Pikka Development Project.

FacilityDescription: The CTV VI Storage Project is a proposed carbon sequestration site in California. The company has not made the location of the project public, although company statements indicate the site is in Central California.
ResearchNotes:
https://news.crc.com/news/news-details/2024/Carbon-TerraVault-Provides-Second-Quarter-2024-Update/default.aspx
-102 million metric ton Class VI permit in central CA

FacilityDescription: UBE Chemicals' proposed manufacturing complex in Waggaman, Louisiana, will make organic chemicals that are used as solvents in the production of lithium-ion batteries and in semiconductor manufacturing processes. The new plant will be located within the Cornerstone Energy Park and, if built, would be the first plant of its kind in the United States.

The Titan Gas Plant is a partially constructed gas processing plant in Lea County, New Mexico. Once fully constructed, the plant is expected to process up to 220 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day.

The Jasper County Storage Facility is a proposed carbon sequestration site in Jasper County, near Beaumont, TX. BP plans to install four carbon injection wells to store carbon dioxide deep underground. The source of the CO2 has not yet been announced.

Announced in September 2024, the Woodland Biofuels Complex is a renewable natural gas plant and green hydrogen facility proposed for Southeast Louisiana. It would be located at the Globalplex Intermodal Terminal at the Port of South Louisiana, although an exact location has not been announced. The plant would convert waste biomass into fuel for transportation, heating, and electricity generation. The company plans to capture up to 870,000 metric tons of carbon and store it underground at a sequestration site to be determined at a later date. If built, the Woodland Biofuels Complex would be the largest renewable natural gas plant in the world.
ResearchNotes: address and lat/long for Globalplex Intermodal Terminal

FacilityDescription: Dude Gas Plant is a proposed gas processing plant that would be located in Lea County, New Mexico. If constructed, the plant would be able to process up to 55 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day.

The High Plains Carbon Storage project is a proposed carbon sequestration site in Kimball County, Nebraska. Tallgrass Energy plans to convert parts of the Trailblazer natural gas pipeline to transport CO2 from ethanol plants and other CO2 producers in Nebraska, Colorado, and Wyoming. The High Plains hub will be one of two planned sequestration sites along this pipeline network.
ResearchNotes: Not much info about this project, but probably part of Tallgrass's CO2 pipeline network. https://tallgrass.com/energy-solutions/co2

FacilityDescription: Ten08 Energy plans to construct an ammonia production plant along the Gulf Coast of Texas, an exact location has not yet been announced. According to the company, the facility will produce both blue and green ammonia, and is expected the produce up to 1.4 million metric tons of ammonia for export to Europe and Asia during the first phase of operation by late 2029 or early 2030.

According to several of these articles, hydrogen green hydrogen will be produced on site for the ammonia production.

FacilityDescription: UBQ Materials' chemical recycling plant would be built in Massachusetts, although the Israeli company is also considering locations in other Northeastern states. It would use a new chemical recycling process that converts unsorted household waste, including organic materials and plastics, into a new type of thermoplastic that, according to the company, could replace oil-based resins. Although details are scarce, in March 2024 the Boston Globe reported that the UBQ plant could be built within the next three years and process around 110,000 tons of garbage per year.

FacilityDescription: The West Bistineau Treating Plant is a natural gas gathering facility located near East Point in Red River Parish, Louisiana.  The plant treats and dehydrates natural gas, producing a mixture of carbon dioxide and hydrogen sulfide as a waste stream. ETC Texas Pipeline is proposing to install carbon dioxide treatment and compression equipment, so that the CO2 wastes can be injected underground at an offsite sequestration facility.

FacilityDescription: First Ammonia's flagship green ammonia plant is proposed for the Port of Victoria, Texas. It would use renewable energy and water to make ammonia, which would then be exported for use as fertilizer, fuel, or as a hydrogen carrier. According to the company, the plant's modular design would allow for fluctuations to match the availability of renewable energy. This project is being developed in partnership with Topsoe and Uniper.

FacilityDescription: Announced in January 2024, this proposed e-methanol plant would be located at the Port of Victoria's North Industrial Park in southeast Texas. Dubbed "Project Nightshade," it would use renewable energy to make green hydrogen through electrolysis, which would then be combined with captured carbon dioxide to create e-methanol. The methanol produced at the plant could be used as a fuel in the shipping industry, or as a raw material in plastic products.

https://www.portofvictoria.com/news-and-media/p/item/55335/green-energy-revolution-is-underway-at-the-port-with-prospective-emethanol-plant-from-european-energys-project-nightshade-llc

FacilityDescription: Mont Belvieu North is a part of Targa's sprawling natural gas liquids fractionation complex in Chambers County, Texas. The facility converts natural gas liquids into ethane, propane, natural gasoline, and other hydrocarbons that are used to make plastics and other high-value products. Once construction of the twelfth fractionation train is completed, the Complex will have a combined fractionation capacity of over 1.3 billion barrels of natural gas liquids per day.

Producers Midstream plans to construct a new gas processing plant in Lea County, New Mexico. To do this the company will relocate an existing gas processing plant capable of processing 60 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day, and may increase processing capacity using additional nearby assets in Texas.

Sumitomo, Hilcorp Alaska, and Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha (K-Line) have agreed to conduct a feasibility study for a cross-border CCS project that would transport CO2 from Japan for sequestration in Alaska. The project would have a total storage capacity of 50 gigatons, or about 50 years' worth of Japan's total CO2 emissions.
ResearchNotes: https://www.ogj.com/energy-transition/article/55236354/hilcrop-sumitomo-k-line-to-study-alaska-ccs-project

FacilityDescription: ACME's green ammonia plant would be built on a 245-acre site at the Port of Victoria in Texas. This integrated green hydrogen and ammonia facility would be able to produce up to 1.2 million metric tons of ammonia annually and would be powered by renewable energy.

FacilityDescription: Announced in July 2024, Jefferson Terminal South is a proposed blue ammonia export terminal that is being developed by the Port of Beaumont and Jefferson Energy Companies. The new terminal will be located on 51 acres in the Port of Beaumont, with plans for future expansion.

Existing compressor station located in Iredell County, North Carolina.

Targa's Falcon Gas Plant is located in the Permian’s Delaware basin, near Orla, Texas. It was built in 2019 and can process up to 330 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day. Once construction of the second gas processing train is completed in the second quarter of 2026, the Falcon Plant will have a combined processing capacity of 540 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day.
ResearchNotes:
AS 11/6/24 - this one is a bit confusing. Initial permit 154537 was issued 1/31/2019 for 287.5 mmscfd; then amended 8/14/23 to add 2nd train and increase throughput at T1 ("Train 1 will process up to 300 million standard cubic feet (MMscf) of natural gas per day, while Train 2 will process up to 240 MMscf per day, for a combined facility-wide processing capacity of 540 MMscf per day.") Permit amended again 2/22/24 to increase throughput at T1 to 330 mmscfd.
Application for most recent operating permit (7/12/24 - see pdf page 116) puts facility-wide capacity at 330 https://records.tceq.texas.gov/cs/idcplg?IdcService=TCEQ_EXTERNAL_SEARCH_GET_FILE&dID=8210916&Rendition=Web
BUT this contradicts the technical review for permit 154537, amended 2/22/24
OGJ announced November 24 that Falcon 2 being built by Q2 2026 - I think the second train is permitted but was never constructed; Targa will likely amend permit gain to increase capacity at T2

https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=regent.showSingleRN&re_id=933569842018330

The Argent LNG Export Terminal is a proposed liquefied natural gas (LNG) export terminal that, if built, would be capable of producing up to 20 million metric tons of LNG every year. It would be located at the Port of Fourchon on the Louisiana Gulf Coast, spanning across 144 acres west of Belle Pass. Construction of the terminal would require the Port to dredge and widen the Belle Pass Channel.

FacilityDescription: The Kern River Eastridge CCS project is located in the Kern River Oilfield, northeast of Bakersfield. The project involves capturing CO2 from the Eastridge Cogeneration Facility, a natural gas-fired plant that powers Chevron's operations in the oil field. The CO2 will be transported by pipeline to the injection wells, located about three miles from the cogeneration facility.

The facility would produce up to 193 million gallons of sustainable aviation fuel annually, using "clean" hydrogen and lower-value agricultural by-products such as corn stover and timber waste. The company is planning to build similar plants in Louisiana, Maine, and Nebraska.

FacilityDescription: Developed by a joint venture between Brazil's Braskem and Japan's Sojitz Corp., the Sustainea plant in Lafayette, Indiana, would make monoethylene glycol (MEG) from corn dextrose. The new plant would be co-located with food ingredients maker Primient, and the MEG produced would be used to make PET resin for bottles, food packaging, apparel, footwear and other products. The Indiana Economic Development Corp. has committed up to $6.9 million in incentive-based tax credits for the new plant, as well as up to $100,000 in training grants. The company eventually has plans to build three bio-MEG plants with total annual production capacity of more than 1.5 billion pounds.

FacilityDescription: The proposed Live Oak CCS Hub is located near Baton Rouge, Louisiana, in Iberville and West Baton Rouge Parishes. The facility would receive CO2 from emitters in greater West Baton Rouge and sequester it deep underground. The project is one of several being developed by parent company Tenaska.

Energy Transfer owns and operates the Arrowhead Gas Plant, located in Reeves County, Texas. The plant consists of four natural gas processing units, or "trains", and is able to process up to 920 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day.

Announced in December 2024, Abundia's chemical recycling plant would be located within the Cedar Port Industrial Park, 30 miles east of downtown Houston. It would process waste plastics into pyrolysis oil using a liquefaction technology developed by Alterra, which operates a similar facility in Akron, Ohio. Development of the site would begin in 2025, although a prospective operating date has not been announced.

FacilityDescription: Energy Transfer owns and operates the Orla Gas Plant, which is located in Reeves County in west Texas. The gas plant can process up to 250 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day.
ResearchNotes: GB 12/9/24: This plant was originally owned and operated by Crestwood Midstream, a company that was acquired by Energy Transfer in 2024. Under Crestwood Midstream the plant was referred to as "Crestwood Delaware Basin Gas Processing Plant", it's still labelled as such in TCEQ's Central Registry, but Energy Transfer is calling the plant "East Orla Gas Plant".

FacilityDescription: The BrightLoop Hydrogen Plant would be built in Mason County, West Virginia, although an exact location has not been announced. The facility would use coal and biomass to produce hydrogen, while capturing and sequestering carbon dioxide. According to the company, the hydrogen produced at the plant could be used to generate power or in industrial applications. The project has received $10 million in funding from the West Virginia Department of Economic Development.

FacilityDescription: The Enterprise Hydrocarbons Terminal (EHT) is a marine hydrocarbons processing and transfer facility along the Houston Ship Channel in Harris County, Texas.  The EHT handles Natural Gas Liquids (NGLs) like propane, butane, isobutane, and propylene.

Japan's JERA, Germany's Uniper, and ConocoPhillips plan to develop a new low-carbon ammonia production facility along the U.S. Gulf Coast. The project would include carbon capture and sequestration facilities and have an initial production capacity of 2 million metric tons per year, with potential to expand in the future.

FacilityDescription: The IRG Erie Plastics Recycling Plant is a proposed plastics recycling facility that would be constructed in Erie County, Pennsylvania. The facility plans to mechanically recycle 160,000 tons of polyethylene terephthalate (PET), high-density polyethylene (HDPE), and polypropylene polymers (PP) and convert it into 100,000 tons of recycled plastic flake annually. The facility would also produce 20,000 tons of CleanRed annually, a proprietary product that could replace a portion of coking coals used in the steelmaking process. In July 2024, the US Department of Energy announced that they would provide a loan guarantee of up to $182.6 million to IRG for the construction of the Erie Plastics Recycling Plant and an injection system at a steel manufacturing facility in Indiana.

FacilityDescription: The Hexion Geismar Plant consists of five formaldehyde production units, a methanol tank farm, and loading/unloading operations for formaldehyde and methanol in Ascension Parish near Geismar, Louisiana along the east bank of the Mississippi River. The facility began operations in 1976, with plant additions in 1985, 1991, and 1999. This facility produces approximately 1.5 billion pounds per year of aqueous formaldehyde solutions, 200 million pounds per year of Urea-Formaldehyde Concentrate (UFC}, and 110 million pounds per year of Methaform (MAF).

The Hexion Luling Plant is a formaldehyde plant located in Luling, St. Charles Parish, Louisiana. The plant is located within the Monsanto Company - Luling Plant, but is entirely owned and operated by Hexion. The Luling Plant began producing formaldehyde in 2016. The facility produces a 52% formaldehyde/water solution product with an annual capacity of 546.7 million pounds, providing formaldehyde product to neighboring facilities via pipeline and tank trunks.

Continental Carbon plans to build its proposed chemical recycling plant in Russell County, Alabama. The facility would pyrolyze used tires to produce 30,000 tons of carbon black, 15,000 tons of steel wire, and 35,000 tons of fuel oil annually. Continental Carbon previously operated a carbon black manufacturing plant at the same site, but the Alabama Department of Environmental Management forced it to close in 2022 after it failed to complete pollution reduction projects required by a consent decree.
ResearchNotes:
GB 1/2/25: Continental Carbon previously operated a carbon black facility at this location, it was forced to close at the end of 2022. The facility was unable to renew their ADEM permit due to their failure to comply with a federal consent decree and the pollution control upgrades/requirements it stipulated (https://www.wrbl.com/news/exclusive-phenix-city-carbon-black-plant-to-shut-down-at-end-of-the-month-due-to-lack-of-permit/). In the permit apps and press release, this is referred to as a new facility. The old facility used fossil fuel feedstock to produce carbon black, the proposed new facility would process spent tires into carbon black.

The production amounts comes from permit application page 31.
facility_name: Continental Carbon Alabama Chemical Recycling Plant

FacilityDescription: The Sunflower Carbon Storage site is located in Jefferson County, Texas, but the exact location has not yet been publicly announced. ExxonMobil plans to sequester carbon dioxide in underground spaces, using four planned injection wells.

Chlorum Solutions plans to build a chlor-alkali plant in Casa Grande, Arizona. The facility will produce bleach, hydrochloric acid, caustic soda, and other chemicals. According to the company, this small-scale plant will reduce transport risks and reliance on long-haul shipping of chlorine from the U.S. Gulf Coast.
